-1.event: Wang Mang consolidates his power and is declared marshal of state. Emperor Ai of Han, who had died the previous day, had no heirs.

8.event: Roman Empire general Tiberius defeats the Dalmatae on the river Bosna.

9.event: The Western Han dynasty ends when Wang Mang claims that the divine Mandate of Heaven called for the end of the dynasty and the beginning of his own, the Xin dynasty.
Arminius' alliance of six Germanic tribes ambushes and annihilates three Roman legions of Publius Quinctilius Varus in the Battle of the Teutoburg Forest.

The Battle of the Teutoburg Forest ends: The Roman Empire suffers the greatest defeat of its history and the Rhine is established as the border between the Empire and the so-called barbarians for the next four hundred years.

-12.event: The Roman emperor Augustus is named Pontifex Maximus, incorporating the position into that of the emperor.

14.event: Agrippa Postumus, maternal grandson of the late Roman emperor Augustus, is executed by his guards under mysterious circumstances while in exile.

17.event: Germanicus celebrates a triumph in Rome for his victories over the Cherusci, Chatti, and other German tribes west of the Elbe.

-20.event: Ludi Volcanalici are held within the temple precinct of Vulcan, and used by Augustus to mark the treaty with Parthia and the return of the legionary standards that had been lost at the Battle of Carrhae in 53 BC.[citation needed]

19.event: The Roman general Germanicus dies near Antioch. He was convinced that the mysterious illness that ended in his death was a result of poisoning by the Syrian governor Gnaeus Calpurnius Piso, whom he had ordered to leave the province.

23.event: Rebels sack the Chinese capital Chang'an during a peasant rebellion.
Rebels decapitate Wang Mang two days after his capital was sacked during a peasant rebellion.

25.event: Guangwu claims the throne as Emperor of China, restoring the Han dynasty after the collapse of the short-lived Xin dynasty.
Luoyang is declared capital of the Eastern Han dynasty by Emperor Guangwu of Han.

-27.event: Octavian transfers the state to the free disposal of the Roman Senate and the people. He receives Spain, Gaul, and Syria as his province for ten years.
Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus is granted the title Augustus by the Roman Senate, marking the beginning of the Roman Empire.

-28.event: A sunspot is observed by Han dynasty astronomers during the reign of Emperor Cheng of Han, one of the earliest dated sunspot observations in China.

-29.event: Octavian holds the first of three consecutive triumphs in Rome to celebrate the victory over the Dalmatian tribes.
Octavian holds the second of three consecutive triumphs in Rome to celebrate the victory over the Dalmatian tribes.

-30.event: Battle of Alexandria: Mark Antony achieves a minor victory over Octavian's forces, but most of his army subsequently deserts, leading to his suicide.
Octavian (later known as Augustus) enters Alexandria, Egypt, bringing it under the control of the Roman Republic.

After the successful invasion of Egypt, Octavian executes Marcus Antonius Antyllus, eldest son of Mark Antony, and Caesarion, the last king of the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt and only child of Julius Caesar and Cleopatra.[citation needed]

-31.event: Final War of the Roman Republic: Battle of Actium: Off the western coast of Greece, forces of Octavian defeat troops under Mark Antony and Cleopatra.

33.event: According to one historian's account, Jesus Christ's Last Supper is held.
Heartbroken by the deaths of her sons Nero and Drusus, and banished to the island of Pandateria by Tiberius, Agrippina the Elder dies of self-inflicted starvation.

-36.event: In the Battle of Naulochus, Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, admiral of Octavian, defeats Sextus Pompey, son of Pompey, thus ending Pompeian resistance to the Second Triumvirate.

36.event: Forces of Emperor Guangwu of the Eastern Han, under the command of Wu Han, conquer the separatist Chengjia empire, reuniting China.

-38.event: Octavian divorces his wife Scribonia and marries Livia Drusilla, ending the fragile peace between the Second Triumvirate and Sextus Pompey.

37.event: Roman Senate annuls Tiberius' will and proclaims Gaius Julius Caesar Augustus Germanicus (aka Caligula = Little Boots) emperor.
Roman emperor Caligula accepts the titles of the Principate, bestowed on him by the Senate.

38.event: Drusilla, Caligula's sister who died in June, with whom the emperor is said to have an incestuous relationship, is deified.

-42.event: The Roman Senate posthumously deifies Julius Caesar.
Liberators' civil war: Triumvirs Mark Antony and Octavian fight a decisive battle with Caesar's assassins Brutus and Cassius.
Liberators' civil war: Mark Antony and Octavian decisively defeat Brutus's army. Brutus commits suicide.

41.event: Claudius is proclaimed Roman emperor by the Praetorian Guard after they assassinate the previous emperor, his nephew Caligula.
After a night of negotiation, Claudius is accepted as Roman emperor by the Senate.

-43.event: Battle of Forum Gallorum between the forces of Mark Antony, and legions loyal to the Roman Senate under the overall command of consul Gaius Pansa.
Battle of Mutina: Mark Antony is again defeated in battle by Aulus Hirtius, who is killed. Antony fails to capture Mutina and Decimus Brutus is murdered shortly after.
Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus, later known as Augustus, compels the Roman Senate to elect him Consul.
Marcus Tullius Cicero is assassinated in Formia on orders of Marcus Antonius.

-44.event: The assassination of Julius Caesar takes place.
Pharaoh Cleopatra VII of Egypt declares her son co-ruler as Ptolemy XV Caesarion.
Cicero launches the first of his Philippicae (oratorical attacks) on Mark Antony. He will make 14 of them over the following months.

-45.event: The Julian calendar takes effect as the civil calendar of the Roman Empire, establishing January 1 as the new date of the new year.
In his last victory, Julius Caesar defeats the Pompeian forces of Titus Labienus and Pompey the Younger in the Battle of Munda.

-46.event: Julius Caesar fights Titus Labienus in the Battle of Ruspina.
Julius Caesar defeats Caecilius Metellus Scipio and Marcus Porcius Cato (Cato the Younger) at the Battle of Thapsus.
Julius Caesar dedicates a temple to Venus Genetrix, fulfilling a vow he made at the Battle of Pharsalus.

-48.event: Caesar's Civil War: Battle of Pharsalus: Julius Caesar decisively defeats Pompey at Pharsalus and Pompey flees to Egypt.
Pompey disembarks at Pelusium upon arriving in Egypt, whereupon he is assassinated by order of King Ptolemy XIII.

-49.event: The Senate of Rome says that Caesar will be declared a public enemy unless he disbands his army. This prompts the tribunes who support him to flee to Ravenna, where Caesar is waiting.
Julius Caesar crosses the Rubicon, signalling the start of civil war.
Caesar, who marched to Spain earlier in the year leaving Marcus Antonius in charge of Italy, defeats Pompey's general Afranius and Petreius in Ilerda (Lerida) north of the Ebro river.

-52.event: Gallic Wars: Vercingetorix, leader of the Gauls, surrenders to the Romans under Julius Caesar, ending the siege and battle of Alesia.

51.event: Nero, later to become Roman emperor, is given the title princeps iuventutis (head of the youth).

53.event: The Roman emperor Nero marries Claudia Octavia.

54.event: Roman emperor Claudius dies from poisoning under mysterious circumstances. He is succeeded by his adoptive son Nero, rather than by Britannicus, his son with Messalina.

55.event: The death under mysterious circumstances of Tiberius Claudius Caesar Britannicus, heir to the Roman empire, on the eve of his coming of age clears the way for Nero to become Emperor.

-61.event: Pompey the Great celebrates his third triumph for victories over the pirates and the end of the Mithridatic Wars on his 45th birthday.

-63.event: Cicero gives the fourth and final of the Catiline Orations.

64.event: The Great Fire of Rome causes widespread devastation and rages on for six days, destroying half of the city.

65.event: The freedman Milichus betrays Piso's plot to kill the Emperor Nero and all the conspirators are arrested.

-69.event: Third Mithridatic War: The military of the Roman Republic subdue Armenia.

68.event: Nero commits suicide, after quoting Vergil's Aeneid, thus ending the Julio-Claudian dynasty and starting the civil war known as the Year of the Four Emperors.

69.event: The Roman legions in Germania Superior refuse to swear loyalty to Galba. They rebel and proclaim Vitellius as emperor.
The Roman legions on the Rhine refuse to declare their allegiance to Galba, instead proclaiming their legate, Aulus Vitellius, as emperor.
Lucius Calpurnius Piso Licinianus is appointed by Galba as deputy Roman Emperor.
Otho seizes power in Rome, proclaiming himself Emperor of Rome, beginning a reign of only three months.
Vitellius, commander of the Rhine armies, defeats Emperor Otho in the Battle of Bedriacum to take power over Rome.
Defeated by Vitellius' troops at Bedriacum, Otho commits suicide.
Tiberius Julius Alexander orders his Roman legions in Alexandria to swear allegiance to Vespasian as Emperor.
Batavian rebellion: The Batavians in Germania Inferior (Netherlands) revolt under the leadership of Gaius Julius Civilis.
In the Second Battle of Bedriacum, troops loyal to Vespasian defeat those of Emperor Vitellius.
Antonius Primus enters Rome to claim the title of Emperor for Nero's former general Vespasian.

70.event: Siege of Jerusalem: Titus and his Roman legions breach the Second Wall of Jerusalem. Jewish defenders retreat to the First Wall. The Romans build a circumvallation, cutting down all trees within fifteen kilometres.
The armies of Titus attack the walls of Jerusalem after a six-month siege. Three days later they breach the walls, which enables the army to destroy the Second Temple.
First Jewish-Roman War: Titus and his armies breach the walls of Jerusalem. (17th of Tammuz in the Hebrew calendar).
Siege of Jerusalem: Titus, son of emperor Vespasian, storms the Fortress of Antonia north of the Temple Mount. The Roman army is drawn into street fights with the Zealots.
Fires resulting from the destruction of the Second Temple in Jerusalem are extinguished.
Titus ends the siege of Jerusalem after destroying Herod's Temple.
A Roman army under Titus occupies and plunders Jerusalem.

73.event: Masada, a Jewish fortress, falls to the Romans after several months of siege, ending the First Jewish-Roman War.

79.event: Mount Vesuvius begins stirring, on the feast day of Vulcan, the Roman god of fire.

81.event: Domitian becomes Emperor of the Roman Empire upon the death of his brother Titus.

85.event: Domitian, who has been conducting a reign of terror for the past three years, is assassinated as a result of a plot by his wife Domitia and twe Praetorian prefects.
Nerva, suspected of complicity of the death of Domitian, is declared emperor by Senate. The Senate then annuls laws passed by Domitian and orders his statues to be destroyed.

96.event: Nerva is proclaimed Roman emperor after Domitian is assassinated.

97.event: Roman emperor Nerva is forced by the Praetorian Guard to adopt general Marcus Ulpius Trajanus as his heir and successor.

98.event: Trajan succeeds his adoptive father Nerva as Roman emperor; under his rule the Roman Empire will reach its maximum extent.
On the death of Nerva, Trajan is declared Roman emperor in Cologne, the seat of his government in lower Germany.

-105.event: Cimbrian War: Defeat at the Battle of Arausio accelerates the Marian reforms of the Roman army of the mid-Republic.

106.event: Start of the Bostran era, the calendar of the province of Arabia Petraea.
The south-western part of Dacia (modern Romania) becomes a Roman province: Roman Dacia.

109.event: Roman emperor Trajan inaugurates the Aqua Traiana, an aqueduct that channels water from Lake Bracciano, 40 kilometres (25 miles) northwest of Rome.

118.event: Hadrian, who became emperor a year ago on Trajan's death, makes his entry into Rome.

135.event: Roman armies enter Betar, slaughtering thousands and ending the Bar Kokhba revolt.

138.event: Roman emperor Hadrian adopts Antoninus Pius as his son, effectively making him his successor.
Emperor Hadrian dies of heart failure at his residence on the bay of Naples, Baiae; he is buried at Rome in the Tomb of Hadrian beside his late wife, Vibia Sabina.

-141.event: Liu Che, posthumously known as Emperor Wu of Han, assumes the throne over the Han dynasty of China.

-153.event: For the first time, Roman consuls begin their year in office on January 1.

161.event: Marcus Aurelius and L. Commodus (who changes his name to Lucius Verus) become joint emperors of Rome on the death of Antoninus Pius.

-164.event: Judas Maccabeus, son of Mattathias of the Hasmonean family, restores the Temple in Jerusalem. This event is commemorated each year by the festival of Hanukkah.

-168.event: Battle of Pydna: Romans under Lucius Aemilius Paullus defeat Macedonian King Perseus who surrenders after the battle, ending the Third Macedonian War.

173.event: Marcomannic Wars: The Roman army in Moravia is encircled by the Quadi, who have broken the peace treaty (171). In a violent thunderstorm emperor Marcus Aurelius defeats and subdues them in the so-called "miracle of the rain".

176.event: Emperor Marcus Aurelius grants his son Commodus the rank of "Imperator" and makes him Supreme Commander of the Roman legions.

180.event: Commodus becomes sole emperor of the Roman Empire at the age of eighteen, following the death of his father, Marcus Aurelius.
Twelve inhabitants of Scillium (near Kasserine, modern-day Tunisia) in North Africa are executed for being Christians. This is the earliest record of Christianity in that part of the world.

190.event: Dong Zhuo has his troops evacuate the capital Luoyang and burn it to the ground.

192.event: Dong Zhuo is assassinated by his adopted son Lü Bu.

193.event: The Senate chooses Pertinax against his will to succeed Commodus as Roman emperor.
After assassinating the Roman Emperor Pertinax, his Praetorian Guards auction off the throne to Didius Julianus.
The distinguished soldier Septimus Severus is proclaimed emperor by the army in Illyricum.

197.event: Emperor Septimius Severus defeats usurper Clodius Albinus in the Battle of Lugdunum, the bloodiest battle between Roman armies.

-202.event: Liu Bang is enthroned as the Emperor of China, beginning four centuries of rule by the Han dynasty.
Second Punic War: At the Battle of Zama, Roman legions under Scipio Africanus defeat Hannibal Barca, leader of the army defending Carthage.

211.event: Following the death of the Roman Emperor Septimius Severus at Eboracum (modern York, England) while preparing to lead a campaign against the Caledonians, the empire is left in the control of his two quarrelling sons, Caracalla and Geta, whom he had instructed to make peace.

-215.event: A temple is built on the Capitoline Hill dedicated to Venus Erycina to commemorate the Roman defeat at Lake Trasimene.

-216.event: The Carthaginian army led by Hannibal defeats a numerically superior Roman army at the Battle of Cannae.

-217.event: Battle of Raphia: Ptolemy IV Philopator of Egypt defeats Antiochus III the Great of the Seleucid kingdom.
The Romans, led by Gaius Flaminius, are ambushed and defeated by Hannibal at the Battle of Lake Trasimene.

217.event: Roman emperor Caracalla is assassinated and is succeeded by his Praetorian Guard prefect, Marcus Opellius Macrinus.

218.event: Battle of Antioch: With the support of the Syrian legions, Elagabalus defeats the forces of emperor Macrinus.

220.event: Emperor Xian of Han is forced to abdicate the throne by Cao Cao's son Cao Pi, ending the Han dynasty.

221.event: Liu Bei, Chinese warlord, proclaims himself emperor of Shu Han, the successor of the Han dynasty.
Roman emperor Elagabalus adopts his cousin Alexander Severus as his heir and receives the title of Caesar.

222.event: Roman emperor Elagabalus is murdered alongside his mother, Julia Soaemias. He is replaced by his 14-year old cousin, Severus Alexander.

224.event: The Battle of Hormozdgan is fought. Ardashir I defeats and kills Artabanus V effectively ending the Parthian Empire.

226.event: Cao Rui succeeds his father as emperor of the Kingdom of Wei.

229.event: On his death, at Cutilia, Vespasian is deified. He is succeeded by his elder son Titus, who is responsible for the capture of Jerusalem in 70. Titus appoints his younger brother Flavius Domitianus as heir.
Sun Quan proclaims himself emperor of Eastern Wu.

230.event: Pope Pontian succeeds Urban I as the eighteenth pope.

235.event: Maximinus Thrax is proclaimed Roman emperor.
Roman emperor Severus Alexander is murdered, marking the start of the Crisis of the Third Century.
Pope Pontian resigns. He is exiled to the mines of Sardinia, along with Hippolytus of Rome.
Pope Anterus succeeds Pontian as the nineteenth pope. During the persecutions of emperor Maximinus Thrax he is martyred.

236.event: Pope Fabian succeeds Anterus to become the twentieth pope of Rome.

238.event: Year of the Six Emperors: The Roman Senate outlaws emperor Maximinus Thrax for his bloodthirsty proscriptions in Rome and nominates two of its members, Pupienus and Balbinus, to the throne.

The Praetorian Guard storm the palace and capture Pupienus and Balbinus. They are dragged through the streets of Rome and executed. On the same day, Gordian III, age 13, is proclaimed emperor, the sixth emperor of the year.

-240.event: First recorded perihelion passage of Halley's Comet.

-241.event: First Punic War: Battle of the Aegates: The Romans sink the Carthaginian fleet bringing the First Punic War to an end.

240.event: Shapur I becomes co-emperor of the Sasanian Empire with his father Ardashir I.

247.event: Philip the Arab marks the millennium of Rome with a celebration of the ludi seaculares.

250.event: Emperor Decius orders everyone in the Roman Empire (except Jews) to make sacrifices to the Roman gods.
Pope Fabian is martyred during the Decian persecution.

254.event: Pope Stephen I succeeds Pope Lucius I, becoming the 23rd pope of the Catholic Church, and immediately takes a stand against Novatianism.

274.event: A temple to Sol Invictus is dedicated in Rome by Emperor Aurelian.

275.event: For the last time, the Roman Senate chooses an emperor; they elect 75-year-old Marcus Claudius Tacitus.

284.event: Diocletian is chosen as Roman emperor.

285.event: Diocletian appoints Maximian as Caesar and co-ruler.
Execution of Saints Crispin and Crispinian during the reign of Diocletian, now the patron saints of leather workers, curriers, and shoemakers.

293.event: Emperor Diocletian and Maximian appoint Constantius Chlorus and Galerius as Caesars. This is considered the beginning of the Tetrarchy, known as the Quattuor Principes Mundi ("Four Rulers of the World").
Roman Emperors Diocletian and Maximian appoint Galerius as Caesar to Diocletian, beginning the period of four rulers known as the Tetrarchy.

-295.event: The first temple to Venus, the Roman goddess of love, beauty and fertility, is dedicated by Quintus Fabius Maximus Gurges during the Third Samnite War.

298.event: Roman Emperor Maximian concludes his campaign in North Africa and makes a triumphal entry into Carthage.

301.event: San Marino, one of the smallest nations in the world and the world's oldest republic still in existence, is founded by Saint Marinus.

303.event: Roman emperor Diocletian orders the destruction of the Christian church in Nicomedia, beginning eight years of Diocletianic Persecution.

305.event: Diocletian and Maximian retire from the office of Roman emperor.

306.event: Martyrdom of Saint Adrian of Nicomedia.
Constantine I is proclaimed Roman emperor by his troops.

307.event: Jin Huaidi becomes emperor of China in succession to his father, Jin Huidi, despite a challenge from his uncle, Sima Ying.
After divorcing his wife Minervina, Constantine marries Fausta, daughter of the retired Roman emperor Maximian.

308.event: At Carnuntum, Emperor emeritus Diocletian confers with Galerius, Augustus of the East, and Maximianus, the recently returned former Augustus of the West, in an attempt to end the civil wars of the Tetrarchy.

309.event: Pope Eusebius is banished by the Emperor Maxentius to Sicily, where he dies, perhaps from a hunger strike.

311.event: The Diocletianic Persecution of Christians in the Roman Empire ends.

312.event: Constantine is said to have received his famous Vision of the Cross.
Constantine I defeats Maxentius, becoming the sole Roman emperor in the West.

Constantine the Great enters Rome after his victory at the Battle of the Milvian Bridge, stages a grand adventus in the city, and is met with popular jubilation. Maxentius' body is fished out of the Tiber and beheaded.

313.event: The decisions of the Edict of Milan, signed by Constantine the Great and co-emperor Valerius Licinius, granting religious freedom throughout the Roman Empire, are published in Nicomedia.

314.event: Pope Sylvester I is consecrated, as successor to the late Pope Miltiades.
Constantine I defeats Roman Emperor Licinius, who loses his European territories.

315.event: The Arch of Constantine is completed near the Colosseum in Rome to commemorate Constantine I's victory over Maxentius at the Milvian Bridge.

320.event: Pappus of Alexandria, Greek philosopher, observes an eclipse of the Sun and writes a commentary on The Great Astronomer (Almagest).

324.event: Battle of Adrianople: Constantine I defeats Licinius, who flees to Byzantium.
Constantine the Great decisively defeats Licinius in the Battle of Chrysopolis, establishing Constantine's sole control over the Roman Empire.

325.event: The First Council of Nicaea is formally opened, starting the first ecumenical council of the Christian Church.
The original Nicene Creed is adopted at the First Council of Nicaea.

326.event: The old St. Peter's Basilica is consecrated by Pope Sylvester I.

328.event: Athanasius is elected Patriarch of Alexandria.
The official opening of Constantine's Bridge built over the Danube between Sucidava (Corabia, Romania) and Oescus (Gigen, Bulgaria) by the Roman architect Theophilus Patricius.

-331.event: Alexander the Great defeats Darius III of Persia in the Battle of Gaugamela.

332.event: Emperor Constantine the Great announces free distributions of food to the citizens in Constantinople.

333.event: Roman Emperor Constantine the Great elevates his youngest son Constans to the rank of Caesar.

335.event: Athanasius is banished to Trier, on the charge that he prevented a grain fleet from sailing to Constantinople.

336.event: First documentary sign of Christmas celebration in Rome.

-338.event: A Macedonian army led by Philip II defeated the combined forces of Athens and Thebes in the Battle of Chaeronea, securing Macedonian hegemony in Greece and the Aegean.

337.event: Constantine II, Constantius II, and Constans succeed their father Constantine I as co-emperors. The Roman Empire is divided between the three Augusti.

350.event: Vetranio proclaims himself Caesar after being encouraged to do so by Constantina, sister of Constantius II.
The Roman usurper Nepotianus, of the Constantinian dynasty, proclaims himself Roman emperor, entering Rome at the head of a group of gladiators.
Vetranio meets Constantius II at Naissus (Serbia) and is forced to abdicate his imperial title. Constantius allows him to live as a private citizen on a state pension.

351.event: The Jewish revolt against Constantius Gallus breaks out after his arrival at Antioch.
Constantius II defeats the usurper Magnentius.

-356.event: The Temple of Artemis in Ephesus, one of the Seven Wonders of the World, is destroyed by arson.

355.event: Claudius Silvanus, accused of treason, proclaims himself Roman Emperor against Constantius II.

356.event: The anti-paganism policy of Constantius II forbids the worship of pagan idols in the Roman Empire.

357.event: Emperor Constantius II enters Rome for the first time to celebrate his victory over Magnus Magnentius.

-362.event: Battle of Mantinea: The Thebans, led by Epaminondas, defeated the Spartans.

361.event: Emperor Constantius II dies of a fever at Mopsuestia in Cilicia; on his deathbed he is baptised and declares his cousin Julian rightful successor.
Julian enters Constantinople as sole Roman Emperor.

362.event: Roman-Persian Wars: Emperor Julian arrives at Antioch with a Roman expeditionary force (60,000 men) and stays there for nine months to launch a campaign against the Persian Empire.

363.event: Roman emperor Julian leaves Antioch with an army of 90,000 to attack the Sasanian Empire, in a campaign which would bring about his own death.
The Roman emperor Julian defeats the Sasanian army in the Battle of Ctesiphon, under the walls of the Sasanian capital, but is unable to take the city.
Emperor Julian marches back up the Tigris and burns his fleet of supply ships. During the withdrawal, Roman forces suffer several attacks from the Persians.
Roman emperor Julian is killed during the retreat from the Sasanian Empire.

364.event: Valentinian I is proclaimed Roman emperor.
Roman Emperor Valentinian I appoints his brother Flavius Valens co-emperor.

365.event: The 365 Crete earthquake affected the Greek island of Crete with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), causing a destructive tsunami that affects the coasts of Libya and Egypt, especially Alexandria. Many thousands were killed.
Roman usurper Procopius bribes two legions passing by Constantinople, and proclaims himself emperor.
The Alemanni cross the Rhine and invade Gaul. Emperor Valentinian I moves to Paris to command the army and defend the Gallic cities.

366.event: The Alemanni cross the frozen Rhine in large numbers, invading the Roman Empire.

367.event: Gratian, son of Roman Emperor Valentinian I, is named co-Augustus at the age of eight by his father.

-371.event: The Battle of Leuctra shatters Sparta's reputation of military invincibility.

372.event: Sixteen Kingdoms: Jin Xiaowudi, age 10, succeeds his father Jin Jianwendi as Emperor of the Eastern Jin dynasty.

378.event: General Siyaj K'ak' conquers Tikal, enlarging the domain of King Spearthrower Owl of Teotihuacán.
Gothic War: Battle of Adrianople: A large Roman army led by Emperor Valens is defeated by the Visigoths. Valens is killed along with over half of his army.

379.event: Emperor Gratian elevates Flavius Theodosius at Sirmium to Augustus, and gives him authority over all the eastern provinces of the Roman Empire.
Yax Nuun Ahiin I is crowned as 15th Ajaw of Tikal

380.event: Edict of Thessalonica: Emperor Theodosius I and his co-emperors Gratian and Valentinian II declare their wish that all Roman citizens convert to Nicene Christianity.
Theodosius I makes his adventus, or formal entry, into Constantinople.

381.event: The end of the First Council of Christian bishops convened in Constantinople by the Roman Emperor Theodosius I.

382.event: Roman Emperor Theodosius I concludes a peace treaty with the Goths and settles them in the Balkans.

-387.event: Roman-Gaulish Wars: Battle of the Allia: A Roman army is defeated by raiding Gauls, leading to the subsequent sacking of Rome.

392.event: Emperor Valentinian II is assassinated while advancing into Gaul against the Frankish usurper Arbogast. He is found hanging in his residence at Vienne.
Arbogast has Eugenius elected Western Roman Emperor.

393.event: Roman emperor Theodosius I proclaims his eight-year-old son Honorius co-emperor.

394.event: The Graffito of Esmet-Akhom, the latest known inscription in Egyptian hieroglyphs, is written.
Battle of the Frigidus: Roman emperor Theodosius I defeats and kills Eugenius the usurper. His Frankish magister militum Arbogast escapes but commits suicide two days later.

395.event: Emperor Arcadius marries Aelia Eudoxia, daughter of the Frankish general Flavius Bauto. She becomes one of the more powerful Roman empresses of Late Antiquity.
Rufinus, praetorian prefect of the East, is murdered by Gothic mercenaries under Gainas.
Later Yan is defeated by its former vassal Northern Wei at the Battle of Canhe Slope.

401.event: The Visigoths, led by king Alaric I, cross the Alps and invade northern Italy.
Pope Innocent I is elected, the only pope to succeed his father in the office.

402.event: Stilicho defeats the Visigoths under Alaric in the Battle of Pollentia.

-404.event: Admiral Lysander and King Pausanias of Sparta blockade Athens and bring the Peloponnesian War to a successful conclusion.

404.event: Saint Telemachus tries to stop a gladiatorial fight in a Roman amphitheatre, and is stoned to death by the crowd. This act impresses the Christian Emperor Honorius, who issues a historic ban on gladiatorial fights.
Byzantine Empress Eudoxia dies from the miscarriage of her seventh pregnancy.

406.event: Vandals, Alans and Suebians cross the Rhine, beginning an invasion of Gaul.

409.event: Vandals and Alans cross the Pyrenees and appear in Hispania.

-411.event: The Athenian coup succeeds, forming a short-lived oligarchy.

410.event: The Visigoths under king Alaric I begin to pillage Rome.
The sacking of Rome by the Visigoths ends after three days.

413.event: Emperor Honorius signs an edict providing tax relief for the Italian provinces Tuscia, Campania, Picenum, Samnium, Apulia, Lucania and Calabria, which were plundered by the Visigoths.

414.event: Emperor Theodosius II, age 13, yields power to his older sister Aelia Pulcheria, who reigned as regent and proclaimed herself empress (Augusta) of the Eastern Roman Empire.

417.event: Emperor Honorius forces Galla Placidia into marriage to Constantius, his famous general (magister militum) (probable).

418.event: A papal conclave begins, resulting in the election of Pope Boniface I.

421.event: Constantius III becomes co-Emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
Italian city Venice is founded with the dedication of the first church, that of San Giacomo di Rialto on the islet of Rialto.
Emperor Theodosius II marries Aelia Eudocia at Constantinople (Byzantine Empire).

425.event: The University of Constantinople is founded by Emperor Theodosius II at the urging of his wife Aelia Eudocia.
Valentinian III is elevated as Roman emperor at the age of six.

428.event: Nestorius becomes the Patriarch of Constantinople. Three years later, he would be deposed due to alleged heresy.

435.event: Deposed Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople Nestorius, considered the originator of Nestorianism, is exiled by Roman Emperor Theodosius II to a monastery in Egypt.

437.event: Emperor Valentinian III begins his reign over the Western Roman Empire. His mother Galla Placidia ends her regency, but continues to exercise political influence at the court in Rome.
Valentinian III, Western Roman Emperor, marries Licinia Eudoxia, daughter of his cousin Theodosius II, Eastern Roman Emperor in Constantinople unifying the two branches of the House of Theodosius.

438.event: Roman emperor Theodosius II publishes the law codex Codex Theodosianus

439.event: The Vandals, led by King Gaiseric, take Carthage in North Africa.

447.event: A powerful earthquake destroys large portions of the Walls of Constantinople, including 57 towers.

451.event: Attila the Hun captures Metz in France, killing most of its inhabitants and burning most of the town.
Battle of Avarayr between Armenian rebels and the Sasanian Empire takes place. The Sasanids defeat the Armenians militarily but guarantee them freedom to openly practice Christianity.
Battle of Chalons: Flavius Aetius' battles Attila the Hun. After the battle, which was inconclusive, Attila retreats, causing the Romans to interpret it as a victory.
The first session of the Council of Chalcedon begins.
The Chalcedonian Creed, regarding the divine and human nature of Jesus, is adopted by the Council of Chalcedon, an ecumenical council.

-453.event: Spring and Autumn period: The house of Zhao defeats the house of Zhi, ending the Battle of Jinyang, a military conflict between the elite families of the State of Jin.

452.event: Severianus, Bishop of Scythopolis, is martyred in Palestine.
Attila leads a Hun army in the invasion of Italy, devastating the northern provinces as he heads for Rome.
Sack of Aquileia: After an earlier defeat on the Catalaunian Plains, Attila lays siege to the metropolis of Aquileia and eventually destroys it.

455.event: Petronius Maximus becomes, with support of the Roman Senate, emperor of the Western Roman Empire; he forces Licinia Eudoxia, the widow of his predecessor, Valentinian III, to marry him.
Emperor Petronius Maximus is stoned to death by an angry mob while fleeing Rome.
Sack of Rome: Vandals enter Rome, and plunder the city for two weeks.
Emperor Avitus enters Rome with a Gallic army and consolidates his power.

456.event: Ricimer defeats Avitus at Piacenza and becomes master of the Western Roman Empire.

457.event: Leo I becomes the Eastern Roman emperor.
Majorian is acclaimed as Western Roman emperor.

461.event: Majorian is arrested near Tortona (northern Italy) and deposed by the Suebian general Ricimer as puppet emperor.
Roman Emperor Majorian is beheaded near the river Iria in north-west Italy following his arrest and deposition by the magister militum Ricimer.
Libius Severus is declared emperor of the Western Roman Empire. The real power is in the hands of the magister militum Ricimer.

467.event: Anthemius is elevated to Emperor of the Western Roman Empire.

472.event: After being besieged in Rome by his own generals, Western Roman Emperor Anthemius is captured in St. Peter's Basilica and put to death.

-474.event: Roman consul Aulus Manlius Vulso celebrates an ovation for concluding the war against Veii and securing a forty years' truce.

473.event: Gundobad (nephew of Ricimer) nominates Glycerius as emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
Emperor Leo I acclaims his grandson Leo II as Caesar of the East Roman Empire.

474.event: Seven-year-old Leo II succeeds his maternal grandfather Leo I as Byzantine emperor. He dies ten months later.
Zeno is crowned as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Julius Nepos forces Roman usurper Glycerius to abdicate the throne and proclaims himself Emperor of the Western Roman Empire.
Emperor Leo II dies after a reign of ten months. He is succeeded by his father Zeno, who becomes sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire.

475.event: Byzantine Emperor Zeno is forced to flee his capital at Constantinople, and his general, Basiliscus gains control of the empire.
Byzantine Emperor Basiliscus issues a circular letter (Enkyklikon) to the bishops of his empire, supporting the Monophysite christological position.
The Roman general Orestes forces western Roman Emperor Julius Nepos to flee his capital city, Ravenna.
Romulus Augustulus is proclaimed Western Roman Emperor.

-477.event: Battle of the Cremera as part of the Roman-Etruscan Wars.  Veii ambushes and defeats the Roman army.

476.event: Odoacer, chieftain of the Germanic tribes (Herulic - Scirian foederati), is proclaimed rex Italiae ("King of Italy") by his troops.
Romulus Augustulus is deposed when Odoacer proclaims himself "King of Italy", thus ending the Western Roman Empire.

-484.event: Dedication of the Temple of Castor and Pollux in ancient Rome

484.event: King Huneric of the Vandals replaces Nicene bishops with Arian ones, and banishes some to Corsica.
Leontius, Roman usurper, is crowned Eastern emperor at Tarsus (modern Turkey). He is recognized in Antioch and makes it his capital.
The Arian Vandal Kingdom ceases its persecution of Nicene Christianity.
Alaric II succeeds his father Euric and becomes king of the Visigoths. He establishes his capital at Aire-sur-l'Adour (Southern Gaul).

-490.event: Battle of Marathon: The conventionally accepted date for the Battle of Marathon. The Athenians and their Plataean allies defeat the first Persian invasion force of Greece.

489.event: Theodoric, king of the Ostrogoths, defeats Odoacer at the Battle of Isonzo, forcing his way into Italy.
The Ostrogoths under Theoderic the Great defeat the forces of Odoacer for the second time.

490.event: Battle of Adda: The Goths under Theodoric the Great and his ally Alaric II defeat the forces of Odoacer on the Adda River, near Milan.

491.event: Flavius Anastasius becomes Byzantine emperor, with the name of Anastasius I.
Empress Ariadne marries Anastasius I. The widowed Augusta is able to choose her successor for the Byzantine throne, after Zeno (late emperor) dies of dysentery.
Odoacer makes a night assault with his Heruli guardsmen, engaging Theoderic the Great in Ad Pinetam. Both sides suffer heavy losses, but in the end Theodoric forces Odoacer back into Ravenna.

493.event: Odoacer, the first barbarian King of Italy after the fall of the Western Roman Empire, is slain by Theoderic the Great, king of the Ostrogoths, while the two kings were feasting together.

-497.event: The first Saturnalia festival was celebrated in ancient Rome.

498.event: After the death of Anastasius II, Symmachus is elected Pope in the Lateran Palace, while Laurentius is elected Pope in Santa Maria Maggiore.

-503.event: Roman consul Agrippa Menenius Lanatus celebrates a triumph for a military victory over the Sabines.

502.event: The Synodus Palmaris, called by Gothic king Theoderic, absolves Pope Symmachus of all charges, thus ending the schism of Antipope Laurentius.
Chinese emperor Xiao Yan names Xiao Tong his heir designate.[citation needed]

506.event: Alaric II, eighth king of the Visigoths, promulgates the Breviary of Alaric (Breviarium Alaricianum or Lex Romana Visigothorum), a collection of "Roman law".
The bishops of Visigothic Gaul meet in the Council of Agde.

-509.event: Publius Valerius Publicola celebrates the first triumph of the Roman Republic after his victory over the deposed king Lucius Tarquinius Superbus at the Battle of Silva Arsia.
The Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus on Rome's Capitoline Hill is dedicated on the ides of September.

508.event: Clovis I, king of the Franks, is baptized into the Catholic faith at Reims, by Saint Remigius.

511.event: King Clovis I dies at Lutetia and is buried in the Abbey of St Genevieve.

523.event: John I becomes the new Pope after the death of Pope Hormisdas.

524.event: The Franks are defeated by the Burgundians in the Battle of Vézeronce.

527.event: Byzantine Emperor Justin I names his nephew Justinian I as co-ruler and successor to the throne.
Justinian I becomes the sole ruler of the Byzantine Empire.

529.event: First Corpus Juris Civilis, a fundamental work in jurisprudence, is issued by Eastern Roman Emperor Justinian I.

531.event: Battle of Callinicum: A Byzantine army under Belisarius is defeated by the Persians at Raqqa (northern Syria).

532.event: Nika riots in Constantinople: A quarrel between supporters of different chariot teams—the Blues and the Greens—in the Hippodrome escalates into violence.
The Nika riots break out, during the racing season at the Hippodrome in Constantinople, as a result of discontent with the rule of the Emperor Justinian I.
Byzantine emperor Justinian I lays the foundation stone of a new Orthodox Christian basilica in Constantinople – the Hagia Sophia.

-534.event: Thespis of Icaria becomes the first recorded actor to portray a character on stage.

533.event: Mercurius becomes Pope John II, the first pope to adopt a new name upon elevation to the papacy.
A Byzantine expeditionary fleet under Belisarius sails from Constantinople to attack the Vandals in Africa, via Greece and Sicily (approximate date).
A Byzantine army of 15,000 men under Belisarius lands at Caput Vada (modern Tunisia) and marches to Carthage.
Belisarius of the Byzantine Empire defeats Gelimer and the Vandals at the Battle of Ad Decimum, near Carthage, North Africa.
Vandalic War: Byzantine general Belisarius defeats the Vandals, commanded by King Gelimer, at the Battle of Tricamarum.

534.event: The second and final edition of the Code of Justinian comes into effect in the Byzantine Empire.

535.event: Byzantine general Belisarius completes the conquest of Sicily, defeating the Gothic garrison of Palermo (Panormos), and ending his consulship for the year.

536.event: Gothic War: The Byzantine general Belisarius enters Rome unopposed; the Gothic garrison flees the capital.

537.event: Siege of Rome: The Ostrogoth army under king Vitiges begins the siege of the capital. Belisarius conducts a delaying action outside the Flaminian Gate; he and a detachment of his bucellarii are almost cut off.

Siege of Rome: King Vitiges attempts to assault the northern and eastern city walls, but is repulsed at the Praenestine Gate, known as the Vivarium, by the defenders under the Byzantine generals Bessas and Peranius.

Siege of Rome: The Byzantine general Belisarius receives his promised reinforcements, 1,600 cavalry, mostly of Hunnic or Slavic origin and expert bowmen. He starts, despite shortages, raids against the Gothic camps and Vitiges is forced into a stalemate.
The second Hagia Sophia in Constantinople is consecrated.

-539.event: The army of Cyrus the Great of Persia takes Babylon, ending the Babylonian empire. (Julian calendar)

538.event: Vitiges, king of the Ostrogoths ends his siege of Rome and retreats to Ravenna, leaving the city to the victorious Byzantine general, Belisarius.

546.event: Siege of Rome: The Ostrogoths under king Totila plunder the city, by bribing the Byzantine garrison.

550.event: Gothic War: The Ostrogoths, under King Totila, conquer Rome after a long siege, by bribing the Isaurian garrison.

551.event: A major earthquake strikes Beirut, triggering a devastating tsunami that affected the coastal towns of Byzantine Phoenicia, causing thousands of deaths.

552.event: Battle of Taginae: Byzantine forces under Narses defeat the Ostrogoths in Italy, and the Ostrogoth king, Totila, is mortally wounded.

553.event: The Second Council of Constantinople begins.

554.event: Emperor Justinian I rewards Liberius for his service in the Pragmatic Sanction, granting him extensive estates in Italy.

557.event: Constantinople is severely damaged by an earthquake, which cracks the dome of Hagia Sophia.

558.event: In Constantinople, the dome of the Hagia Sophia collapses, twenty years after its construction. Justinian I immediately orders that the dome be rebuilt.
Chlothar I is crowned King of the Franks.

561.event: Following the death of King Chlothar I at Compiègne, his four sons, Charibert I, Guntram, Sigebert I and Chilperic I, divide the Frankish Kingdom.

-567.event: Servius Tullius, the king of Rome, celebrates a triumph for his victory over the Etruscans.

-571.event: Servius Tullius, king of Rome, celebrates the first of his three triumphs for his victory over the Etruscans.

574.event: Byzantine Emperor Justin II, suffering recurring seizures of insanity, adopts his general Tiberius and proclaims him as Caesar.

582.event: Maurice becomes Emperor of the Byzantine Empire.

583.event: Maya queen Yohl Ik'nal is crowned ruler of Palenque.

-585.event: A solar eclipse occurs, as predicted by the Greek philosopher and scientist Thales, while Alyattes is battling Cyaxares in the Battle of the Eclipse, leading to a truce. This is one of the cardinal dates from which other dates can be calculated.
Lucius Tarquinius Priscus, king of Rome, celebrates a triumph for his victories over the Sabines, and the surrender of Collatia.

-587.event: Babylon's siege of Jerusalem ends following the destruction of Solomon's Temple.
The Neo-Babylonian Empire sacks Jerusalem and destroys the First Temple.

587.event: Treaty of Andelot: King Guntram of Burgundy recognizes Childebert II as his heir.

589.event: Reccared I opens the Third Council of Toledo, marking the entry of Visigothic Spain into the Catholic Church.
King Authari marries Theodelinda, daughter of the Bavarian duke Garibald I. A Catholic, she has great influence among the Lombard nobility.

590.event: Khosrau II is crowned king of Persia.
Emperor Maurice proclaims his son Theodosius as co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Consecration of Pope Gregory I (Gregory the Great).

597.event: Augustine of Canterbury and his fellow-labourers baptise in Kent more than 10,000 Anglo-Saxons.

598.event: Balkan Campaign: The Avars lift the siege at the Byzantine stronghold of Tomis. Their leader Bayan I retreats north of the Danube River after the Avaro-Slavic hordes are decimated by the plague.

Goguryeo-Sui War: Emperor Wéndi of Sui orders his youngest son, Yang Liang (assisted by the co-prime minister Gao Jiong), to conquer Goguryeo (Korea) during the Manchurian rainy season, with a Chinese army and navy.

599.event: Maya king Uneh Chan of Calakmul attacks rival city-state Palenque in southern Mexico, defeating queen Yohl Ik'nal and sacking the city.

602.event: Byzantine Emperor Maurice is forced to watch as the usurper Phocas executes his five sons before Maurice is beheaded himself.

607.event: Ono no Imoko is dispatched as envoy to the Sui court in China (Traditional Japanese date: July 3, 607).

610.event: Heraclius arrives at Constantinople, kills Byzantine Emperor Phocas, and becomes emperor.

611.event: Maya king Uneh Chan of Calakmul sacks rival city-state Palenque in southern Mexico.

613.event: Eight-month-old Constantine is crowned as co-emperor (Caesar) by his father Heraclius at Constantinople.

614.event: King Chlothar II promulgates the Edict of Paris (Edictum Chlotacharii), a sort of Frankish Magna Carta that defends the rights of the Frankish nobles while it excludes Jews from all civil employment in the Frankish Kingdom.

615.event: Pakal ascends the throne of Palenque at the age of 12.

617.event: Battle of Huoyi: Li Yuan defeats a Sui dynasty army, opening the path to his capture of the imperial capital Chang'an and the eventual establishment of the Tang dynasty.

618.event: Li Yuan becomes Emperor Gaozu of Tang, initiating three centuries of Tang dynasty rule over China.
Transition from Sui to Tang: Wang Shichong decisively defeats Li Mi at the Battle of Yanshi.
The Tang dynasty scores a decisive victory over their rival Xue Rengao at the Battle of Qianshuiyuan.

619.event: A qaghan of the Western Turkic Khaganate is assassinated in a Chinese palace by Eastern Turkic rivals after the approval of Tang emperor Gaozu.

621.event: Battle of Hulao: Li Shimin, the son of the Chinese emperor Gaozu, defeats the numerically superior forces of Dou Jiande near the Hulao Pass (Henan). This victory decides the outcome of the civil war that followed the Sui dynasty's collapse in favour of the Tang dynasty.

622.event: The beginning of the Islamic calendar.

624.event: The Battle of Badr, the first major battle between the Muslims and Quraysh.

626.event: Li Shimin, the future Emperor Taizong of Tang, ambushes and kills his rival brothers Li Yuanji and Li Jiancheng in the Xuanwu Gate Incident.
The Avar and Slav armies leave the siege of Constantinople.
Li Shimin, posthumously known as Emperor Taizong of Tang, assumes the throne over the Tang dynasty of China.

627.event: King Edwin of Northumbria is converted to Christianity by Paulinus, bishop of York.
Battle of Nineveh: A Byzantine army under Emperor Heraclius defeats Emperor Khosrau II's Persian forces, commanded by General Rhahzadh.

628.event: Khosrow II, last Sasanian shah of Iran, is overthrown.
Khosrow II, the last great Shah of the Sasanian Empire (Iran), is overthrown by his son Kavadh II.

629.event: Emperor Heraclius enters Constantinople in triumph after his victory over the Persian Empire.
Dagobert I is crowned King of the Franks.

630.event: Conquest of Mecca: The prophet Muhammad and his followers conquer the city, Quraysh surrender.
Emperor Heraclius returns the True Cross, one of the holiest Christian relics, to Jerusalem.

631.event: Emperor Taizong of Tang sends envoys to the Xueyantuo bearing gold and silk in order to seek the release of Chinese prisoners captured during the transition from Sui to Tang.

632.event: The Farewell Sermon (Khutbah, Khutbatul Wada') of the Islamic prophet Muhammad.
Yazdegerd III ascends the throne as king (shah) of the Persian Empire. He becomes the last ruler of the Sasanian dynasty (modern Iran).
Fatimah, daughter of the Islamic prophet Muhammad, dies, with her cause of death being a controversial topic among the Sunni Muslims and Shia Muslims.

633.event: Battle of Hatfield Chase: King Edwin of Northumbria is defeated and killed by an alliance under Penda of Mercia and Cadwallon of Gwynedd.
Fourth Council of Toledo takes place.

634.event: Siege of Damascus: The Rashidun Arabs under Khalid ibn al-Walid capture Damascus from the Byzantine Empire.

636.event: Arab-Byzantine wars: The Battle of Yarmouk between Byzantine Empire and Rashidun Caliphate begins.

Battle of Yarmouk: Arab forces led by Khalid ibn al-Walid take control of the Levant away from the Byzantine Empire, marking the first great wave of Muslim conquests and the rapid advance of Islam outside Arabia.
The Rashidun Caliphate defeats the Sasanian Empire at the Battle of al-Qādisiyyah in Iraq.

637.event: The Battle of Moira is fought between the High King of Ireland and the Kings of Ulster and Dál Riata. It is claimed to be the largest battle in the history of Ireland.
Arab-Byzantine wars: Antioch surrenders to the Rashidun Caliphate after the Battle of the Iron Bridge.

639.event: Ashina Jiesheshuai and his tribesmen assaulted Emperor Taizong at Jiucheng Palace.

640.event: Battle of Heliopolis: The Muslim Arab army under 'Amr ibn al-'As defeat the Byzantine forces near Heliopolis (Egypt).
Pope John IV is elected, several months after his predecessor's death.

642.event: Battle of Maserfield: Penda of Mercia defeats and kills Oswald of Northumbria.

644.event: Umar ibn al-Khattab, the second Muslim caliph, is assassinated by a Persian slave in Medina.

645.event: Isshi Incident: Prince Naka-no-Ōe and Fujiwara no Kamatari assassinate Soga no Iruka during a coup d'état at the imperial palace.
Chinese forces under general Li Shiji besiege the strategic fortress city of Anshi (Liaoning) during the Goguryeo-Tang War.

649.event: Conquest of Kucha: The forces of Kucha surrender after a forty-day siege led by Tang dynasty general Ashina She'er, establishing Tang control over the northern Tarim Basin in Xinjiang.
King Chindasuinth, at the urging of bishop Braulio of Zaragoza, crowns his son Recceswinth as co-ruler of the Visigothic Kingdom.[citation needed]

653.event: Pope Martin I is arrested and taken to Constantinople, due to his opposition to monothelitism.

654.event: Pope Eugene I elected to succeed Martinus I.

655.event: Battle of the Winwaed: Penda of Mercia is defeated by Oswiu of Northumbria.

656.event: Ali becomes Caliph of the Rashidun Caliphate.

657.event: First Fitna: In the Battle of Siffin, troops led by Ali ibn Abu Talib clash with those led by Muawiyah I.

-660.event: Traditional date for the foundation of Japan by Emperor Jimmu.

660.event: Korean forces under general Kim Yu-sin of Silla defeat the army of Baekje in the Battle of Hwangsanbeol.

661.event: The Rashidun Caliphate is effectively ended with the assassination of Ali, the last caliph.

663.event: Silla-Tang armies crush the Baekje restoration attempt and force Yamato Japan to withdraw from Korea in the Battle of Baekgang.

671.event: Emperor Tenji of Japan introduces a water clock (clepsydra) called Rokoku. The instrument, which measures time and indicates hours, is placed in the capital of Ōtsu.

673.event: Emperor Tenmu of Japan assumes the Chrysanthemum Throne at the Palace of Kiyomihara in Asuka.
King Wamba of the Visigoths puts down a revolt by Hilderic, governor of Nîmes (France) and rival for the throne.

677.event: Climax of the Siege of Thessalonica by the Slavs in a three-day assault on the city walls.

680.event: The Battle of Karbala is won by the Umayyads under Yazid I.
The Sixth Ecumenical Council commences in Constantinople.

681.event: Twelfth Council of Toledo: King Erwig of the Visigoths initiates a council in which he implements diverse measures against the Jews in Spain.
Pope Honorius I is posthumously excommunicated by the Sixth Ecumenical Council.

682.event: Pope Leo II begins his pontificate.

683.event: Yazid I's army kills 11,000 people of Medina including notable Sahabas in Battle of al-Harrah.
During the Siege of Mecca, the Kaaba catches fire and is burned down.

684.event: Battle of Marj Rahit: Umayyad partisans defeat the supporters of Ibn al-Zubayr and cement Umayyad control of Syria.

685.event: The Battle of Dun Nechtain is fought between a Pictish army under King Bridei III and the invading Northumbrians under King Ecgfrith, who are decisively defeated.

686.event: Maya king Yuknoom Yich'aak K'ahk' assumes the crown of Calakmul.

687.event: Pope Sergius I is elected as a compromise between antipopes Paschal and Theodore.

690.event: Empress Wu Zetian ascends to the throne of the Tang dynasty and proclaims herself ruler of the Chinese Empire.
Empress Wu Zetian establishes the Zhou Dynasty of China.

694.event: At the Seventeenth Council of Toledo, Egica, a king of the Visigoths of Hispania, accuses Jews of aiding Muslims, sentencing all Jews to slavery.

699.event: En no Ozuno, a Japanese mystic and apothecary who will later be regarded as the founder of a folk religion Shugendō, is banished to Izu Ōshima.

705.event: Empress Wu Zetian abdicates the throne, restoring the Tang dynasty.

706.event: Byzantine emperor Justinian II has his predecessors Leontios and Tiberios III publicly executed in the Hippodrome of Constantinople.
In China, Emperor Zhongzong of Tang inters the bodies of relatives in the Qianling Mausoleum, located on Mount Liang outside Chang'an.

708.event: Pope Constantine becomes the 88th pope. He would be the last pope to visit Constantinople until 1967.
Copper coins are minted in Japan for the first time (Traditional Japanese date: August 10, 708).

711.event: Dagobert III succeeds his father King Childebert III as King of the Franks.
Islamic conquest of Hispania: Moorish troops led by Tariq ibn Ziyad land at Gibraltar to begin their invasion of the Iberian Peninsula (Al-Andalus).
Umayyad conquest of Hispania: Battle of Guadalete: Umayyad forces under Tariq ibn Ziyad defeat the Visigoths led by King Roderic.

713.event: The Byzantine emperor Philippicus is blinded, deposed and sent into exile by conspirators of the Opsikion army in Thrace. He is succeeded by Anastasios II, who begins the reorganization of the Byzantine army.

714.event: Pepin of Herstal, mayor of the Merovingian palace, dies at Jupille (modern Belgium). He is succeeded by his infant grandson Theudoald, while his widow Plectrude holds actual power in the Frankish Kingdom.

715.event: Ragenfrid defeats Theudoald at the Battle of Compiègne.

717.event: Battle of Vincy between Charles Martel and Ragenfrid.
Theodosius III resigns the throne to the Byzantine Empire to enter the clergy.
Arab-Byzantine wars: Maslama ibn Abd al-Malik begins the Second Arab Siege of Constantinople, which will last for nearly a year.

718.event: Arab-Byzantine wars: Raising of the Second Arab Siege of Constantinople.

721.event: Odo of Aquitaine defeats the Moors in the Battle of Toulouse.

724.event: Empress Genshō abdicates the throne in favor of her nephew Shōmu who becomes emperor of Japan.

730.event: Battle of Marj Ardabil: The Khazars annihilate an Umayyad army and kill its commander, al-Jarrah ibn Abdallah al-Hakami.

732.event: Charles Martel's forces defeat an Umayyad army near Tours, France.

737.event: The Turgesh drive back an Umayyad invasion of Khuttal, follow them south of the Oxus, and capture their baggage train.

-747.event: According to Ptolemy, the epoch (origin) of the Nabonassar Era began at noon on this date. Historians use this to establish the modern BC chronology for dating historic events.

747.event: Abbasid Revolution: Abu Muslim Khorasani begins an open revolt against Umayyad rule, which is carried out under the sign of the Black Standard.

Carloman, mayor of the palace of Austrasia, renounces his position as majordomo and retires to a monastery near Rome. His brother Pepin the Short becomes the sole ruler (de facto) of the Frankish Kingdom.

748.event: Abbasid Revolution: The Hashimi rebels under Abu Muslim Khorasani take Merv, capital of the Umayyad province Khorasan, marking the consolidation of the Abbasid revolt.

750.event: In the Battle of the Zab, the Abbasid rebels defeat the Umayyad Caliphate, leading to the overthrow of the dynasty.

752.event: Mayan king Bird Jaguar IV of Yaxchilan in modern-day Chiapas, Mexico, assumes the throne.

755.event: An Lushan revolts against Chancellor Yang Guozhong at Yanjing, initiating the An Lushan Rebellion during the Tang dynasty of China.

756.event: An Lushan, leader of a revolt against the Tang Dynasty, declares himself emperor and establishes the state of Yan.
Abd al-Rahman I, the founder of the Arab dynasty that ruled the greater part of Iberia for nearly three centuries, becomes emir of Cordova, Spain.

An Lushan Rebellion: Emperor Xuanzong of Tang is ordered by his Imperial Guards to execute chancellor Yang Guozhong by forcing him to commit suicide or face a mutiny. General An Lushan has other members of the emperor's family killed.

757.event: Du Fu returns to Chang'an as a member of Emperor Xuanzong's court, after having escaped the city during the An Lushan Rebellion.

758.event: Guangzhou is sacked by Arab and Persian pirates.

759.event: Tang dynasty poet Du Fu departs for Chengdu, where he is hosted by fellow poet Pei Di.

760.event: Fourteenth recorded perihelion passage of Halley's Comet.

-763.event: Assyrians record a solar eclipse that is later used to fix the chronology of Mesopotamian history.

762.event: Led by Muhammad al-Nafs al-Zakiyya, the Hasanid branch of the Alids begins the Alid Revolt against the Abbasid Caliphate.
During the An Shi Rebellion, the Tang dynasty, with the help of Huihe tribe, recaptures Luoyang from the rebels.

763.event: Following the Battle of Bakhamra between Alids and Abbasids near Kufa, the Alid rebellion ends with the death of Ibrahim, brother of Isa ibn Musa.
The Byzantine army of emperor Constantine V defeats the Bulgarian forces in the Battle of Anchialus.

766.event: Emperor Constantine V humiliates nineteen high-ranking officials, after discovering a plot against him. He executes the leaders, Constantine Podopagouros and his brother Strategios.

768.event: Pope Stephen III is elected to office, and quickly seeks Frankish protection against the Lombard threat, since the Byzantine Empire is no longer able to help.
Carloman I and Charlemagne are crowned kings of the Franks.

769.event: The Lateran Council condemns the Council of Hieria and anathematizes its iconoclastic rulings.

771.event: Austrasian king Carloman I dies, leaving his brother Charlemagne king of the now complete Frankish Kingdom.

775.event: The Battle of Bagrevand puts an end to an Armenian rebellion against the Abbasid Caliphate. Muslim control over the South Caucasus is solidified and its Islamization begins, while several major Armenian nakharar families lose power and their remnants flee to the Byzantine Empire.

778.event: The Battle of Roncevaux Pass takes place between the army of Charlemagne and a Basque army.

781.event: The oldest recorded eruption of Mount Fuji (Traditional Japanese date: Sixth day of the seventh month of the first year of the Ten'o (天応) era).

783.event: The Asturian queen Adosinda is held at a monastery to prevent her king from retaking the throne from Mauregatus.

786.event: A Hasanid Alid uprising in Mecca is crushed by the Abbasids at the Battle of Fakhkh.
"Night of the three Caliphs": Harun al-Rashid becomes the Abbasid caliph upon the death of his brother al-Hadi. Birth of Harun's son al-Ma'mun.

787.event: Second Council of Nicaea: The council assembles at the church of Hagia Sophia.

789.event: Idris I reaches Volubilis and founds the Idrisid dynasty, marking the secession of Morocco from the Abbasid caliphate and founding the first Moroccan state.

792.event: Kardam of Bulgaria defeats Byzantine Emperor Constantine VI at the Battle of Marcellae.

793.event: Vikings raid the abbey at Lindisfarne in Northumbria, commonly accepted as the beginning of Norse activity in the British Isles.

794.event: While visiting the royal Mercian court at Sutton Walls with a view to marrying princess Ælfthryth, King Æthelberht II of East Anglia is taken captive and beheaded.
Emperor Kanmu relocates the Japanese capital to Heian-kyō (now Kyoto).

796.event: King Æthelred I of Northumbria is murdered in Corbridge by a group led by his ealdormen, Ealdred and Wada. The patrician Osbald is crowned, but abdicates within 27 days.

797.event: Empress Irene organizes a conspiracy against her son, the Byzantine emperor Constantine VI. He is deposed and blinded. Shortly after, Constantine dies of his wounds; Irene proclaims herself basileus.

799.event: After mistreatment and disfigurement by the citizens of Rome, pope Leo III flees to the Frankish court of king Charlemagne at Paderborn for protection.

800.event: A council is convened in the Vatican, at which Charlemagne is to judge the accusations against Pope Leo III.
The coronation of Charlemagne as Holy Roman Emperor, in Rome.

801.event: King Louis the Pious captures Barcelona from the Moors after a siege of several months.

802.event: Empress Irene is deposed and banished to Lesbos. Conspirators place Nikephoros, the minister of finance, on the Byzantine throne.

805.event: Noble Erchana of Dahauua grants the Bavarian town of Dachau to the Diocese of Freising

811.event: Byzantine emperor Nikephoros I plunders the Bulgarian capital of Pliska and captures Khan Krum's treasury.
Battle of Pliska: Byzantine Emperor Nikephoros I is killed and his heir Staurakios is seriously wounded.

813.event: Battle of Versinikia: The Bulgars led by Krum defeat the Byzantine army near Edirne. Emperor Michael I is forced to abdicate in favor of Leo V the Armenian.
Byzantine emperor Michael I, under threat by conspiracies, abdicates in favor of his general Leo the Armenian, and becomes a monk (under the name Athanasius).

814.event: The death of Charlemagne, the first Holy Roman Emperor, brings about the accession of his son Louis the Pious as ruler of the Frankish Empire.

816.event: King Louis the Pious is crowned emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by the Pope.

820.event: Eastern Emperor Leo V is murdered in a church of the Great Palace of Constantinople by followers of Michael II.

823.event: Lothair I is crowned King of Italy by Pope Paschal I.

829.event: Theophilos succeeds his father Michael II as Byzantine Emperor.

834.event: Emperor Louis the Pious is restored as sole ruler of the Frankish Empire.

835.event: Sweet Dew Incident: Emperor Wenzong of the Tang dynasty conspires to kill the powerful eunuchs of the Tang court, but the plot is foiled.

836.event: Pactum Sicardi, a peace treaty between the Principality of Benevento and the Duchy of Naples, is signed.

837.event: Halley's Comet makes its closest approach to Earth at a distance equal to 0.0342 AU (5.1 million kilometres/3.2 million miles).

838.event: Battle of Anzen: The Byzantine emperor Theophilos suffers a heavy defeat by the Abbasids.

841.event: In the Battle of Fontenay-en-Puisaye, forces led by Charles the Bald and Louis the German defeat the armies of Lothair I of Italy and Pepin II of Aquitaine.

842.event: Charles the Bald and Louis the German swear the Oaths of Strasbourg in the French and German languages.

843.event: Triumph of Orthodoxy: Empress Theodora II restores the veneration of icons in the Orthodox churches in the Byzantine Empire.
The Vikings sack French city of Nantes.

844.event: Louis II is crowned as king of Italy at Rome by pope Sergius II.

845.event: The 42 Martyrs of Amorium are killed after refusing to convert to Islam.
Paris is sacked by Viking raiders, probably under Ragnar Lodbrok, who collects a huge ransom in exchange for leaving.
The first duke of Brittany, Nominoe, defeats the Frankish king Charles the Bald at the Battle of Ballon near Redon.

851.event: Battle of Jengland: Erispoe defeats Charles the Bald near the Breton town of Jengland.

852.event: Croatian Knez Trpimir I issues a statute, a document with the first known written mention of the Croats name in Croatian sources.

853.event: A Byzantine fleet sacks and destroys undefended Damietta in Egypt.

856.event: Michael III, emperor of the Byzantine Empire, overthrows the regency of his mother, empress Theodora (wife of Theophilos) with support of the Byzantine nobility.
Damghan earthquake: An earthquake near the Persian city of Damghan kills an estimated 200,000 people, the sixth deadliest earthquake in recorded history.

860.event: Byzantine-Rus' War: A fleet of about 200 Rus' vessels sails into the Bosphorus and starts pillaging the suburbs of the Byzantine capital Constantinople.

861.event: Assassination of the Abbasid caliph al-Mutawakkil by the Turkish guard, who raise al-Muntasir to the throne. Start of the "Anarchy at Samarra".

863.event: Major Byzantine victory at the Battle of Lalakaon against an Arab raid.

864.event: The Edict of Pistres of Charles the Bald orders defensive measures against the Vikings.

866.event: Battle of Brissarthe: The Franks led by Robert the Strong are defeated by a joint Breton-Viking army.

868.event: A copy of the Diamond Sutra is printed in China, making it the oldest known dated printed book.

869.event: The 8.4-9.0 Mw  Sanriku earthquake strikes the area around Sendai in northern Honshu, Japan. Inundation from the tsunami extended several kilometers inland.
The Fourth Council of Constantinople is convened to depose patriarch Photios I.

870.event: The Fourth Council of Constantinople closes.
Treaty of Meerssen: King Louis the German and his half-brother Charles the Bald partition the Middle Frankish Kingdom into two larger east and west divisions.
The city of Melite surrenders to an Aghlabid army following a siege, putting an end to Byzantine Malta.
Battle of Englefield: The Vikings clash with ealdorman Æthelwulf of Berkshire. The invaders are driven back to Reading (East Anglia); many Danes are killed.

871.event: Battle of Reading: Æthelred of Wessex and his brother Alfred are defeated by a Danish invasion army.
Æthelred I and Alfred the Great lead a West Saxon army to repel an invasion by Danelaw Vikings.
Battle of Basing: The West Saxons led by King Æthelred I are defeated by the Danelaw Vikings at Basing.
Æthelred of Wessex is defeated by a Danish invasion army at the Battle of Marton.

872.event: Louis II of Italy is crowned for the second time as Holy Roman Emperor at Rome, at the age of 47. His first coronation was 28 years earlier, in 844, during the reign of his father Lothair I.

875.event: Charles the Bald, King of the Franks, is crowned as Holy Roman Emperor Charles II.

876.event: The Battle of Dayr al-'Aqul saves Baghdad from the Saffarids.
Frankish forces led by Louis the Younger prevent a West Frankish invasion and defeat emperor Charles II ("the Bald").

877.event: Louis the Stammerer (son of Charles the Bald) is crowned king of the West Frankish Kingdom at Compiègne.

878.event: Syracuse, Sicily, is captured by the Muslim Aghlabids after a nine-month siege.
Louis the Stammerer is crowned as king of West Francia by Pope John VIII.

879.event: Pope John VIII gives blessings to Branimir of Croatia and to the Croatian people, considered to be international recognition of the Croatian state.
Pope John VIII recognizes the Duchy of Croatia under Duke Branimir as an independent state.

880.event: Battle of Lüneburg Heath: King Louis III of France is defeated by the Norse Great Heathen Army at Lüneburg Heath in Saxony.
The Nea Ekklesia is inaugurated in Constantinople, setting the model for all later cross-in-square Orthodox churches.
Luoyang, eastern capital of the Tang dynasty, is captured by rebel leader Huang Chao during the reign of Emperor Xizong.

881.event: Battle of Saucourt-en-Vimeu: Louis III of France defeats the Vikings, an event celebrated in the poem Ludwigslied.

887.event: Emperor Charles the Fat is deposed by the Frankish magnates in an assembly at Frankfurt, leading his nephew, Arnulf of Carinthia, to declare himself king of the East Frankish Kingdom in late November.
Berengar I is elected as king of Italy by the lords of Lombardy. He is crowned with the Iron Crown of Lombardy at Pavia.

893.event: An earthquake destroys the city of Dvin, Armenia.

897.event: Al-Hadi ila'l-Haqq Yahya enters Sa'dah and founds the Zaydi Imamate of Yemen.

900.event: The Laguna Copperplate Inscription (the earliest known written document found in what is now the Philippines): the Commander-in-Chief of the Kingdom of Tondo, as represented by the Honourable Jayadewa, Lord Minister of Pailah, pardons from all debt the Honourable Namwaran and his relations.
Count Reginar I of Hainault rises against Zwentibold of Lotharingia and slays him near present-day Susteren.

902.event: Taormina, the last Byzantine stronghold in Sicily, is captured by the Aghlabid army, concluding the Muslim conquest of Sicily.

903.event: The Abbasid army under Muhammad ibn Sulayman al-Katib defeats the Qarmatians at the Battle of Hama.

904.event: Sergius III is elected pope, after coming out of retirement to take over the papacy from the deposed antipope Christopher.
Sack of Thessalonica: Saracen raiders under Leo of Tripoli sack Thessaloniki, the Byzantine Empire's second-largest city, after a short siege, and plunder it for a week.
The warlord Zhu Quanzhong kills Emperor Zhaozong, the penultimate emperor of the Tang dynasty, after seizing control of the imperial government.

905.event: King Berengar I of Italy and a hired Hungarian army defeats the Frankish forces at Verona. King Louis III is captured and blinded for breaking his oath (see 902).

906.event: Ahmad ibn Kayghalagh leads a raid against the Byzantine Empire, taking 4,000-5,000 captives.

907.event: Abaoji, chieftain of the Yila tribe, is named khagan of the Khitans.
Zhu Wen forces Emperor Ai into abdicating, ending the Tang dynasty after nearly three hundred years of rule.

908.event: Battle of Eisenach: An invading Hungarian force defeats an East Frankish army under Duke Burchard of Thuringia.

910.event: Battle of Augsburg: The Hungarians defeat the East Frankish army under King Louis the Child, using the famous feigned retreat tactic of the nomadic warriors.
The Hungarians defeat the East Frankish army near the Rednitz River, killing its leader Gebhard, Duke of Lotharingia (Lorraine).

The last major Danish army to raid England for nearly a century is defeated at the Battle of Tettenhall by the allied forces of Mercia and Wessex, led by King Edward the Elder and Æthelred, Lord of the Mercians.

911.event: Signing of the Treaty of Saint-Clair-sur-Epte between Charles the Simple and Rollo of Normandy.

912.event: Alexander becomes Emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Abd ar-Rahman III becomes the eighth Emir of Córdoba.

913.event: Constantine VII, the 8-year-old illegitimate son of Leo VI the Wise, becomes nominal ruler of the Byzantine Empire under the regency of a seven-man council headed by Patriarch Nicholas Mystikos, appointed by Constantine's uncle Alexander III on his deathbed.

914.event: Start of the First Fatimid invasion of Egypt.

915.event: Pope John X crowns Berengar I of Italy as Holy Roman Emperor (probable date).

917.event: Battle of Acheloos: Tsar Simeon I of Bulgaria decisively defeats a Byzantine army.
Liu Yan declares himself emperor, establishing the Southern Han state in southern China, at his capital of Panyu.

919.event: Romanos Lekapenos seizes the Boukoleon Palace in Constantinople and becomes regent of the Byzantine emperor Constantine VII.
The second Fatimid invasion of Egypt begins, when the Fatimid heir-apparent, al-Qa'im bi-Amr Allah, sets out from Raqqada at the head of his army.
The nobles of Franconia and Saxony elect Henry the Fowler at the Imperial Diet in Fritzlar as king of the East Frankish Kingdom.
Battle of Islandbridge: High King Niall Glúndub is killed while leading an Irish coalition against the Vikings of Uí Ímair, led by King Sitric Cáech.

920.event: Rout of an alliance of Christian troops from Navarre and Léon against the Muslims at the Battle of Valdejunquera.
Romanos I Lekapenos is crowned co-emperor of the underage Constantine VII.

921.event: Treaty of Bonn: The Frankish kings Charles the Simple and Henry the Fowler sign a peace treaty or 'pact of friendship' (amicitia) to recognize their borders along the Rhine.

923.event: Battle of Soissons: King Robert I of France is killed and King Charles the Simple is arrested by the supporters of Duke Rudolph of Burgundy.
Battle of Firenzuola: Lombard forces under King Rudolph II and Adalbert I, margrave of Ivrea, defeat the dethroned Emperor Berengar I of Italy at Firenzuola (Tuscany).
The Qarmatians of Bahrayn capture and pillage the city of Basra.

927.event: King Constantine II of Scotland, King Hywel Dda of Deheubarth, Ealdred of Bamburgh and King Owain of the Cumbrians accepted the overlordship of King Æthelstan of England, leading to seven years of peace in the north.
The Saracens conquer and destroy Taranto.
The Sajid emir of Adharbayjan, Yusuf ibn Abi'l-Saj is defeated and captured by the Qarmatians near Kufa.

929.event: Emir Abd-ar-Rahman III establishes the Caliphate of Córdoba.
Battle of Lenzen: Slavic forces (the Redarii and the Obotrites) are defeated by a Saxon army near the fortified stronghold of Lenzen in Brandenburg.

932.event: After a two-years siege, the city of Toledo, in Spain, surrenders to the forces of the Caliph of Córdoba Abd al-Rahman III, assuming an important victory in his campaign to subjugate the Central March.
Abbasid caliph al-Muqtadir is killed while fighting against the forces of general Mu'nis al-Muzaffar. Al-Muqtadir's brother al-Qahir is chosen to succeed him.

933.event: After a ten-year truce, German King Henry the Fowler defeats a Hungarian army at the Battle of Riade near the Unstrut river.

934.event: Meng Zhixiang declares himself emperor and establishes Later Shu as a new state independent of Later Tang.

935.event: Duke Wenceslaus I of Bohemia is murdered by a group of nobles led by his brother Boleslaus I, who succeeds him.

936.event: King Henry the Fowler dies in his royal palace in Memleben. He is succeeded by his son Otto I, who becomes the ruler of East Francia.
Coronation of King Otto I of Germany.
Shi Jingtang is enthroned as the first emperor of the Later Jin by Emperor Taizong of Liao, following a revolt against Emperor Fei of Later Tang.

937.event: Ten Kingdoms: Li Bian usurps the throne and deposes Emperor Yang Pu. The Wu State is replaced by Li (now called "Xu Zhigao"), who becomes the first ruler of Southern Tang.

938.event: Translation of the relics of martyr Wenceslaus I, Duke of Bohemia, Prince of the Czechs.

939.event: Battle of Simancas: King Ramiro II of León defeats the Moorish army under Caliph Abd-al-Rahman III near the city of Simancas.
The Battle of Alhandic is fought between Ramiro II of León and Abd-ar-Rahman III at Zamora in the context of the Spanish Reconquista. The battle resulted in a victory for the Emirate of Córdoba.
Battle of Andernach: Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor, crushes a rebellion against his rule, by a coalition of Eberhard of Franconia and other Frankish dukes.
Æthelstan, the first king of all England, dies and is succeeded by his half-brother, Edmund I.

942.event: Start of the four-day Battle of al-Mada'in, between the Hamdanids of Mosul and the Baridis of Basra over control of the Abbasid capital, Baghdad.
Assassination of William I of Normandy.

945.event: The co-emperors Stephen and Constantine are overthrown and forced to become monks by Constantine VII, who becomes sole emperor of the Byzantine Empire.

946.event: Caliph Al-Mustakfi is blinded and deposed by Emir Mu'izz al-Dawla, ruler of the Buyid Empire. He is succeeded by Al-Muti as caliph of the Abbasid Caliphate.
Emperor Suzaku abdicates the throne in favor of his brother Murakami who becomes the 62nd emperor of Japan.
King Edmund I of England is murdered by a thief whom he personally attacks while celebrating St Augustine's Mass Day.

947.event: Emperor Tai Zong of the Khitan-led Liao Dynasty invades the Later Jin, resulting in the destruction of the Later Jin.
The Later Han is founded by Liu Zhiyuan. He declares himself emperor.
Abu Yazid, a Kharijite rebel leader, is defeated and killed in the Hodna Mountains in modern-day Algeria by Fatimid forces.

951.event: Guo Wei, a court official, leads a military coup and declares himself emperor of the new Later Zhou.
Emperor Li Jing sends a Southern Tang expeditionary force of 10,000 men under Bian Hao to conquer Chu. Li Jing removes the ruling family to his own capital in Nanjing, ending the Chu Kingdom.

954.event: The 13-year-old Lothair III is crowned at the Abbey of Saint-Remi as king of the West Frankish Kingdom.

955.event: Battle of Lechfeld: Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor defeats the Magyars, ending 50 years of Magyar invasion of the West.
King Otto I defeats a Slavic revolt in what is now Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.

959.event: Eraclus becomes the 25th bishop of Liège.
Edgar the Peaceful becomes king of all England, in succession to Eadwig.

960.event: The coronation of Zhao Kuangyin as Emperor Taizu of Song, initiating the Song dynasty period of China that would last more than three centuries.
Battle of Andrassos: Byzantines under Leo Phokas the Younger score a crushing victory over the Hamdanid Emir of Aleppo, Sayf al-Dawla.

961.event: Byzantine conquest of Chandax by Nikephoros Phokas, end of the Emirate of Crete.
King Otto I elects his six-year-old son Otto II as heir apparent and co-ruler of the East Frankish Kingdom. He is crowned at Aachen, and placed under the tutelage of his grandmother Matilda.

962.event: Translatio imperii: Pope John XII crowns Otto I, Holy Roman Emperor, the first Holy Roman Emperor in nearly 40 years.
Emperor Otto I and Pope John XII co-sign the Diploma Ottonianum, recognizing John as ruler of Rome.
The Sack of Aleppo as part of the Arab-Byzantine wars: Under the future Emperor Nicephorus Phocas, Byzantine troops storm the city of Aleppo.

963.event: The Byzantine army proclaims Nikephoros II Phokas Emperor of the Romans on the plains outside Cappadocian Caesarea.
Nikephoros II Phokas is crowned emperor of the Byzantine Empire.
Synod of Rome: Emperor Otto I calls a council at St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Pope John XII is deposed on charges of an armed rebellion against Otto.
Pope Leo VIII is appointed to the office of Protonotary and begins his papacy as antipope of Rome.

966.event: After his marriage to the Christian Doubravka of Bohemia, the pagan ruler of the Polans, Mieszko I, converts to Christianity, an event considered to be the founding of the Polish state.

969.event: The Fatimid general Jawhar leads the Friday prayer in Fustat in the name of Caliph al-Mu'izz li-Din Allah, thereby symbolically completing the Fatimid conquest of Egypt.
The Byzantine Empire recovers Antioch from Arab rule.
Byzantine Emperor Nikephoros II Phokas is assassinated by his wife Theophano and her lover, the later Emperor John I Tzimiskes.

971.event: Using crossbows, Song dynasty troops soundly defeat a war elephant corps of the Southern Han at Shao.
