972.event: Co-Emperor Otto II, a son of Otto I (the Great), marries the Byzantine princess Theophanu. She is crowned empress by Pope John XIII at Rome.
Battle of Cedynia, the first documented victory of Polish forces, takes place.

977.event: Franco-German war of 978-980: Holy Roman Emperor Otto II lifts the siege at Paris and withdraws. His rearguard is defeated while crossing the Aisne River by West Frankish forces under King Lothair III.

980.event: Vladimir the Great consolidates the Kievan realm from Ukraine to the Baltic Sea. He is proclaimed ruler (knyaz) of all Kievan Rus'.

982.event: King Otto II and his Frankish army were defeated by the Muslim army of al-Qasim at Cape Colonna, Southern Italy.
Holy Roman Emperor Otto II is defeated by the Saracens in the Battle of Capo Colonna, in Calabria.

986.event: Louis V becomes the last Carolingian king of West Francia after the death of his father, Lothaire.

Byzantine-Bulgarian wars: Battle of the Gates of Trajan: The Bulgarians under the Comitopuli Samuel and Aron defeat the Byzantine forces at the Gate of Trajan, with Byzantine Emperor Basil II barely escaping.

987.event: Bardas Phokas the Younger and Bardas Skleros, Byzantine generals of the military elite, begin a wide-scale rebellion against Emperor Basil II.
Hugh Capet is crowned King of France, the first of the Capetian dynasty that would rule France until the French Revolution in 1792.

988.event: The Norse King Glúniairn recognises Máel Sechnaill mac Domnaill, High King of Ireland, and agrees to pay taxes and accept Brehon Law; the event is considered to be the founding of the city of Dublin.

991.event: Battle of Maldon: The English, led by Byrhtnoth, Ealdorman of Essex, are defeated by a band of inland-raiding Vikings near Maldon, Essex.

993.event: Ulrich of Augsburg is canonized as a saint.

994.event: Major Fatimid victory over the Byzantine Empire at the Battle of the Orontes.

995.event: Boleslaus II, Duke of Bohemia, kills most members of the rival Slavník dynasty.

996.event: Sixteen-year-old Otto III is crowned Holy Roman Emperor.
Emperor Otto III issues a deed to Gottschalk, Bishop of Freising, which is the oldest known document using the name Ostarrîchi (Austria in Old High German).

997.event: Battle of Spercheios: Bulgarian forces of Tsar Samuel are defeated by a Byzantine army under general Nikephoros Ouranos at the Spercheios River in Greece.

998.event: Arab-Byzantine wars: Battle of Apamea: Fatimids defeat a Byzantine army near Apamea.

999.event: Battle of Glenmama: The combined forces of Munster and Meath under king Brian Boru inflict a crushing defeat on the allied armies of Leinster and Dublin near Lyons Hill in Ireland.

1000.event: Fatimid caliph al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah assassinates the eunuch chief minister Barjawan and assumes control of the government.
The foundation of the Kingdom of Hungary: Hungary is established as a Christian kingdom by Stephen I of Hungary.

1001.event: Grand Prince Stephen I of Hungary is named the first King of Hungary by Pope Sylvester II (probable).

1002.event: At an assembly at Pavia of Lombard nobles, Arduin of Ivrea is restored to his domains and crowned King of Italy.
Henry II, a cousin of Emperor Otto III, is elected and crowned King of Germany.
English king Æthelred II orders the killing of all Danes in England, known today as the St. Brice's Day massacre.

1003.event: Boleslaus III is restored to authority with armed support from Bolesław I the Brave of Poland.

1009.event: First known mention of Lithuania, in the annals of the monastery of Quedlinburg.
Lombard Revolt: Lombard forces led by Melus revolt in Bari against the Byzantine Catepanate of Italy.
Pope Sergius IV becomes the 142nd pope, succeeding Pope John XVIII.
Mainz Cathedral suffers extensive damage from a fire, which destroys the building on the day of its inauguration.
The Church of the Holy Sepulchre, a Christian church in Jerusalem, is completely destroyed by the Fatimid caliph Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah, who hacks the Church's foundations down to bedrock.
Berber forces led by Sulayman ibn al-Hakam defeat the Umayyad caliph Muhammad II of Córdoba in the battle of Alcolea.
Lý Công Uẩn is enthroned as emperor of Đại Cồ Việt, founding the Lý dynasty.

1010.event: Ferdowsi completes his epic poem Shahnameh.

1011.event: Lombard Revolt: Greek citizens of Bari rise up against the Lombard rebels led by Melus and deliver the city to Basil Mesardonites, Byzantine governor (catepan) of the Catepanate of Italy.
Danes capture Canterbury after a siege, taking Ælfheah, archbishop of Canterbury, as a prisoner.

1012.event: Duke Oldřich of Bohemia deposes and blinds his brother Jaromír, who flees to Poland.

1013.event: Sweyn Forkbeard takes control of the Danelaw and is proclaimed king of England.

1014.event: Pope Benedict VIII crowns Henry of Bavaria, King of Germany and of Italy, as Holy Roman Emperor.
Battle of Clontarf: High King of Ireland Brian Boru defeats Viking invaders, but is killed in battle.

Byzantine-Bulgarian wars: Battle of Kleidion: Byzantine emperor Basil II inflicts a decisive defeat on the Bulgarian army, and his subsequent treatment of 15,000 prisoners reportedly causes Tsar Samuil of Bulgaria to die of a heart attack less than three months later, on October 6.

1016.event: Edmund Ironside succeeds his father Æthelred the Unready as King of England.
The Danes defeat the English in the Battle of Assandun.

1018.event: Poland and the Holy Roman Empire conclude the Peace of Bautzen.
Count Dirk III defeats an army sent by Emperor Henry II in the Battle of Vlaardingen.
Byzantine general Eustathios Daphnomeles blinds and captures Ibatzes of Bulgaria by a ruse, thereby ending Bulgarian resistance against Emperor Basil II's conquest of Bulgaria.

1021.event: On the feast of Eid al-Adha, the death of the Fatimid caliph al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah, kept secret for six weeks, is announced, along with the succession of his son, al-Zahir li-i'zaz Din Allah. On the same day, al-Hakim's designated heir, Abd al-Rahim ibn Ilyas, is arrested in Damascus and brought to Egypt.

1025.event: Constantine VIII becomes sole emperor of the Byzantine Empire, 63 years after being crowned co-emperor.
Coronation of Mieszko II Lambert as king of Poland.

1027.event: Pope John XIX crowns Conrad II as Holy Roman Emperor.
Robert II of France names his son Henry I as junior King of the Franks.

1028.event: Constantine VIII died, ending his uninterrupted reign as emperor or co-emperor of the Byzantine Empire of 66 years.
Future Byzantine empress Zoe takes the throne as empress consort to Romanos III Argyros.

1030.event: Ladejarl-Fairhair succession wars: Battle of Stiklestad: King Olaf II fights and dies trying to regain his Norwegian throne from the Danes.

The Battle of Azaz ends with a humiliating retreat of the Byzantine emperor, Romanos III Argyros, against the Mirdasid rulers of Aleppo. The retreat degenerates into a rout, in which Romanos himself barely escapes capture.

1031.event: Olaf II of Norway is canonized as Saint Olaf by Grimketel, the English Bishop of Selsey.

1032.event: Conrad II, Holy Roman Emperor becomes king of Burgundy.

1034.event: Máel Coluim mac Cináeda, King of Scots, dies. His grandson, Donnchad, son of Bethóc and Crínán of Dunkeld, inherits the throne.

1035.event: William the Conqueror becomes the Duke of Normandy, reigns until 1087.

1038.event: King Stephen I, the first king of Hungary, dies; his nephew, Peter Orseolo, succeeds him.

1040.event: King Duncan I is killed in battle against his first cousin and rival Macbeth. The latter succeeds him as King of Scotland.

1041.event: Michael V, adoptive son of Empress Zoë of Byzantium, is proclaimed emperor of the Eastern Roman Empire.

1042.event: Edward the Confessor becomes King of England - the country's penultimate Anglo-Saxon king.

1043.event: Edward the Confessor is crowned King of England.

1046.event: Nasir Khusraw begins the seven-year Middle Eastern journey which he will later describe in his book Safarnama.
Henry III is crowned Holy Roman Emperor by Pope Clement II.

1048.event: Damasus II is elected pope, and dies 23 days later.
Battle of Kapetron between a combined Byzantine-Georgian army and a Seljuq army.

1051.event: Henry I of France marries the Rus' princess, Anne of Kiev.

1053.event: Battle of Civitate: Three thousand Norman horsemen of Count Humphrey rout the troops of Pope Leo IX.

1054.event: A supernova, called SN 1054, is seen by Chinese Song dynasty, Arab, and possibly Amerindian observers near the star Zeta Tauri. For several months it remains bright enough to be seen during the day. Its remnants form the Crab Nebula.

Three Roman legates break relations between Western and Eastern Christian Churches through the act of placing an Papal bull (of doubtful validity) of Excommunication on the altar of Hagia Sophia during Saturday afternoon divine liturgy. Historians frequently describe the event as the start of the East-West Schism.
Siward, Earl of Northumbria, invades Scotland and defeats Macbeth, King of Scotland somewhere north of the Firth of Forth.

1055.event: Theodora is crowned empress of the Byzantine Empire.

1056.event: After a sudden illness a few days previously, Byzantine Empress Theodora dies childless, thus ending the Macedonian dynasty.

1057.event: Frederik van Lotharingen elected as first Belgian Pope Stephen IX.
King Macbeth is killed at the Battle of Lumphanan by the forces of Máel Coluim mac Donnchada.
Abdication of Byzantine Emperor Michael VI Bringas after just one year.

1058.event: Agnes of Poitou and Andrew I of Hungary meet to negotiate about the border territory of Burgenland.

1060.event: Béla I is crowned king of Hungary.

1065.event: Edward the Confessor's Romanesque monastic church at Westminster Abbey is consecrated.

1066.event: Following the death of Edward the Confessor on the previous day, the Witan meets to confirm Harold Godwinson as the new King of England; Harold is crowned the same day, sparking a succession crisis that will eventually lead to the Norman conquest of England.
Norwegian king Harald Hardrada lands with Tostig Godwinson at the mouth of the Humber River and begins his invasion of England.
At the Battle of Fulford, Harald Hardrada defeats earls Morcar and Edwin.
In the Battle of Stamford Bridge, Harald Hardrada, the invading King of Norway, is defeated by King Harold II of England.
William the Conqueror and his army set sail from the mouth of the Somme river, beginning the Norman conquest of England.
William the Conqueror lands in England, beginning the Norman conquest.
The Norman conquest of England begins with the Battle of Hastings.

Following the death of Harold II at the Battle of Hastings, Edgar the Ætheling is proclaimed King of England by the Witan; he is never crowned, and concedes power to William the Conqueror two months later.
William the Conqueror, Duke of Normandy is crowned king of England, at Westminster Abbey, London.
Granada massacre: A Muslim mob storms the royal palace in Granada, crucifies Jewish vizier Joseph ibn Naghrela and massacres most of the Jewish population of the city.

1068.event: Romanos IV Diogenes marries Eudokia Makrembolitissa and is crowned Byzantine Emperor.
An earthquake in the Levant and the Arabian Peninsula leaves up to 20,000 dead.
Byzantine-Norman wars: Italo-Normans begin a nearly-three-year siege of Bari.

1069.event: Robert de Comines, appointed Earl of Northumbria by William the Conqueror, rides into Durham, England, where he is defeated and killed by rebels. This incident leads to the Harrying of the North.

1070.event: The Pavian-born Benedictine Lanfranc is appointed as the new Archbishop of Canterbury in England.

1071.event: Bari, the last Byzantine possession in southern Italy, is surrendered to Robert Guiscard.
The Seljuq Turks defeat the Byzantine army at the Battle of Manzikert, and soon gain control of most of Anatolia.

1072.event: Robert Guiscard conquers Palermo in Sicily for the Normans.

1074.event: Battle of Mogyoród: Dukes Géza and Ladislaus defeat their cousin Solomon, King of Hungary, forcing him to flee to Hungary's western borderland.

1075.event: Dmitar Zvonimir is crowned King of Croatia.

1076.event: Having received a letter during the Lenten synod of 14-20 February demanding that he abdicate, Pope Gregory VII excommunicates Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor.
Coronation of Bolesław II the Generous as king of Poland.

1077.event: Walk to Canossa: The excommunication of Henry IV, Holy Roman Emperor, is lifted after he humbles himself before Pope Gregory VII at Canossa in Italy.
The Patriarchate of Friûl, the first Friulian state, is created.

1080.event: Harald III of Denmark dies and is succeeded by Canute IV, who would later be the first Dane to be canonized.

1081.event: Alexios I Komnenos overthrows the Byzantine emperor Nikephoros III Botaneiates, and, after his troops spend three days extensively looting Constantinople, is formally crowned on April 4.
The Normans defeat the Byzantine Empire in the Battle of Dyrrhachium.

1082.event: Ramon Berenguer II, Count of Barcelona is assassinated.

1083.event: Canonization of the first King of Hungary, Saint Stephen and his son Saint Emeric celebrated as a National Day in Hungary.

1085.event: Alfonso VI of Castile takes Toledo, Spain, back from the Moors.

1086.event: King Canute IV of Denmark is killed by rebellious peasants.
Spanish Reconquista: At the Battle of Sagrajas, the Almoravids defeats the Castilians, but are unable to take advantage of their victory.

1087.event: William Rufus becomes King of England, taking the title William II, (reigned until 1100).
William II is crowned King of England, and reigns until 1100.

1088.event: Election of Urban II as the 159th Pope of the Catholic Church. He is best known for initiating the Crusades.

1091.event: Battle of Levounion: The Pechenegs are defeated by Byzantine Emperor Alexios I Komnenos.[citation needed]
London tornado of 1091: A tornado thought to be of strength T8/F4 strikes the heart of London.

1092.event: The Diocese of Pisa is elevated to the rank of metropolitan archdiocese by Pope Urban II

1093.event: Battle of Alnwick: in an English victory over the Scots, Malcolm III of Scotland, and his son Edward, are killed.

1095.event: The Council of Clermont begins: called by Pope Urban II, it led to the First Crusade to the Holy Land.
Pope Urban II declares the First Crusade at the Council of Clermont.

1096.event: First Crusade: Around 800 Jews are massacred in Worms, Germany.
Count Emicho enters Mainz, where his followers massacre Jewish citizens. At least 600 Jews are killed.
Starting date of the First Crusade as set by Pope Urban II.
A Seljuk Turkish army successfully fights off the People's Crusade.

1097.event: The Siege of Nicaea begins during the First Crusade.
Battle of Dorylaeum: Crusaders led by prince Bohemond of Taranto defeat a Seljuk army led by sultan Kilij Arslan I.
First Crusade: Crusaders led by Godfrey of Bouillon, Bohemund of Taranto, and Raymond IV, Count of Toulouse, begin the Siege of Antioch.

1098.event: First Crusade: The first Siege of Antioch ends as Crusader forces take the city; the second siege began five days later.
After 5-month siege during the First Crusade, the Crusaders seize Antioch (today's Turkey).
Fighters of the First Crusade defeat Kerbogha of Mosul.

1099.event: First Crusade: The Siege of Jerusalem begins.
Some 15,000 starving Christian soldiers begin the siege of Jerusalem by marching in a religious procession around the city as its Muslim defenders watch.
First Crusade: Christian soldiers take the Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem after the final assault of a difficult siege.
First Crusade: Godfrey of Bouillon is elected the first Defender of the Holy Sepulchre of The Kingdom of Jerusalem.
First Crusade: Battle of Ascalon Crusaders under the command of Godfrey of Bouillon defeat Fatimid forces led by Al-Afdal Shahanshah. This is considered the last engagement of the First Crusade.
Raniero is elected as Pope Paschal II.

1100.event: Henry I is crowned King of England in Westminster Abbey.
Henry I of England marries Matilda of Scotland, the daughter of Malcolm III of Scotland and a direct descendant of the Saxon king Edmund Ironside; Matilda is crowned in the same day.
Baldwin of Boulogne is crowned the first King of Jerusalem in the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem.

1105.event: Maginulfo is elected the Antipope as Sylvester IV.
Holy Roman Emperor Henry IV is forced to abdicate in favor of his son, Henry V, in Ingelheim.

1106.event: King Henry I of England defeats his brother Robert Curthose at the Battle of Tinchebray.

1108.event: Battle of Uclés: Almoravid troops under the command of Tamim ibn Yusuf defeat a Castile and León alliance under the command of Prince Sancho Alfónsez.

1110.event: The Kingdom of Jerusalem captures Sidon.

1111.event: Henry V is crowned Holy Roman Emperor.
Highest Galician nobility led by Pedro Fróilaz de Traba and the bishop Diego Gelmírez crown Alfonso VII as "King of Galicia".

1112.event: Ramon Berenguer III, Count of Barcelona, and Douce I, Countess of Provence, marry, uniting the fortunes of those two states.

1113.event: Pope Paschal II issues Pie Postulatio Voluntatis, recognizing the Order of Hospitallers.

1118.event: Roger of Salerno, Prince of Antioch, captures Azaz from the Seljuk Turks.

1120.event: Crusades: The Council of Nablus is held, establishing the earliest surviving written laws of the Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem.
Richard III of Capua is anointed as Prince two weeks before his untimely death.
Jordan II of Capua is anointed as prince after his infant nephew's death.
The White Ship sinks in the English Channel, drowning William Adelin, son and heir of Henry I of England.

1121.event: Battle of Didgori: The Georgian army under King David IV wins a decisive victory over the famous Seljuk commander Ilghazi.

1122.event: Pope Callixtus II and Holy Roman Emperor Henry V agree to the Concordat of Worms to put an end to the Investiture Controversy.

1124.event: The city of Tyre falls to the Venetian Crusade after a siege of nineteen weeks.
Pope Honorius II is consecrated, having been elected after the controversial dethroning of Pope Celestine II.

1126.event: Emperor Huizong abdicates the Chinese throne in favour of his son Emperor Qinzong.
Following the death of his mother, queen Urraca of León, Alfonso VII is proclaimed king of León.

1127.event: Jin-Song Wars: Invading Jurchen soldiers from the Jin dynasty besiege and sack Bianjing (Kaifeng), the capital of the Song dynasty of China, and abduct Emperor Qinzong of Song and others, ending the Northern Song dynasty.

1128.event: Geoffrey V of Anjou, known as Plantagenet, marries Matilda, daughter of Henry I, King of England, and widow of the Emperor Henry V.
Battle of São Mamede, near Guimarães: Forces led by Afonso I defeat forces led by his mother Teresa of León and her lover Fernando Pérez de Traba.

1130.event: The troubled 1130 papal election exposes a rift within the College of Cardinals.
Count Roger II of Sicily is crowned the first king of Sicily.

1132.event: Battle of Nocera between Ranulf II of Alife and Roger II of Sicily.

1134.event: The name Zagreb was mentioned for the first time in the Felician Charter relating to the establishment of the Zagreb Bishopric around 1094.

1135.event: Alfonso VII of León and Castile is crowned in León Cathedral as Imperator totius Hispaniae (Emperor of all of Spain).
Three weeks after the death of King Henry I of England, Stephen of Blois claims the throne and is privately crowned King of England, beginning the English Anarchy.

1137.event: Eleanor of Aquitaine marries Prince Louis, later King Louis VII of France, at the Cathedral of Saint-André in Bordeaux.
Ranulf of Apulia defeats Roger II of Sicily at the Battle of Rignano, securing his position as duke until his death two years later.

1138.event: Konrad III von Hohenstaufen was elected king of Germany at Coblenz in the presence of the papal legate Theodwin.
Battle of the Standard between Scotland and England.
A massive earthquake strikes Aleppo; it is one of the most destructive earthquakes ever.
Lý Anh Tông is enthroned as emperor of Vietnam at the age of two, beginning a 37-year reign.

1139.event: Roger II of Sicily is excommunicated by Innocent II for supporting Anacletus II as pope for seven years, even though Roger had already publicly recognized Innocent's claim to the papacy.
Battle of Ourique: The Almoravids, led by Ali ibn Yusuf, are defeated by Prince Afonso Henriques who is proclaimed King of Portugal.
A magnitude 7.7 earthquake strikes the Caucasus mountains in the Seljuk Empire, causing mass destruction and killing up to 300,000 people.

1140.event: The French scholar Peter Abelard is found guilty of heresy.
Song dynasty general Yue Fei defeats an army led by Jin dynasty general Wuzhu at the Battle of Yancheng during the Jin-Song Wars.
After a siege of several weeks, the city of Weinsberg and its castle surrender to Conrad III of Germany.

1141.event: The Battle of Lincoln, at which Stephen, King of England is defeated and captured by the allies of Empress Matilda.
Empress Matilda becomes the first female ruler of England, adopting the title 'Lady of the English'.
Yelü Dashi, the Liao dynasty general who founded the Qara Khitai, defeats the Seljuq and Kara-Khanid forces at the Battle of Qatwan.
Empress Matilda's reign as 'Lady of the English' ends with Stephen of Blois regaining the title of 'King of England'.

1142.event: A peace treaty ends the Jin-Song wars.

1143.event: With the signing of the Treaty of Zamora, King Alfonso VII of León and Castile recognises Portugal as a Kingdom.

1144.event: The capital of the crusader County of Edessa falls to Imad ad-Din Zengi, the atabeg of Mosul and Aleppo.

1145.event: The main altar of Lund Cathedral, at the time seat of the archiepiscopal see of all the Nordic countries, is consecrated.

1146.event: Bernard of Clairvaux preaches his famous sermon in a field at Vézelay, urging the necessity of a Second Crusade. Louis VII is present, and joins the Crusade.

1147.event: Seljuk Turks defeat German crusaders under Conrad III at the Battle of Dorylaeum.
Reconquista: After a siege of four months, crusader knights reconquer Lisbon.

1148.event: Louis VII of France lays siege to Damascus during the Second Crusade.
The Siege of Damascus ends in a decisive crusader defeat and leads to the disintegration of the Second Crusade.

1149.event: Pope Eugene III takes refuge in the castle of Ptolemy II of Tusculum.
Raymond of Poitiers is defeated and killed at the Battle of Inab by Nur ad-Din Zangi.
The reconstructed Church of the Holy Sepulchre is consecrated in Jerusalem.

1152.event: Frederick I Barbarossa is elected King of Germany.
Annulment of the marriage of King Louis VII of France and Queen Eleanor of Aquitaine.
The future Henry II of England marries Eleanor of Aquitaine. He would become king two years later, after the death of his cousin once removed King Stephen of England.

1153.event: Malcolm IV becomes King of Scotland.
Baldwin III of Jerusalem takes control of the Kingdom of Jerusalem from his mother Melisende, and also captures Ascalon.

1154.event: Henry II of England is crowned at Westminster Abbey.

1156.event: Finnish peasant Lalli kills English clergyman Henry, the Bishop of Turku, on the ice of Lake Köyliö.

1157.event: Albert I of Brandenburg, also called The Bear (Ger: Albrecht der Bär), becomes the founder of the Margraviate of Brandenburg, Germany and the first margrave.
The Battle of Grathe Heath ends the Danish Civil War.

1158.event: Vladislaus II, Duke of Bohemia becomes King of Bohemia.
German city Munich (München) is first mentioned as forum apud Munichen in the Augsburg arbitration by Holy Roman Emperor Friedrich I.
The city of Munich is founded by Henry the Lion on the banks of the river Isar.

1160.event: Louis VII of France marries Adela of Champagne.

1161.event: Battle of Caishi: A Song dynasty fleet fights a naval engagement with Jin dynasty ships on the Yangtze river during the Jin-Song Wars.
Jin-Song wars: Military officers conspire against the emperor Wanyan Liang of the Jin dynasty after a military defeat at the Battle of Caishi, and assassinate the emperor at his camp.

1164.event: Battle of Harim: Nur ad-Din Zangi defeats the Crusader armies of the County of Tripoli and the Principality of Antioch.

1167.event: Battle of Monte Porzio: A Roman army supporting Pope Alexander III is defeated by Christian of Buch and Rainald of Dassel.
Sicilian Chancellor Stephen du Perche moves the royal court to Messina to prevent a rebellion.

1169.event: A strong earthquake strikes the Ionian coast of Sicily, causing tens of thousands of injuries and deaths, especially in Catania.
Saladin becomes the emir of Egypt.
Norman mercenaries land at Bannow Bay in Leinster, marking the beginning of the Norman invasion of Ireland.

Battle of the Blacks: Uprising by the black African forces of the Fatimid army, along with a number of Egyptian emirs and commoners, against Saladin. The uprising is defeated after two days, consolidating Saladin's position as master of Egypt.

1170.event: The Kingdom of Dublin falls to Norman invaders.

Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, is assassinated inside Canterbury Cathedral by followers of King Henry II; he subsequently becomes a saint and martyr in the Anglican Communion and the Catholic Church.

1172.event: Henry the Young King and Margaret of France are crowned junior king and queen of England.

1173.event: Construction of the campanile of the Cathedral of Pisa (now known as the Leaning Tower of Pisa) begins; it will take two centuries to complete.
The widow Stamira sacrifices herself in order to raise the siege of Ancona by the forces of Emperor Frederick Barbarossa.

1174.event: Baldwin IV, 13, becomes King of Jerusalem, with Raymond III, Count of Tripoli as regent and William of Tyre as chancellor.
William I of Scotland, a key rebel in the Revolt of 1173-74, is captured at Alnwick by forces loyal to Henry II of England.

1176.event: The Hashshashin (Assassins) attempt to assassinate Saladin near Aleppo.
Battle of Legnano: The Lombard League defeats Emperor Frederick I.
The Battle of Myriokephalon is the last attempt by the Byzantine Empire to recover central Anatolia from the Seljuk Turks.

1177.event: Baldwin IV of Jerusalem and Raynald of Châtillon defeat Saladin at the Battle of Montgisard.

1178.event: Five Canterbury monks see an event believed to have been the formation of the Giordano Bruno crater on the moon. It is believed that the current oscillations of the Moon's distance from the Earth (on the order of meters) are a result of this collision.

1179.event: The Battle of Kalvskinnet takes place outside Nidaros (now Trondheim), Norway. Earl Erling Skakke is killed, and the battle changes the tide of the civil wars.
Philip II is crowned as 'King of France'.

1180.event: Emperor Antoku accedes to the throne of Japan.
First Battle of Uji, starting the Genpei War in Japan.
Genpei War: Battle of Ishibashiyama in Japan.
Philip Augustus becomes king of France at the age of fifteen.

1183.event: Taira no Munemori and the Taira clan take the young Emperor Antoku and the three sacred treasures and flee to western Japan to escape pursuit by the Minamoto clan.
Genpei War: The Battle of Mizushima takes place off the Japanese coast, where Minamoto no Yoshinaka's invasion force is intercepted and defeated by the Taira clan.

1184.event: The naval Battle of Fimreite is won by the Birkebeiner pretender Sverre Sigurdsson. Sigurdsson takes the Norwegian throne and King Magnus V of Norway is killed.

1185.event: Battle of Yashima: the Japanese forces of the Taira clan are defeated by the Minamoto clan.
The cave city of Vardzia is consecrated by Queen Tamar of Georgia.
Sack of Thessalonica by the Normans.
Isaac II Angelos kills Stephen Hagiochristophorites and then appeals to the people, resulting in the revolt that deposes Andronikos I Komnenos and places Isaac on the throne of the Byzantine Empire.
The Uprising of Asen and Peter begins on the feast day of St. Demetrius of Thessaloniki and ends with the creation of the Second Bulgarian Empire.

1186.event: Henry VI, the son and heir of the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick I, marries Constance of Sicily.

Georgenberg Pact: Ottokar IV, Duke of Styria and Leopold V, Duke of Austria sign a heritage agreement in which Ottokar gives his duchy to Leopold and to his son Frederick under the stipulation that Austria and Styria would henceforth remain undivided.

1187.event: The Crusades: Battle of Hattin: Saladin defeats Guy of Lusignan, King of Jerusalem.
Saladin begins the Siege of Jerusalem.

1189.event: Richard I of England officially invested as Duke of Normandy.
Friedrich Barbarossa arrives at Niš, the capital of Serbian King Stefan Nemanja, during the Third Crusade.
Third Crusade: The Crusaders begin the Siege of Acre under Guy of Lusignan.
Richard I of England (a.k.a. Richard "the Lionheart") is crowned at Westminster.

1190.event: Massacre of Jews at Clifford's Tower, York.
Third Crusade: Frederick I Barbarossa drowns in the river Saleph while leading an army to Jerusalem.
Conrad of Montferrat becomes King of Jerusalem upon his marriage to Isabella I of Jerusalem.

1191.event: Richard I of England marries Berengaria of Navarre in Cyprus; she is crowned Queen consort of England the same day.
Richard I arrives in Acre, beginning the Third Crusade.
Third Crusade: Saladin's garrison surrenders to Philip Augustus, ending the two-year siege of Acre.
Richard I of England initiates the Massacre at Ayyadieh, leaving 2,600–3,000 Muslim hostages dead.
Third Crusade: Battle of Arsuf: Richard I of England defeats Saladin at Arsuf.

1192.event: Assassination of Conrad of Montferrat (Conrad I), King of Jerusalem, in Tyre, two days after his title to the throne is confirmed by election. The killing is carried out by Hashshashin.
Minamoto no Yoritomo becomes Sei-i Taishōgun and the de facto ruler of Japan. (Traditional Japanese date: the 12th day of the seventh month in the third year of the Kenkyū (建久) era).
The Treaty of Jaffa is signed between Richard I of England and Saladin, leading to the end of the Third Crusade.
Richard I of England is captured and imprisoned by Leopold V of Austria on his way home to England after the Third Crusade.

1194.event: King Richard I of England gives Portsmouth its first Royal Charter.
Sverre is crowned King of Norway, leading to his excommunication by the Catholic Church and civil war.
Palermo is conquered by Henry VI, Holy Roman Emperor.

1195.event: Battle of Alarcos: Almohad forces defeat the Castilian army of Alfonso VIII and force its retreat to Toledo.

1198.event: Philip of Swabia, Prince of Hohenstaufen, is crowned King of Germany (King of the Romans)

1199.event: King Richard I of England is wounded by a crossbow bolt while fighting in France, leading to his death on April 6.
John is crowned King of England.

1200.event: King John of England and King Philip II of France sign the Treaty of Le Goulet.
King John of England, signer of the first Magna Carta, marries Isabella of Angoulême in Angoulême Cathedral.
Isabella of Angoulême is crowned Queen consort of England.

1201.event: Attempted usurpation by John Komnenos the Fat for the throne of Alexios III Angelos.

1202.event: Georgian-Seljuk wars: At the Battle of Basian the Kingdom of Georgia defeats the Sultanate of Rum.
Fourth Crusade: Despite letters from Pope Innocent III forbidding it and threatening excommunication, Catholic crusaders begin a siege of Zara (now Zadar, Croatia).

1203.event: The Fourth Crusade assaults Constantinople. The Byzantine emperor Alexios III Angelos flees from his capital into exile.
Isaac II Angelos, restored Byzantine Emperor, declares his son Alexios IV Angelos co-emperor after pressure from the forces of the Fourth Crusade.

1204.event: The Siege of Château Gaillard ends in a French victory over King John of England, who loses control of Normandy to King Philip II Augustus.
The Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade breach the walls of Constantinople and enter the city, which they completely occupy the following day.
Constantinople falls to the Crusaders of the Fourth Crusade, temporarily ending the Byzantine Empire.
Having been elected on May 9, Baldwin IX, Count of Flanders is crowned as the first Emperor of the Latin Empire.

1205.event: Philip of Swabia undergoes a second coronation as King of the Romans.

1206.event: Michael IV Autoreianos is appointed Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople.

1207.event: Terra Mariana, eventually comprising present-day Latvia and Estonia, is established.
King John of England expels Canterbury monks for supporting Archbishop Stephen Langton.

1208.event: The Battle of Lena takes place between King Sverker II of Sweden and his rival, Prince Eric, whose victory puts him on the throne as King Eric X of Sweden.

1209.event: Massacre at Béziers: The first major military action of the Albigensian Crusade.
Otto IV is crowned Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire by Pope Innocent III.

1210.event: Pope Innocent III excommunicates Holy Roman Emperor Otto IV.

1211.event: Battle of the Rhyndacus: The Latin emperor Henry of Flanders defeats the Nicaean emperor Theodore I Laskaris.

1212.event: The most severe of several early fires of London burns most of the city to the ground.

Battle of Las Navas de Tolosa: After Pope Innocent III calls European knights to a crusade, forces of Kings Alfonso VIII of Castile, Sancho VII of Navarre, Peter II of Aragon and Afonso II of Portugal defeat those of the Berber Muslim leader Almohad, thus marking a significant turning point in the Reconquista and in the medieval history of Spain.
The Golden Bull of Sicily is issued to confirm the hereditary royal title in Bohemia for the Přemyslid dynasty.

1213.event: Albigensian Crusade: Simon de Montfort, 5th Earl of Leicester, defeats Peter II of Aragon at the Battle of Muret.

1214.event: During the Anglo-French War (1213-1214), an English invasion force led by John, King of England, lands at La Rochelle in France.
Battle of Bouvines: Philip II of France decisively defeats Imperial, English and Flemish armies, effectively ending John of England's Angevin Empire.
The port city of Sinope surrenders to the Seljuq Turks.

1215.event: Rebel barons renounce their allegiance to King John of England — part of a chain of events leading to the signing of the Magna Carta.
Zhongdu (now Beijing), then under the control of the Jurchen ruler Emperor Xuanzong of Jin, is captured by the Mongols under Genghis Khan, ending the Battle of Zhongdu.
King John of England puts his seal to Magna Carta.
Pope Innocent III issues a bull declaring Magna Carta invalid.
The Fourth Council of the Lateran meets, defining the doctrine of transubstantiation, the process by which bread and wine are, by that doctrine, said to transform into the body and blood of Christ.

1216.event: First Barons' War: Prince Louis of France takes the city of Winchester, abandoned by John, King of England, and soon conquers over half of the kingdom.
King John of England dies at Newark-on-Trent and is succeeded by his nine-year-old son Henry.
Pope Honorius III approves the Dominican Order through the papal bull of confirmation Religiosam vitam.

1217.event: The Second Battle of Lincoln is fought near Lincoln, England, resulting in the defeat of Prince Louis of France by William Marshal, 1st Earl of Pembroke.
Livonian Crusade: The Estonian leader Lembitu and Livonian leader Kaupo the Accursed are killed in the Battle of St. Matthew's Day.

The Charter of the Forest is sealed at St Paul's Cathedral, London by King Henry III, acting under the regency of William Marshall, 1st Earl of Pembroke which re-establishes for free men rights of access to the royal forest that had been eroded by William the Conqueror and his heirs.

1218.event: The Fifth Crusade leaves Acre for Egypt.
Al-Kamil becomes sultan of the Ayyubid dynasty.

1219.event: Northern Crusades: Danish victory at the Battle of Lindanise (modern-day Tallinn) establishes the Danish Duchy of Estonia.

1220.event: Sweden is defeated by Estonian tribes in the Battle of Lihula.

1223.event: Mongol invasion of the Cumans: Battle of the Kalka River: Mongol armies of Genghis Khan led by Subutai defeat Kievan Rus' and Cumans.
Louis VIII becomes King of France upon the death of his father, Philip II.

1225.event: Treaty of San Germano is signed at San Germano between Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II and Pope Gregory IX. A Dominican named Guala is responsible for the negotiations.
The Lý dynasty of Vietnam ends after 216 years by the enthronement of the boy emperor Trần Thái Tông, husband of the last Lý monarch, Lý Chiêu Hoàng, starting the Trần dynasty.

1226.event: Khwarazmian sultan Jalal ad-Din conquers the Georgian capital of Tbilisi.
The first recorded instance of the Catholic practice of perpetual Eucharistic adoration formally begins in Avignon, France.

1227.event: Investiture Controversy: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, is excommunicated by Pope Gregory IX for his failure to participate in the Crusades.
Gąsawa massacre: At an assembly of Piast dukes at Gąsawa, Polish Prince Leszek the White,  Duke Henry the Bearded and others are attacked by assassins while bathing.

1228.event: The canonization of Saint Francis of Assisi
Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II lands in Acre, Israel, and starts the Sixth Crusade, which results in a peaceful restoration of the Kingdom of Jerusalem.

1229.event: The Sixth Crusade: Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, signs a ten-year truce with al-Kamil, regaining Jerusalem, Nazareth, and Bethlehem with neither military engagements nor support from the papacy.
Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor, declares himself King of Jerusalem in the Sixth Crusade.
Battle of Portopí: The Aragonese army under the command of James I of Aragon disembarks at Santa Ponça, Majorca, with the purpose of conquering the island.
Ögedei Khan is proclaimed Khagan of the Mongol Empire in Kodoe Aral, Khentii: Mongolia.
James I the Conqueror, King of Aragon, enters Medina Mayurqa (now known as Palma, Spain), thus consummating the Christian reconquest of the island of Majorca.

1230.event: Bulgarian Tsar Ivan Asen II defeats Theodore of Epirus in the Battle of Klokotnitsa.
William de Braose is hanged by Prince Llywelyn the Great.
The Siege of Jaén begins, in the context of the Spanish Reconquista.

1232.event: Mongol-Jin War: The Mongols begin their siege on Kaifeng, the capital of the Jin dynasty.

The Spanish town of Arjona declares independence and names its native Muhammad ibn Yusuf as ruler. This marks the Muhammad's first rise to prominence; he would later establish the Nasrid Emirate of Granada, the last independent Muslim state in Spain.

1233.event: Mongol-Jin War: The Mongols entered Kaifeng after a successful siege and began looting in the fallen capital of the Jin dynasty.

1236.event: King Henry III of England marries Eleanor of Provence.
The Samogitians defeat the Livonian Brothers of the Sword in the Battle of Saule.

1237.event: Spanish Reconquista: The Battle of the Puig between the Moorish forces of Taifa of Valencia against the Kingdom of Aragon culminates in an Aragonese victory.
England and Scotland sign the Treaty of York, establishing the location of their common border.
The city of Ryazan is sacked by the Mongol army of Batu Khan.

1238.event: The Mongols burn the Russian city of Vladimir.

The Battle of the Sit River is fought in the northern part of the present-day Yaroslavl Oblast of Russia between the Mongol hordes of Batu Khan and the Russians under Yuri II of Vladimir-Suzdal during the Mongol invasion of Rus'.
King James I of Aragon conquers Valencia from the Moors. Shortly thereafter, he proclaims himself king of Valencia.
James I of Aragon founds the Kingdom of Valencia.

1240.event: At the instigation of Louis IX of France, an inter-faith debate, known as the Disputation of Paris, starts between a Christian monk and four rabbis.
Swedish-Novgorodian Wars: A Novgorodian army led by Alexander Nevsky defeats the Swedes in the Battle of the Neva.
Mongol invasion of Rus': Kyiv under Daniel of Galicia and Voivode Dmytro falls to the Mongols under Batu Khan.

1241.event: First Mongol invasion of Poland: Mongols overwhelm Polish armies in Kraków in the Battle of Chmielnik and plunder the city.
Battle of Liegnitz: Mongol forces defeat the Polish and German armies.
Batu Khan defeats Béla IV of Hungary at the Battle of Mohi.

1242.event: During the Battle on the Ice of Lake Peipus, Russian forces, led by Alexander Nevsky, rebuff an invasion attempt by the Teutonic Knights.
Following the Disputation of Paris, twenty-four carriage loads of Jewish religious manuscripts were burnt in Paris.
Battle of Taillebourg: Louis IX of France puts an end to the revolt of his vassals Henry III of England and Hugh X of Lusignan.

1243.event: Mongols defeat the Seljuk Turks at the Battle of Köse Dağ.

1244.event: Over 200 Cathars who refuse to recant are burnt to death after the Fall of Montségur.
Siege of Jerusalem: The city's citadel, the Tower of David, surrenders to Khwarezmian Empire.
Pope Innocent IV arrives at Lyon for the First Council of Lyon.

1245.event: Thomas, the first known Bishop of Finland, is granted resignation after confessing to torture and forgery.

1246.event: Henry Raspe is elected anti-king of the Kingdom of Germany in opposition to Conrad IV.
With the death of Frederick II, Duke of Austria, the Babenberg dynasty ends in Austria.

1248.event: The foundation stone of Cologne Cathedral, built to house the relics of the Three Wise Men, is laid. (Construction is eventually completed in 1880.)
The Dutch city of Ommen receives city rights and fortification rights from Otto III, the Archbishop of Utrecht.
Conquest of Seville by Christian troops under King Ferdinand III of Castile.
An overnight landslide on the north side of Mont Granier, one of the largest historical rockslope failures ever recorded in Europe, destroys five villages.

1249.event: Andrew of Longjumeau is dispatched by Louis IX of France as his ambassador to meet with the Khagan of the Mongol Empire.
Coronation of Alexander III as King of Scots.

1250.event: Seventh Crusade: Crusaders engage Ayyubid forces in the Battle of Al Mansurah.
Seventh Crusade: Ayyubids of Egypt capture King Louis IX of France in the Battle of Fariskur.

1251.event: Celebrated by the Carmelite Order-but doubted by modern historians-as the day when Saint Simon Stock had a vision of the Virgin Mary.

1252.event: Pope Innocent IV issues the papal bull ad extirpanda, which authorizes, but also limits, the torture of heretics in the Medieval Inquisition.
Alfonso X is proclaimed king of Castile and León.

1253.event: Nichiren, a Japanese Buddhist monk, propounds Namu Myōhō Renge Kyō for the very first time and declares it to be the essence of Buddhism, in effect founding Nichiren Buddhism.
Battle of West-Capelle: John I of Avesnes defeats Guy of Dampierre.
Mindaugas is crowned King of Lithuania.
Pope Innocent IV canonises Stanislaus of Szczepanów, killed by king Bolesław II.

1254.event: Serbian King Stefan Uroš I and the Republic of Venice sign a peace treaty.

1256.event: The Augustinian monastic order is constituted at the Lecceto Monastery when Pope Alexander IV issues a papal bull Licet ecclesiae catholicae.
Mongol forces under Hulagu enter and dismantle the Nizari Ismaili (Assassin) stronghold at Alamut Castle (in present-day Iran) as part of their offensive on Islamic southwest Asia.

1257.event: Richard of Cornwall, and his wife, Sanchia of Provence, are crowned King and Queen of the Germans at Aachen Cathedral.
Kraków, in Poland, receives city rights.

1258.event: First Mongol invasion of Đại Việt: Đại Việt defeats the Mongols at the battle of Đông Bộ Đầu, forcing the Mongols to withdraw from the country.
Mongol invasions: Baghdad falls to the Mongols, bringing the Islamic Golden Age to an end.
War of Saint Sabas: In the Battle of Acre, the Venetians defeat a larger Genoese fleet sailing to relieve Acre.

Regent George Mouzalon and his brothers are killed during a coup headed by the aristocratic faction under Michael VIII Palaiologos, paving the way for its leader to ultimately usurp the throne of the Empire of Nicaea.

1259.event: Michael VIII Palaiologos is proclaimed co-emperor of the Empire of Nicaea with his ward John IV Laskaris.

Kings Louis IX of France and Henry III of England agree to the Treaty of Paris, in which Henry renounces his claims to French-controlled territory on continental Europe (including Normandy) in exchange for Louis withdrawing his support for English rebels.

1260.event: Kublai Khan becomes ruler of the Mongol Empire.
The Livonian Order suffers its greatest defeat in the 13th century in the Battle of Durbe against the Grand Duchy of Lithuania
The Mamluks defeat the Mongols at the Battle of Ain Jalut in Palestine, marking their first decisive defeat and the point of maximum expansion of the Mongol Empire.
The Sienese Ghibellines, supported by the forces of Manfred, King of Sicily, defeat the Florentine Guelphs at Montaperti.
The Great Prussian Uprising among the old Prussians begins against the Teutonic Knights.
Chartres Cathedral is dedicated in the presence of King Louis IX of France.

1261.event: The city of Constantinople is recaptured by Nicaean forces under the command of Alexios Strategopoulos, re-establishing the Byzantine Empire.
Michael VIII Palaiologos is crowned as the first Byzantine emperor in fifty-seven years.
Pope Urban IV succeeds Pope Alexander IV, becoming the 182nd pope.
Eleven-year-old John IV Laskaris of the restored Eastern Roman Empire is deposed and blinded by orders of his co-ruler Michael VIII Palaiologos.

1262.event: Battle of Hausbergen between bourgeois militias and the army of the bishop of Strasbourg.

1263.event: The Battle of Largs is fought between Norwegians and Scots.

1264.event: In the conflict between King Henry III of England and his rebellious barons led by Simon de Montfort, King Louis IX of France issues the Mise of Amiens, a one-sided decision in favour of Henry that later leads to the Second Barons' War.
Battle of Lewes: Henry III of England is captured and forced to sign the Mise of Lewes, making Simon de Montfort the effective ruler of England.
The Parliament of Ireland meets at Castledermot in County Kildare, the first definitively known meeting of this Irish legislature.
Mudéjar revolt: Muslim rebel forces took the Alcázar of Jerez de la Frontera after defeating the Castilian garrison.
After tricking the Venetian galley fleet into sailing east to the Levant, the Genoese capture an entire Venetian trade convoy at the Battle of Saseno.
The Statute of Kalisz, guaranteeing Jews safety and personal liberties and giving battei din jurisdiction over Jewish matters, is promulgated by Bolesław the Pious, Duke of Greater Poland.

1265.event: The first English parliament to include not only Lords but also representatives of the major towns holds its first meeting in the Palace of Westminster, now commonly known as the "Houses of Parliament".
A draft Byzantine-Venetian treaty is concluded between Venetian envoys and Emperor Michael VIII Palaiologos, but is not ratified by Doge Reniero Zeno.

Second Barons' War: Battle of Evesham: The army of Prince Edward (the future king Edward I of England) defeats the forces of rebellious barons led by Simon de Montfort, 6th Earl of Leicester, killing de Montfort and many of his allies.

1266.event: Battle of Benevento: An army led by Charles, Count of Anjou, defeats a combined German and Sicilian force led by Manfred, King of Sicily. Manfred is killed in the battle and Pope Clement IV invests Charles as king of Sicily and Naples.
War of Saint Sabas: In the Battle of Trapani, the Venetians defeat a larger Genoese fleet, capturing all its ships.

1267.event: The Treaty of Montgomery recognises Llywelyn ap Gruffudd as Prince of Wales, but only as a vassal of King Henry III.

1268.event: The Battle of Wesenberg is fought between the Livonian Order and Dovmont of Pskov.
A five-year Byzantine-Venetian peace treaty is concluded between Venetian envoys and Emperor Michael VIII Palaiologos.
The Principality of Antioch, a crusader state, falls to the Mamluk Sultan Baibars in the Siege of Antioch.
The Battle of Tagliacozzo marks the fall of the Hohenstaufen family from the Imperial and Sicilian thrones, and leading to the new chapter of Angevin domination in Southern Italy.
Conradin is executed along with his companion Frederick I, Margrave of Baden by Charles I of Sicily.

1269.event: The present church building at Westminster Abbey is consecrated.

1270.event: Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeats the Livonian Order in the Battle of Karuse.
Yekuno Amlak takes the imperial throne of Ethiopia, restoring the Solomonic dynasty to power after a 100-year Zagwe interregnum.

Philip III, although suffering from dysentery, becomes King of France following the death of his father Louis IX, during the Eighth Crusade. His uncle, Charles I of Naples, is forced to begin peace negotiations with Muhammad I al-Mustansir, Hafsid Sultan of Tunis.
The Eighth Crusade ends by an agreement between Charles I of Anjou (replacing his deceased brother King Louis IX of France) and the Hafsid dynasty of Tunis, Tunisia.
The Nizari Ismaili garrison of Gerdkuh, Persia surrender after 17 years to the Mongols.

1271.event: In Syria, sultan Baibars conquers the Krak des Chevaliers.
Kublai Khan renames his empire "Yuan" (元 yuán), officially marking the start of the Yuan dynasty of Mongolia and China.

1272.event: While travelling during the Ninth Crusade, Prince Edward becomes King of England upon Henry III of England's death, but he will not return to England for nearly two years to assume the throne.

1274.event: In France, the Second Council of Lyon opens to regulate the election of the Pope.
Edward I of England returns from the Ninth Crusade and is crowned King seventeen days later.

1275.event: Traditional founding of the city of Amsterdam.

1276.event: Magnus Ladulås is crowned King of Sweden in Uppsala Cathedral.
While taking exile in Fuzhou, away from the advancing Mongol invaders, the remnants of the Song dynasty court hold the coronation ceremony for Emperor Duanzong.
Pope John XXI is elected Pope.

1277.event: The University of Paris issues the last in a series of condemnations of various philosophical and theological theses.
The Byzantine-Venetian treaty of 1277 is concluded, stipulating a two-year truce and renewing Venetian commercial privileges in the Byzantine Empire.
The Treaty of Aberconwy, a humiliating settlement forced on Llywelyn ap Gruffudd by King Edward I of England, brings a temporary end to the Welsh Wars.

1278.event: The naval Battle of Algeciras takes place in the context of the Spanish Reconquista resulting in a victory for the Emirate of Granada and the Maranid Dynasty over the Kingdom of Castile.
Spanish Reconquista: the forces of the Kingdom of Castile initiate the ultimately futile Siege of Algeciras against the Emirate of Granada.
Ladislaus IV of Hungary and Rudolf I of Germany defeat Ottokar II of Bohemia in the Battle on the Marchfeld near Dürnkrut in (then) Moravia.
Trần Thánh Tông, the second emperor of the Trần dynasty, decides to pass the throne to his crown prince Trần Khâm and take up the post of Retired Emperor.

1279.event: The Livonian Order is defeated in the Battle of Aizkraukle by the Grand Duchy of Lithuania.
A Mongol victory at the Battle of Yamen ends the Song dynasty in China.
The Nichiren Shōshū branch of Buddhism is founded in Japan.

1280.event: The Spanish Reconquista: In the Battle of Moclín the Emirate of Granada ambush a superior pursuing force, killing most of them in a military disaster for the Kingdom of Castile.

1281.event: Mongol invasion of Japan: The Mongolian fleet of Kublai Khan is destroyed by a "divine wind" for the second time in the Battle of Kōan.

1282.event: The people of Sicily rebel against the Angevin king Charles I, in what becomes known as the Sicilian Vespers.
Peter III of Aragon lands at Trapani to intervene in the War of the Sicilian Vespers.
Peter III of Aragon becomes the King of Sicily.
Pope Martin IV excommunicates King Peter III of Aragon.
Battle of Orewin Bridge: Llywelyn ap Gruffudd, the last native Prince of Wales, is killed at Cilmeri, near Builth Wells, in mid-Wales.

1283.event: Battle of the Gulf of Naples: Roger of Lauria, admiral to King Peter III of Aragon, destroys the Neapolitan fleet and captures Charles of Salerno.
Roger of Lauria, commanding the Aragonese fleet, defeats an Angevin fleet sent to put down a rebellion on Malta.

1284.event: The Statute of Rhuddlan incorporates the Principality of Wales into England.
The Republic of Pisa is defeated in the Battle of Meloria by the Republic of Genoa, thus losing its naval dominance in the Mediterranean.

1285.event: Second Mongol invasion of Vietnam: Forces led by Prince Trần Quang Khải of the Trần dynasty destroy most of the invading Mongol naval fleet in a battle at Chuong Duong.

1287.event: King Wareru founds the Hanthawaddy Kingdom, and proclaims independence from the Pagan Kingdom.
Kublai Khan defeats the force of Nayan and other traditionalist Borjigin princes in East Mongolia and Manchuria.
St. Lucia's flood: The Zuiderzee sea wall in the Netherlands collapses, killing over 50,000 people.

1288.event: Mongol invasions of Vietnam: Yuan forces are defeated by Trần forces in the Battle of Bach Dang in present-day northern Vietnam.
The Battle of Worringen ends the War of the Limburg Succession, with John I, Duke of Brabant, being one of the more important victors.

1290.event: King Edward I of England issues the Edict of Expulsion, banishing all Jews (numbering about 16,000) from England; this was Tisha B'Av on the Hebrew calendar, a day that commemorates many Jewish calamities.

1291.event: Scottish nobles recognize the authority of Edward I of England pending the selection of a king.
Fall of Acre, the end of Crusader presence in the Holy Land.
The Old Swiss Confederacy is formed with the signature of the Federal Charter.
The Republic of Venice enacts a law confining most of Venice's glassmaking industry to the "island of Murano".

1292.event: John Balliol becomes King of Scotland.

1293.event: King Sancho IV of Castile creates the Estudio de Escuelas de Generales in Alcalá de Henares.
An earthquake strikes Kamakura, Kanagawa, Japan, killing about 23,000.

Mongol invasion of Java was a punitive expedition against King Kertanegara of Singhasari, who had refused to pay tribute to the Yuan and maimed one of its ministers. However, it ended with failure for the Mongols. Regarded as establish City of Surabaya
Raden Wijaya is crowned as the first monarch of Majapahit kingdom of Java, taking the throne name Kertarajasa Jayawardhana.

1294.event: Temür, grandson of Kublai, is elected Khagan of the Mongols and Emperor of the Yuan dynasty with the reigning titles Oljeitu and Chengzong.
Saint Celestine V resigns the papacy after only five months to return to his previous life as an ascetic hermit.
Pope Boniface VIII is elected, replacing St. Celestine V, who had resigned.

1295.event: Przemysł II crowned king of Poland, following Ducal period. The white eagle is added to the Polish coat of arms.
The first treaty forming the Auld Alliance between Scotland and France against England is signed in Paris.

1296.event: Edward I sacks Berwick-upon-Tweed, during armed conflict between Scotland and England.
First War of Scottish Independence: John Balliol's Scottish army is defeated by an English army commanded by John de Warenne, 6th Earl of Surrey at the Battle of Dunbar.

1297.event: François Grimaldi, disguised as a monk, leads his men to capture the fortress protecting the Rock of Monaco, establishing his family as the rulers of Monaco.
Battle of Stirling Bridge: Scots jointly led by William Wallace and Andrew Moray defeat the English.

1298.event: Residents of Riga and Grand Duchy of Lithuania defeated the Livonian Order in the Battle of Turaida.
The Battle of Göllheim is fought between Albert I of Habsburg and Adolf of Nassau-Weilburg.
Wars of Scottish Independence: Battle of Falkirk: King Edward I of England and his longbowmen defeat William Wallace and his Scottish schiltrons outside the town of Falkirk.

1299.event: According to Edward Gibbon, Osman I invades the territory of Nicomedia for the first time, usually considered to be the founding day of the Ottoman state.

1300.event: The city of Bilbao is founded.

1301.event: Andrew III of Hungary dies, ending the Árpád dynasty in Hungary.
Edward of Caernarvon (later king Edward II of England) becomes the first English Prince of Wales.

1302.event: Dante Alighieri is condemned in absentia and exiled from Florence.
Bruges Matins, the nocturnal massacre of the French garrison in Bruges by members of the local Flemish militia.
Battle of the Golden Spurs (Guldensporenslag in Dutch): A coalition around the Flemish cities defeats the king of France's royal army.
Battle of Bapheus: Decisive Ottoman victory over the Byzantines opening up Bithynia for Turkish conquest.
The Byzantine-Venetian War comes to an end.
Pope Boniface VIII issues the Papal bull Unam sanctam, claiming spiritual supremacy for the papacy.

1303.event: The English are defeated at the Battle of Roslin, in the First War of Scottish Independence.
The Sapienza University of Rome is instituted by a bull of Pope Boniface VIII.
Chittorgarh falls to the Delhi Sultanate, after which thirty thousand Hindu inhabitants are killed.
Guillaume de Nogaret takes Pope Boniface VIII prisoner on behalf of Philip IV of France.

1304.event: Wars of Scottish Independence: Fall of Stirling Castle: King Edward I of England takes the stronghold using the War Wolf.
The Battle of Mons-en-Pévèle is fought to a draw between the French army and the Flemish militias.

1305.event: A peace treaty between the Flemish and the French is signed at Athis-sur-Orge.
Sir William Wallace is executed for high treason at Smithfield, London.

1306.event: In front of the high altar of Greyfriars Church in Dumfries, Robert the Bruce murders John Comyn, sparking the revolution in the Wars of Scottish Independence.
Robert the Bruce becomes King of Scots (Scotland).
The Earl of Pembroke's army defeats Bruce's Scottish army at the Battle of Methven.

1307.event: Külüg Khan is enthroned as Khagan of the Mongols and Wuzong of the Yuan.
Hundreds of the Knights Templar in France are arrested at dawn by King Philip the Fair, and later confess under torture to heresy.
Pope Clement V issues the papal bull Pastoralis Praeeminentiae which instructed all Christian monarchs in Europe to arrest all Templars and seize their assets.

1308.event: Pope Clement V pardons Jacques de Molay, the last Grand Master of the Knights Templar, absolving him of charges of heresy.
The reign of Emperor Hanazono of Japan begins.

1309.event: Pope Clement V imposes excommunication and interdiction on Venice, and a general prohibition of all commercial intercourse with Venice, which had seized on Ferrara, a papal fiefdom.
Henry VII is recognized King of the Romans by Pope Clement V.
The First Siege of Gibraltar takes place in the context of the Spanish Reconquista pitting the forces of the Kingdom of Castile against the Emirate of Granada resulting in a Castilian victory.

1310.event: The city of Rhodes surrenders to the forces of the Knights of St. John, completing their conquest of Rhodes. The knights establish their headquarters on the island and rename themselves the Knights of Rhodes.

1311.event: Battle of Halmyros: The Catalan Company defeats Walter V, Count of Brienne to take control of the Duchy of Athens, a Crusader state in Greece.
Duccio's Maestà, a seminal artwork of the early Italian Renaissance, is unveiled and installed in Siena Cathedral in Siena, Italy.
The peerage and clergy restrict the authority of English kings with the Ordinances of 1311.
The Council of Vienne convenes for the first time.

1312.event: Vox in excelso: Pope Clement V dissolves the Order of the Knights Templar.
At the Battle of Rozgony, King Charles I of Hungary wins a decisive victory over the family of Palatine Amade Aba.

1313.event: King Thihathu founds the Pinya Kingdom as the de jure successor state of the Pagan Kingdom.
Louis the Bavarian defeats his cousin Frederick I of Austria at the Battle of Gammelsdorf.

1314.event: Jacques de Molay, the 23rd and final Grand Master of the Knights Templar, is burned at the stake.
First War of Scottish Independence: The Battle of Bannockburn (south of Stirling) begins.
First War of Scottish Independence: The Battle of Bannockburn concludes with a decisive victory by Scottish forces led by Robert the Bruce.
King Haakon V of Norway moves the capital from Bergen to Oslo.

1315.event: Enguerrand de Marigny is hanged at the instigation of Charles, Count of Valois.
The Great Famine of Europe becomes so dire that even the king of England has difficulties buying bread for himself and his entourage.

Battle of Montecatini: The army of the Republic of Pisa, commanded by Uguccione della Faggiuola, wins a decisive victory against the joint forces of the Kingdom of Naples and the Republic of Florence despite being outnumbered.
Growth of the Old Swiss Confederacy: The Schweizer Eidgenossenschaft ambushes the army of Leopold I in the Battle of Morgarten.

1316.event: The Battle of Picotin, between Ferdinand of Majorca and the forces of Matilda of Hainaut, ends in victory for Ferdinand.
The Burgundian and Majorcan claimants of the Principality of Achaea meet in the Battle of Manolada.
The Second Battle of Athenry takes place near Athenry during the Bruce campaign in Ireland.

1317.event: The "Nyköping Banquet": King Birger of Sweden treacherously seizes his two brothers Valdemar, Duke of Finland and Eric, Duke of Södermanland, who were subsequently starved to death in the dungeon of Nyköping Castle.

1319.event: A Knights Hospitaller fleet scores a crushing victory over an Aydinid fleet off Chios.

1320.event: Duke Wladyslaw Lokietek becomes king of Poland.
The Scots reaffirm their independence by signing the Declaration of Arbroath.
In the Battle of Saint George, the Byzantines under Andronikos Asen ambush and defeat the forces of the Principality of Achaea, securing possession of Arcadia.

1322.event: Stephen Uroš III is crowned King of Serbia, having defeated his half-brother Stefan Konstantin in battle. His son is crowned "young king" in the same ceremony.
The central tower of Ely Cathedral falls on the night of 12th–13th.
Louis IV, Holy Roman Emperor, defeats Frederick I of Austria in the Battle of Mühldorf.
Mladen II Šubić of Bribir is deposed as the Croatian Ban after the Battle of Bliska.
Robert the Bruce of Scotland defeats King Edward II of England at the Battle of Old Byland, forcing Edward to accept Scotland's independence.

1323.event: Treaty of Paris of 1323 is signed.
The Treaty of Nöteborg between Sweden and Novgorod Republic is signed, regulating the border between the two countries for the first time.

1325.event: Alfonso IV becomes King of Portugal.
Ibn Battuta begins his travels, leaving his home in Tangiers to travel to Mecca (gone 24 years).

1326.event: The Treaty of Novgorod delineates borders between Russia and Norway in Finnmark.

1327.event: The teenaged Edward III is crowned King of England, but the country is ruled by his mother Queen Isabella and her lover Roger Mortimer.
First War of Scottish Independence: James Douglas leads a raid into Weardale and almost kills Edward III of England.

1328.event: Wars of Scottish Independence end: By the Treaty of Edinburgh-Northampton, England recognises Scotland as an independent state.
Antipope Nicholas V, a claimant to the papacy, is consecrated in Rome by the Bishop of Venice.
William of Ockham, the Franciscan Minister-General Michael of Cesena, and two other Franciscan leaders secretly leave Avignon, fearing a death sentence from Pope John XXII.
Philip VI is crowned King of France.
The House of Gonzaga seizes power in the Duchy of Mantua, and will rule until 1708.
Battle of Cassel: French troops stop an uprising of Flemish farmers.

1329.event: Pope John XXII issues his In Agro Dominico condemning some writings of Meister Eckhart as heretical.
The Battle of Pelekanon results in a Byzantine defeat by the Ottoman Empire.
Quilon, the first Indian Christian Diocese, is erected by Pope John XXII; the French-born Jordanus is appointed the first Bishop.

1330.event: At the Battle of Posada, Basarab I of Wallachia defeats the Hungarian army of Charles I Robert.
Battle of Posada ends: Wallachian Voievode Basarab I defeats the Hungarian army by ambush.

1331.event: King Stefan Uroš III, after months of anarchy, surrenders to his son and rival Stefan Dušan, who succeeds as King of Serbia.
Stefan Dušan declares himself king of Serbia.
The Battle of Płowce is fought, between the Kingdom of Poland and the Teutonic Order. The Poles are defeated but their leaders escape capture.

1332.event: Amda Seyon I, Emperor of Ethiopia begins his campaigns in the southern Muslim provinces.
Wars of Scottish Independence: Battle of Dupplin Moor: Scots under Domhnall II, Earl of Mar are routed by Edward Balliol.
Rinchinbal Khan becomes the Khagan of the Mongols and Emperor of the Yuan dynasty, reigning for only 53 days.

1333.event: Wars of Scottish Independence: Battle of Halidon Hill: The English win a decisive victory over the Scots.
The River Arno floods causing massive damage in Florence as recorded by the Florentine chronicler Giovanni Villani.

1334.event: The bishop of Florence blesses the first foundation stone for the new campanile (bell tower) of the Florence Cathedral, designed by the artist Giotto di Bondone.
Cardinal Jacques Fournier, a Cistercian monk, is elected Pope Benedict XII.

1335.event: At the congress of Visegrád Charles I of Hungary mediates a reconciliation between two neighboring monarchs, John of Bohemia and Casimir III of Poland.

1336.event: Four thousand defenders of Pilenai commit mass suicide rather than be taken captive by the Teutonic Knights.

1337.event: Edward, the Black Prince is made Duke of Cornwall, the first Duchy in England.

1338.event: The Battle of Arnemuiden, in which a French force defeats the English, is the first naval battle of the Hundred Years' War and the first naval battle in which gunpowder artillery is used.

1339.event: The Milanese army and the St. George's (San Giorgio) Mercenaries of Lodrisio Visconti clash in the Battle of Parabiago; Visconti is defeated.

1340.event: Hundred Years' War: Battle of Sluys: The French fleet is almost completely destroyed by the English fleet commanded in person by King Edward III.
Reconquista: Portuguese and Castilian forces halt a Muslim invasion at the Battle of Río Salado.

1341.event: The Byzantine civil war of 1341-1347 formally begins with the proclamation of John VI Kantakouzenos as Byzantine Emperor.

1342.event: St. Mary Magdalene's flood is the worst such event on record for central Europe.
The Siege of Algeciras commences during the Spanish Reconquista.

1343.event: Pope Clement VI issues the papal bull Unigenitus to justify the power of the pope and the use of indulgences. Nearly 200 years later, Martin Luther would protest this.
Arnošt of Pardubice becomes the last Bishop of Prague (3 March 1343 O.S.), and, a year later, the first Archbishop of Prague.
St. George's Night Uprising commences in the Duchy of Estonia.
After the execution of her husband, Jeanne de Clisson sells her estates and raises a force of men with which to attack French shipping and ports.
A tsunami, caused by an earthquake in the Tyrrhenian Sea, devastates Naples and the Maritime Republic of Amalfi, among other places.

1344.event: The Siege of Algeciras, one of the first European military engagements where gunpowder was used, comes to an end.
The lower town of Smyrna is captured by Crusaders in response to Aydınid piracy.

1345.event: The megas doux Alexios Apokaukos, chief minister of the Byzantine Empire, is lynched by political prisoners.
Friso-Hollandic Wars: Frisians defeat Holland in the Battle of Warns.

1346.event: Stefan Dušan, "the Mighty", is crowned Emperor of the Serbs at Skopje, his empire occupying much of the Balkans.
Charles IV, Count of Luxembourg and King of Bohemia, is elected King of the Romans.
Jaume Ferrer sets out from Majorca for the "River of Gold", the Senegal River.
At the Battle of Crécy, an English army easily defeats a French one twice its size.
The English capture King David II of Scotland at Neville's Cross and imprison him for eleven years.

1347.event: The Byzantine civil war of 1341-47 ends with a power-sharing agreement between John VI Kantakouzenos and John V Palaiologos.

1348.event: A strong earthquake strikes the South Alpine region of Friuli in modern Italy, causing considerable damage to buildings as far away as Rome.
Holy Roman Emperor Charles IV charters Prague University.
The founding of the Order of the Garter by King Edward III is announced on St. George's Day.
Czech king Karel IV founds the Charles University in Prague, which was later named after him and was the first university in Central Europe.
Pope Clement VI issues a papal bull protecting the Jews accused of having caused the Black Death.
The anti-royalist Union of Valencia attacks the Jews of Murviedro on the pretext that they are serfs of the King of Valencia and thus "royalists".

1349.event: The Jewish population of Basel, believed by the residents to be the cause of the ongoing Black Death, is rounded up and incinerated.
Several hundred Jews are burned to death by mobs while the remaining Jews are forcibly removed from Strasbourg.
The rule of the Bavand dynasty in Mazandaran is brought to an end by the murder of Hasan II.
Dušan's Code, the constitution of the Serbian Empire, is enacted by Dušan the Mighty.
Six thousand Jews are killed in Mainz after being blamed for the bubonic plague.

1350.event: Battle of Winchelsea (or Les Espagnols sur Mer): The English naval fleet under King Edward III defeats a Castilian fleet of 40 ships.

1351.event: Combat of the Thirty: Thirty Breton knights call out and defeat thirty English knights.

1352.event: War of the Breton Succession: Anglo-Bretons defeat the French in the Battle of Mauron.

1355.event: Charles IV of Bohemia is crowned with the Iron Crown of Lombardy as King of Italy in Milan.
The St Scholastica Day riot breaks out in Oxford, England, leaving 63 scholars and perhaps 30 locals dead in two days.
King Tvrtko I of Bosnia writes In castro nostro Vizoka vocatum from the Old town of Visoki.

1356.event: Edward Balliol surrenders his claim to the Scottish throne to Edward III in exchange for an English pension.
Battle of Poitiers: An English army under the command of Edward, the Black Prince defeats a French army and captures King John II.
Basel earthquake, the most significant historic seismological event north of the Alps, destroys the town of Basel, Switzerland.

1357.event: Emperor Charles IV assists in laying the foundation stone of Charles Bridge in Prague.

1358.event: The Republic of Ragusa is founded.

1359.event: Francesco II Ordelaffi of Forlì surrenders to the Papal commander Gil de Albornoz.
Peter I of Cyprus ascends the throne of Cyprus after his father, Hugh IV of Cyprus, abdicates.

1360.event: Treaty of Brétigny drafted between King Edward III of England and King John II of France (the Good).
Muhammed VI becomes the tenth Nasrid king of Granada after killing his brother-in-law Ismail II.
The Treaty of Brétigny is ratified, marking the end of the first phase of the Hundred Years' War.

1361.event: The Battle of Linuesa is fought in the context of the Spanish Reconquista between the forces of the Emirate of Granada and the combined army of the Kingdom of Castile and of Jaén resulting in a Castilian victory.

1362.event: Saint Marcellus's flood kills at least 25,000 people on the shores of the North Sea.
Saint Marcellus' flood kills at least 25,000 people on the shores of the North Sea.
Kaunas Castle falls to the Teutonic Order after a month-long siege.

1363.event: The five-week Battle of Lake Poyang begins, in which the forces of two Chinese rebel leaders (Chen Youliang and Zhu Yuanzhang) meet to decide who will supplant the Yuan dynasty.
Battle of Lake Poyang: In one of the largest naval battles in history, Zhu Yuanzhang's rebels defeat rival Chen Youliang.

1364.event: Jagiellonian University, the oldest university in Poland, is founded in Kraków.
Troops of the Republic of Pisa and the Republic of Florence clash in the Battle of Cascina.
Hundred Years' War: English forces defeat the French in Brittany, ending the War of the Breton Succession.

1365.event: Albert III of Mecklenburg (King Albert of Sweden) grants city rights to Ulvila (Swedish: Ulvsby).
The Ava Kingdom and the royal city of Ava (Inwa) founded by King Thado Minbya.

1367.event: Swa Saw Ke becomes king of Ava

1368.event: In a coronation ceremony, Zhu Yuanzhang ascends the throne of China as the Hongwu Emperor, initiating Ming dynasty rule over China that would last for three centuries.

1370.event: Northern Crusades: Grand Duchy of Lithuania and the Teutonic Knights meet in the Battle of Rudau.
Brussels massacre: Between six and twenty Jews are murdered and the rest of the Jewish community is banished from Brussels, Belgium, for allegedly desecrating consecrated Host.
Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor, grants city privileges to Karlovy Vary.

1371.event: Robert II becomes King of Scotland, beginning the Stuart dynasty.
Serbian-Turkish wars: Ottoman Turks fought against a Serbian army at the Battle of Maritsa.

1373.event: Julian of Norwich, a Christian mystic and anchoress, experiences the deathbed visions described in her Revelations of Divine Love.
Julian of Norwich has visions of Jesus while suffering from a life-threatening illness, visions which are later described and interpreted in her book Revelations of Divine Love.

1374.event: A sudden outbreak of St. John's Dance causes people in the streets of Aachen, Germany, to experience hallucinations and begin to jump and twitch uncontrollably until they collapse from exhaustion.

1377.event: Pope Gregory XI reaches Rome, after deciding to move the Papacy back to Rome from Avignon.
Pope Gregory XI issues five papal bulls to denounce the doctrines of English theologian John Wycliffe.
King Richard II of England is crowned.
Russian troops are defeated by forces of the Blue Horde Khan Arapsha in the Battle on Pyana River.
Tvrtko I is crowned the first king of Bosnia.

1378.event: Cardinal Robert of Geneva is elected as Pope Clement VII, beginning the Papal schism.

1380.event: Battle of Kulikovo: Russian forces defeat a mixed army of Tatars and Mongols, stopping their advance.

1381.event: Beginning of the Peasants' Revolt in England.
Peasants' Revolt: In England, rebels assemble at Blackheath, just outside London.
In England, the Peasants' Revolt, led by Wat Tyler, comes to a head, as rebels set fire to the Savoy Palace.
Richard II of England meets leaders of Peasants' Revolt at Mile End. The Tower of London is stormed by rebels who enter without resistance.
John Ball, a leader in the Peasants' Revolt, is hanged, drawn and quartered in the presence of King Richard II of England.

1382.event: Siege of Moscow: The Golden Horde led by Tokhtamysh lays siege to the capital of the Grand Duchy of Moscow.
Louis the Great's daughter, Mary, is crowned "king" of Hungary.

1383.event: The male line of the Portuguese House of Burgundy becomes extinct with the death of King Fernando, leaving only his daughter Beatrice. Rival claimants begin a period of civil war and disorder.

1384.event: Jadwiga is crowned King of Poland, although she is a woman.[citation needed]

1385.event: Portuguese Crisis of 1383-85: Battle of Aljubarrota: Portuguese forces commanded by John I of Portugal defeat the Castilian army of John I of Castile.

1386.event: King Charles III of Naples and Hungary is assassinated at Buda.
Władysław II Jagiełło (Jogaila) is crowned King of Poland.
Battle of the Vikhra River: The Principality of Smolensk is defeated by the Grand Duchy of Lithuania and becomes its vassal.
England and Portugal formally ratify their alliance with the signing of the Treaty of Windsor, making it the oldest diplomatic alliance in the world which is still in force.
The Old Swiss Confederacy makes great strides in establishing control over its territory by soundly defeating the Duchy of Austria in the Battle of Sempach.

Karl Topia, the ruler of Princedom of Albania forges an alliance with the Republic of Venice, committing to participate in all wars of the Republic and receiving coastal protection against the Ottomans in return.
The Universität Heidelberg holds its first lecture, making it the oldest German university.
Timur of Samarkand captures and sacks the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, taking King Bagrat V of Georgia captive.

1387.event: Battle of Castagnaro: Padua, led by John Hawkwood, is victorious over Giovanni Ordelaffi of Verona.
English victory over a Franco-Castilian-Flemish fleet in the Battle of Margate off the coast of Margate.

1388.event: Despite being outnumbered 16 to 1, forces of the Old Swiss Confederacy are victorious over the Archduchy of Austria in the Battle of Näfels.
During the Battle of Buyur Lake, General Lan Yu leads a Ming army forward to crush the Mongol hordes of Tögüs Temür, the Khan of Northern Yuan.
The Battle of Otterburn, a border skirmish between the Scottish and the English in Northern England, is fought near Otterburn.
Maria of Enghien sells the lordship of Argos and Nauplia to the Republic of Venice.

1389.event: Battle of Kosovo: The Ottoman Empire defeats Serbs and Bosnians.
France and England agree to the Truce of Leulinghem, inaugurating a 13-year peace, the longest period of sustained peace during the Hundred Years' War.

1390.event: Lithuanian Civil War (1389-92): The Teutonic Knights begin a five-week siege of Vilnius.
First trial for witchcraft in Paris leading to the death of three people.

1391.event: Tokhtamysh-Timur war: Battle of the Kondurcha River: Timur defeats Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde in present-day southeast Russia.
Konrad von Wallenrode becomes the 24th Grand Master of the Teutonic Order.

1392.event: Muhammed VII becomes the twelfth sultan of the Emirate of Granada.
Japanese Emperor Go-Kameyama abdicates in favor of rival claimant Go-Komatsu.

1395.event: Timur defeats Tokhtamysh of the Golden Horde at the Battle of the Terek River. The Golden Horde capital city, Sarai, is razed to the ground and Timur installs a puppet ruler on the throne.
Battle of Rovine: The Wallachians defeat an invading Ottoman army.

1396.event: Ottoman Emperor Bayezid I defeats a Christian army at the Battle of Nicopolis.

1397.event: The Kalmar Union is formed under the rule of Margaret I of Denmark.

1398.event: The Battle of Kellistown was fought on this day between the forces of the English led by Roger Mortimer, 4th Earl of March against the O'Byrnes and O'Tooles under the command of Art Óg mac Murchadha Caomhánach, the most powerful Chieftain in Leinster.
In the Treaty of Salynas, Lithuania cedes Samogitia to the Teutonic Knights.
Sultan Nasir-u Din Mehmud's armies in Delhi are defeated by Timur.

1399.event: Henry IV is proclaimed king of England.
Coronation of Henry IV of England at Westminster Abbey.
