Women's rights: US President Rutherford B. Hayes signs a bill allowing female attorneys to argue cases before the Supreme Court of the United States.
In Utica, New York, Frank Woolworth opens the first of many of five-and-dime Woolworth stores.

1880.event: Thomas Edison receives a patent for his incandescent lamp.
Seven people are killed in the Mussel Slough Tragedy, a gun battle in California.
War of the Pacific: The Battle of Arica, the assault and capture of Morro de Arica (Arica Cape), ends the Campaña del Desierto (Desert Campaign).
First performance of O Canada at the Congrès national des Canadiens-Français. The song would later become the national anthem of Canada.
Australian bushranger Ned Kelly is captured at Glenrowan.
France annexes Tahiti, renaming the independent Kingdom of Tahiti as "Etablissements de français de l'Océanie".
Second Anglo-Afghan War: Battle of Maiwand: Afghan forces led by Mohammad Ayub Khan defeat the British Army in battle near Maiwand, Afghanistan.
Construction of Cologne Cathedral, the most famous landmark in Cologne, Germany, is completed.
The army of Mohammad Ayub Khan is routed by the British at the Battle of Kandahar, ending the Second Anglo-Afghan War.

1881.event: Thomas Edison and Alexander Graham Bell form the Oriental Telephone Company.
The sentences of the trial of the warlocks of Chiloé are imparted.
The Canadian Pacific Railway is incorporated by Act of Parliament at Ottawa (44th Vic., c.1).
Cleopatra's Needle, a 3,500-year-old Ancient Egyptian obelisk is erected in Central Park, New York.
China and Russia sign the Sino-Russian Ili Treaty.
First Boer War: The Battle of Majuba Hill takes place.
Spelman College is founded in Atlanta, Georgia as the Atlanta Baptist Female Seminary, an institute of higher education for African-American women.
The Four Dead in Five Seconds Gunfight is fought in El Paso, Texas.
In Dodge City, Kansas, Bat Masterson fights his last gun battle.
Billy the Kid escapes from the Lincoln County jail in Mesilla, New Mexico.

1882.event: Queen Victoria narrowly escapes an assassination attempt by Roderick Maclean in Windsor.
Britain's first electric trams run in east London.
Robert Koch announces the discovery of Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium responsible for tuberculosis.
The Knights of Columbus is established.
American Old West: Robert Ford kills Jesse James.
French and Vietnamese troops clashed in Tonkin, when Commandant Henri Rivière seized the citadel of Hanoi with a small force of marine infantry.
Thomas Henry Burke and Lord Frederick Cavendish are stabbed to death by Fenian assassins in Phoenix Park, Dublin.
The United States Congress passes the Chinese Exclusion Act.
The Triple Alliance between the German Empire, Austria-Hungary and the Kingdom of Italy is formed.

1883.event: The Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act, establishing the United States Civil Service, is enacted by Congress.
The first electric lighting system employing overhead wires, built by Thomas Edison, begins service at Roselle, New Jersey.
Alabama becomes the first U.S. state to enact an anti-trust law.
The Paris Convention for the Protection of Industrial Property is signed.
Buffalo Bill's 1st Buffalo Bill's Wild West opens in Omaha, Nebraska.
Krakatoa begins to erupt; the volcano explodes three months later, killing more than 36,000 people.
The Brooklyn Bridge in New York City is opened to traffic after 14 years of construction.
Alexander III is crowned Tsar of Russia.
In New York City, a stampede on the recently opened Brooklyn Bridge killed twelve people.
The first regularly scheduled Orient Express departs Paris.

1884.event: The Fabian Society is founded in London, United Kingdom.
The first volume (A to Ant) of the Oxford English Dictionary is published.
More than sixty tornadoes strike the Southern United States, one of the largest tornado outbreaks in U.S. history.
The Siege of Khartoum begins. It lasts until January 26, 1885.

A mob in Cincinnati, Ohio, United States attacks members of a jury which had returned a verdict of manslaughter in what was seen as a clear case of murder; over the next few days the mob would riot and eventually destroy the courthouse.[citation needed]
Pope Leo XIII publishes the encyclical Humanum genus, condemning Freemasonry.
The arrival at Plymouth of Tāwhiao, King of Maoris, to claim the protection of Queen Victoria.
The first purpose-built roller coaster, LaMarcus Adna Thompson's "Switchback Railway", opens in New York's Coney Island amusement park.
Dow Jones & Company publishes its first stock average.

1885.event: Twenty-five nations adopt Sandford Fleming's proposal for standard time (and also, time zones).
Sino-French War: Beginning of the Battle of Núi Bop.
Sino-French War: French troops under General Oscar de Négrier defeat a numerically superior Qing force at Núi Bop in northern Vietnam.
A British force defeats a large Dervish army at the Battle of Abu Klea in the Sudan.
Troops loyal to The Mahdi conquer Khartoum, killing the Governor-General Charles George Gordon.
King Leopold II of Belgium establishes the Congo as a personal possession.
The first government-approved Japanese immigrants arrive in Hawaii.
Adventures of Huckleberry Finn by Mark Twain is published in the United States.
The newly completed Washington Monument is dedicated.
Sino-French War: French Army gains an important victory in the Battle of Đồng Đăng in the Tonkin region of Vietnam.

1886.event: Modern field hockey is born with the formation of The Hockey Association in England.
Karl Benz patents the first successful gasoline-driven automobile.

Charles Martin Hall produced the first samples of aluminium from the electrolysis of aluminium oxide, after several years of intensive work. He was assisted in this project by his older sister, Julia Brainerd Hall.
Geronimo, Apache warrior, surrenders to the U.S. Army, ending the main phase of the Apache Wars.
John Pemberton brews the first batch of Coca-Cola in a backyard in Atlanta.
William Ewart Gladstone introduces the first Irish Home Rule Bill into the British House of Commons.

Rallies are held throughout the United States demanding the eight-hour work day, culminating in the Haymarket affair in Chicago, in commemoration of which May 1 is celebrated as International Workers' Day in many countries.
Haymarket affair: A bomb is thrown at policemen trying to break up a labor rally in Chicago, United States, killing eight and wounding 60. The police fire into the crowd.
Pharmacist John Pemberton first sells a carbonated beverage named "Coca-Cola" as a patent medicine.
The pharmacist John Pemberton places his first advertisement for Coca-Cola, which appeared in The Atlanta Journal.

1887.event: The United States Senate allows the Navy to lease Pearl Harbor as a naval base.
In Punxsutawney, Pennsylvania, the first Groundhog Day is observed.
The Dawes Act authorizes the President of the United States to survey Native American tribal land and divide it into individual allotments.
The French Riviera is hit by a large earthquake, killing around 2,000.
Argonia, Kansas elects Susanna M. Salter as the first female mayor in the United States.
On Easter Sunday, Pope Leo XIII authorizes the establishment of the Catholic University of America.
A week after being arrested by the Prussian Secret Police, French police inspector Guillaume Schnaebelé is released on order of William I, German Emperor, defusing a possible war.
Herman Hollerith applies for US patent #395,781 for the 'Art of Compiling Statistics', which was his punched card calculator.
The Reinsurance Treaty between Germany and Russia is signed.
The Rocky Mountains Park Act becomes law in Canada creating the nation's first national park, Banff National Park.

1888.event: The National Geographic Society is founded in Washington, D.C.
The Great Blizzard of 1888 begins along the eastern seaboard of the United States, shutting down commerce and killing more than 400 people.
Start of the Anglo-Tibetan War of 1888.
The premiere of the very first Romani language operetta is staged in Moscow, Russia.
In England, The Football League, the world's oldest professional association football league, meets for the first time.
Jack the Ripper: The first of 11 unsolved brutal murders of women committed in or near the impoverished Whitechapel district in the East End of London, occurs.
In Southeast Asia, the North Borneo Chartered Company's territories become the British protectorate of North Borneo.
With the passage of the Lei Áurea ("Golden Law"), Empire of Brazil abolishes slavery.
Nikola Tesla delivers a lecture describing the equipment which will allow efficient generation and use of alternating currents to transmit electric power over long distances.
The Rio de la Plata earthquake takes place.

1889.event: Herman Hollerith is issued US patent #395,791 for the 'Art of Applying Statistics' — his punched card calculator.
The Coca-Cola Company, then known as the Pemberton Medicine Company, is incorporated in Atlanta.
Archduke Crown Prince Rudolf of Austria, heir to the Austro-Hungarian crown, is found dead with his mistress Baroness Mary Vetsera in the Mayerling.
US president Grover Cleveland signs a bill elevating the United States Department of Agriculture to a Cabinet-level agency.
Meiji Constitution of Japan is adopted.
Antonín Dvořák's Jakobín is premiered at National Theater in Prague
President Grover Cleveland signs a bill admitting North Dakota, South Dakota, Montana and Washington as U.S. states.
The Ahmadiyya Muslim Community is established by Mirza Ghulam Ahmad in Qadian, British India.
The Eiffel Tower is officially opened.
At noon, thousands rush to claim land in the Land Rush of 1889. Within hours the cities of Oklahoma City and Guthrie are formed with populations of at least 10,000.

1890.event: Eritrea is consolidated into a colony by the Italian government.
The United Mine Workers of America is founded in Columbus, Ohio.
Nellie Bly completes her round-the-world journey in 72 days.
The longest bridge in Great Britain, the Forth Bridge in Scotland, measuring 8,094 feet (2,467 m) long, is opened by the Duke of Rothesay, later King Edward VII.
Chancellor of the German Empire Otto von Bismarck is dismissed by Emperor Wilhelm II.
The Pan-American Union is founded by the First International Conference of American States in Washington, D.C.
The United States Census Bureau begins using Herman Hollerith's tabulating machine to count census returns.
Canada and Bermuda are linked by telegraph cable.
The U.S. Congress passes the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Idaho is admitted as the 43rd U.S. state.

1891.event: Liliʻuokalani is proclaimed the last monarch and only queen regnant of the Kingdom of Hawaii.
History of Portugal: The first attempt at a Portuguese republican revolution breaks out in the northern city of Porto.
Allmänna Idrottsklubben (AIK) (Swedish Sports Club) is founded.
Shoshone National Forest is established as the first national forest in the US and world.
Almon Strowger patents the Strowger switch, a device which led to the automation of telephone circuit switching.
SS Utopia collides with HMS Anson in the Bay of Gibraltar and sinks, killing 562 of the 880 passengers on board.
Chilean Civil War: The ironclad Blanco Encalada is sunk at Caldera Bay by torpedo boats.
The Music Hall in New York City (later known as Carnegie Hall) has its grand opening and first public performance, with Tchaikovsky as the guest conductor.
Pope Leo XIII defends workers' rights and property rights in the encyclical Rerum novarum, the beginning of modern Catholic social teaching.

The International Electrotechnical Exhibition opens in Frankfurt, Germany, and will feature the world's first long-distance transmission of high-power, three-phase electric current (the most common form today).

1892.event: Ellis Island begins processing immigrants into the United States.
James Naismith publishes the rules of basketball.
The General Electric Company is formed.
In San Francisco, John Muir organizes the Sierra Club.
The Chicago "L" elevated rail system begins operation.
Homer Plessy is arrested for refusing to leave his seat in the "whites-only" car of a train; he lost the resulting court case, Plessy v. Ferguson.
The Limelight Department, one of the world's first film studios, is officially established in Melbourne, Australia.
The Homestead Strike begins near Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania.
Western Samoa changes the International Date Line, causing Monday (July 4) to occur twice, resulting in a year with 367 days.

1893.event: The Washington National Cathedral is chartered by Congress. The charter is signed by President Benjamin Harrison.
The Independent Labour Party of the United Kingdom holds its first meeting.
U.S. Marines land in Honolulu, Hawaii from the USS Boston to prevent the queen from abrogating the Bayonet Constitution.
Lorrin A. Thurston, along with the Citizens' Committee of Public Safety, led the Overthrow of the Kingdom of Hawaii and the government of Queen Liliʻuokalani.
The Tati Concessions Land, formerly part of Matabeleland, is formally annexed to the Bechuanaland Protectorate, now Botswana.
Thomas A. Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio, the Black Maria in West Orange, New Jersey.
Verdi's last opera, Falstaff premieres at La Scala, Milan.
Electrical engineer Nikola Tesla gives the first public demonstration of radio in St. Louis, Missouri.
The trial of Lizzie Borden for the murder of her father and step-mother begins in New Bedford, Massachusetts.

Grover Cleveland notices a rough spot in his mouth and on July 1 undergoes secret, successful surgery to remove a large, cancerous portion of his jaw; the operation was not revealed to the public until 1917, nine years after the president's death.

1894.event: Thomas Edison makes a kinetoscopic film of someone sneezing. On the same day, his employee, William Kennedy Dickson, receives a patent for motion picture film.
The Cripple Creek miner's strike, led by the Western Federation of Miners, begins in Cripple Creek, Colorado, United States.
Anarchist Émile Henry hurls a bomb into the Cafe Terminus in Paris, killing one person and wounding 20.
The Stanley Cup ice hockey competition is held for the first time, in Montreal, Canada.
Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, departs Massillon, Ohio for Washington, D.C.
The first ever commercial motion picture house opens in New York City, United States, using ten Kinetoscopes, a device for peep-show viewing of films.
Norway formally adopts the Krag-Jørgensen bolt-action rifle as the main arm of its armed forces, a weapon that would remain in service for almost 50 years.
Coxey's Army, the first significant American protest march, arrives in Washington, D.C.
Four thousand Pullman Palace Car Company workers go on a wildcat strike.
The Manchester Ship Canal in the United Kingdom is officially opened by Queen Victoria, who later knights its designer Sir Edward Leader Williams.

1895.event: Dreyfus affair: French army officer Alfred Dreyfus is stripped of his rank and sentenced to life imprisonment on Devil's Island.
The National Trust is founded in the United Kingdom.
First Italo-Ethiopian War: The war's opening battle, the Battle of Coatit, occurs; it is an Italian victory.
Fountains Valley, Pretoria, the oldest nature reserve in Africa, is proclaimed by President Paul Kruger.
William G. Morgan creates a game called Mintonette, which soon comes to be referred to as volleyball.
Revolution breaks out in Baire, a town near Santiago de Cuba, beginning the Cuban War of Independence; the war ends along with the Spanish-American War in 1898.
Auguste and Louis Lumière record their first footage using their newly patented cinematograph.
Before the Société pour L'Encouragement à l'Industrie, brothers Auguste and Louis Lumière demonstrate movie film technology publicly for the first time.
The trial in the libel case brought by Oscar Wilde begins, eventually resulting in his imprisonment on charges of homosexuality.
In Pollock v. Farmers' Loan & Trust Co. the Supreme Court of the United States declares unapportioned income tax to be unconstitutional.

1896.event: Utah is admitted as the 45th U.S. state.
An X-ray generating machine is exhibited for the first time by H. L. Smith.

Walter Arnold of East Peckham, Kent, becomes the first person to be convicted of speeding. He was fined one shilling, plus costs, for speeding at 8 mph (13 km/h), thereby exceeding the contemporary speed limit of 2 mph (3.2 km/h).
La bohème premieres in Turin at the Teatro Regio (Turin), conducted by the young Arturo Toscanini.

An Englishman raised in Australia, Bob Fitzsimmons, fought an Irishman, Peter Maher, in an American promoted event which technically took place in Mexico, winning the 1896 World Heavyweight Championship in boxing.
Battle of Adwa: An Ethiopian army defeats an outnumbered Italian force, ending the First Italo-Ethiopian War.
With the approval of Emperor Guangxu, the Qing dynasty post office is opened, marking the beginning of a postal service in China.
Charilaos Vasilakos wins the first modern Olympic marathon race with a time of three hours and 18 minutes.
An explosion at the Brunner Mine near Greymouth, New Zealand kills 65 coal miners in the country's worst industrial accident.

1897.event: Shinhan Bank, the oldest bank in South Korea, opens in Seoul.
The Greco-Turkish War is declared between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.

J. J. Thomson of the Cavendish Laboratory announces his discovery of the electron as a subatomic particle, over 1,800 times smaller than a proton (in the atomic nucleus), at a lecture at the Royal Institution in London.
Dracula, a Gothic horror novel by Irish author Bram Stoker, is published.

The original manuscript of William Bradford's history, Of Plymouth Plantation, is returned to the Governor of Massachusetts by the Bishop of London after being taken during the American Revolutionary War.
A treaty annexing the Republic of Hawaii to the United States is signed; the Republic would not be dissolved until a year later.

British colonial officers Charles Walter Rand and Lt. Charles Egerton Ayerst are assassinated in Pune, Maharashtra, India by the Chapekar brothers and Mahadeo Vinayak Ranade, who are later caught and hanged.
British-Italian engineer Guglielmo Marconi obtains a patent for radio in London.
Salomon August Andrée leaves Spitsbergen to attempt to reach the North Pole by balloon.
American author Jack London embarks on a sailing trip to take part in the Klondike's gold rush, from which he wrote his first successful stories.

1898.event: New York, New York annexes land from surrounding counties, creating the City of Greater New York. The four initial boroughs, Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, and The Bronx, are joined on January 25 by Staten Island to create the modern city of five boroughs.
Émile Zola's J'accuse…! exposes the Dreyfus affair.
Dreyfus affair: Émile Zola is brought to trial for libel for publishing J'Accuse…!
The battleship USS Maine explodes and sinks in Havana harbor in Cuba, killing about 274 of the ship's roughly 354 crew. The disaster pushes the United States to declare war on Spain.
Émile Zola is imprisoned in France after writing J'Accuse…!, a letter accusing the French government of antisemitism and wrongfully imprisoning Captain Alfred Dreyfus.
King George I of Greece survives an assassination attempt.
In Melbourne, the representatives of five colonies adopt a constitution, which would become the basis of the Commonwealth of Australia.[page needed]
U.S. President William McKinley signed a joint resolution to Congress for declaration of war against Spain, beginning the Spanish-American War.

Spanish-American War: The United States Navy begins a blockade of Cuban ports. When the U.S. Congress issued a declaration of war on April 25, it declared that a state of war had existed from this date.
Spanish-American War: The USS Nashville captures a Spanish merchant ship.

1899.event: The United States takes possession of Wake Island in the Pacific Ocean.
The Malolos Constitution is inaugurated, establishing the First Philippine Republic. Emilio Aguinaldo is sworn in as its first president.
The Australian Premiers' Conference held in Melbourne decides to locate Australia's capital city, Canberra, between Sydney and Melbourne.
The Philippine-American War begins with the Battle of Manila.
Spanish-American War: The Treaty of Paris, a peace treaty between the United States and Spain, is ratified by the United States Senate.
Voting machines are approved by the U.S. Congress for use in federal elections.
Tsar Nicholas II of Russia issues a declaration known as the February Manifesto, which reduces the autonomy of the Grand Duchy of Finland, thus beginning the first period of oppression.
Iceland's first football club, Knattspyrnufélag Reykjavíkur, is founded.

1900.event: Nigeria becomes British protectorate with Frederick Lugard as high commissioner.
American statesman and diplomat John Hay announces the Open Door Policy to promote trade with China.
Irish nationalist leader John Edward Redmond calls for revolt against British rule.
Second Boer War: Having already besieged the fortress at Ladysmith, Boer forces attack it, but are driven back by British defenders.
President William McKinley  places Alaska under military rule.
To combat Czech nationalism, Emperor Franz Joseph decrees German will be language of the Austro-Hungarian Armed Forces.
Giacomo Puccini's Tosca opens in Rome.
The United States Senate accepts the Anglo-German treaty of 1899 in which the United Kingdom renounces its claims to the Samoan islands.
Second Boer War: The Battle of Spion Kop between the forces of the South African Republic and the Orange Free State and British forces ends in a British defeat.

1901.event: The Southern Nigeria Protectorate is established within the British Empire.

The British colonies of New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania, and Western Australia federate as the Commonwealth of Australia; Edmund Barton is appointed the first Prime Minister.
The first great Texas oil gusher is discovered at Spindletop in Beaumont, Texas.
New York: Automobile Club of America installs signs on major highways.
Queen Victoria, Queen of the United Kingdom, stricken with paralysis. She dies three days later at the age of 81.
Edward VII is proclaimed King of the United Kingdom after the death of his mother, Queen Victoria.
Anton Chekhov's Three Sisters premieres at Moscow Art Theatre in Russia.
J. P. Morgan forms U.S. Steel, a $1 billion steel company, having bought some of John D. Rockefeller's iron mines and Andrew Carnegie's entire steel business.
The legislature of Hawaii Territory convenes for the first time.

1902.event: The first American college football bowl game, the Rose Bowl between Michigan and Stanford, is held in Pasadena, California.
The Carnegie Institution of Washington is founded in Washington, D.C. with a $10 million gift from Andrew Carnegie.
The first Anglo-Japanese Alliance is signed in London.
Second Boer War: Australian soldiers Harry "Breaker" Morant and Peter Handcock are executed in Pretoria after being convicted of war crimes.
Second Boer War: Boers, led by Koos de la Rey, inflict the biggest defeat upon the British since the beginning of the war, at Tweebosch.
Macario Sakay issues Presidential Order No. 1 of his Tagalog Republic.
Dmitry Sipyagin, Minister of Interior of the Russian Empire, is assassinated in the Marie Palace, Saint Petersburg.
"Electric Theatre", the first full-time movie theater in the United States, opens in Los Angeles.

A stand box collapses at Ibrox Park (now Ibrox Stadium) in Glasgow, Scotland, which led to the deaths of 25 and injuries to more than 500 supporters during an international association football match between Scotland and England.
The 7.5 Mw  Guatemala earthquake shakes Guatemala with a maximum Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe), killing between 800 and 2,000.

1903.event: Topsy, an elephant, is electrocuted by the owners of Luna Park, Coney Island. The Edison film company records the film Electrocuting an Elephant of Topsy's death.
Hallam Tennyson, 2nd Baron Tennyson, son of the poet Alfred Tennyson, becomes the second Governor-General of Australia.
El Yunque National Forest in Puerto Rico becomes part of the United States National Forest System as the Luquillo Forest Reserve.
Anton Bruckner's 9th Symphony receives its first performance in Vienna, Austria.
The United States Department of Commerce and Labor is established (later split into the Department of Commerce and the Department of Labor).
Cuba leases Guantánamo Bay to the United States "in perpetuity".
In New York City the Martha Washington Hotel opens, becoming the first hotel exclusively for women.
Pelican Island National Wildlife Refuge, the first national wildlife refuge in the US, is established by President Theodore Roosevelt.
The Kishinev pogrom in Kishinev (Bessarabia) begins, forcing tens of thousands of Jews to later seek refuge in Palestine and the Western world.
Atlético Madrid Association football club is founded

1904.event: The distress signal "CQD" is established only to be replaced two years later by "SOS".
Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard receives its premiere performance at the Moscow Art Theatre.
Ålesund Fire: The Norwegian coastal town Ålesund is devastated by fire, leaving 10,000 people homeless and one person dead. Kaiser Wilhelm II funds the rebuilding of the town in Jugendstil style.
A fire begins in Baltimore, Maryland; it destroys over 1,500 buildings in 30 hours.
Battle of Port Arthur: A surprise torpedo attack by the Japanese at Port Arthur, Japan starts the Russo-Japanese War.

Aceh War: Dutch Colonial Army's Marechaussee regiment led by General G.C.E. van Daalen launch military campaign to capture Gayo Highland, Alas Highland, and Batak Highland in Dutch East Indies' Northern Sumatra region, which ends with genocide to Acehnese and Bataks people.
Russo-Japanese War: Battle of Port Arthur concludes.
The United Kingdom sells a meteorological station on the South Orkney Islands to Argentina; the islands are subsequently claimed by the United Kingdom in 1908.[citation needed]
The French Third Republic and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland sign the Entente cordiale.
The United States begins construction of the Panama Canal.

1905.event: Bloody Sunday in Saint Petersburg, beginning of the 1905 revolution.
The world's largest diamond ever, the Cullinan, which weighs 3,106.75 carats (0.621350 kg), is found at the Premier Mine near Pretoria in South Africa.
In Mexico, the General Hospital of Mexico is inaugurated, started with four basic specialties.
The U.S. Supreme Court upholds the constitutionality of Massachusetts's mandatory smallpox vaccination program in Jacobson v. Massachusetts.
Chicago attorney Paul Harris and three other businessmen meet for lunch to form the Rotary Club, the world's first service club.
Eleftherios Venizelos calls for Crete's union with Greece, and begins what is to be known as the Theriso revolt.
Kaiser Wilhelm II of Germany declares his support for Moroccan independence in Tangier, beginning the First Moroccan Crisis.
In India, an earthquake hits the Kangra Valley, killing 20,000, and destroying most buildings in Kangra, McLeod Ganj and Dharamshala.

The Supreme Court of the United States decides Lochner v. New York, which holds that the "right to free contract" is implicit in the due process clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution.
Albert Einstein completes his doctoral thesis at the University of Zurich.

1906.event: SS Valencia runs aground on rocks on Vancouver Island, British Columbia, killing more than 130.
HMS Dreadnought, the first of a revolutionary new breed of battleships, is christened.
Pope Pius X publishes the encyclical Vehementer Nos.
Édouard de Laveleye forms the Belgian Olympic Committee in Brussels.
Moro Rebellion: United States Army troops bring overwhelming force against the native Moros in the First Battle of Bud Dajo, leaving only six survivors.
The Courrières mine disaster, Europe's worst ever, kills 1099 miners in northern France.
The first England vs France rugby union match is played at Parc des Princes in Paris.
The Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States (later the National Collegiate Athletic Association) is established to set rules for college sports in the United States.
Mount Vesuvius erupts and devastates Naples.
The Algeciras Conference gives France and Spain control over Morocco.

1907.event: Maria Montessori opens her first school and daycare center for working class children in Rome, Italy.
An earthquake in Kingston, Jamaica kills more than 1,000 people.
Charles Curtis of Kansas becomes the first Native American U.S. Senator.
Belgian chemist Leo Baekeland announces the creation of Bakelite, the world's first synthetic plastic.
The Mud March is the first large procession organised by the National Union of Women's Suffrage Societies (NUWSS).
The first parliamentary elections of Finland (at the time the Grand Duchy of Finland) are held.
The Ellis Island immigration center processes 11,747 people, more than on any other day.
The unicameral Parliament of Finland gathers for its first plenary session.
The first Isle of Man TT race is held.
The National Association for Women's Suffrage succeeds in getting Norwegian women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.

1908.event: Grand Canyon National Monument is created.
The Rhoads Opera House fire in Boyertown, Pennsylvania kills 171 people.
The Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority becomes the first Greek-letter organization founded and established by African American college women.
New York City passes the Sullivan Ordinance, making it illegal for women to smoke in public, only to have the measure vetoed by the mayor.
The first Boy Scout troop is organized in England by Robert Baden-Powell.
Members of the Portuguese Republican Party fail in their attempted coup d'état against the administrative dictatorship of Prime Minister João Franco.
Indian pacifist and leader Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi is released from prison by Jan C. Smuts after being tried and sentenced to two months in jail earlier in the month.
Lisbon Regicide: King Carlos I of Portugal and Infante Luis Filipe are shot dead in Lisbon.
The Collinwood school fire, Collinwood near Cleveland, Ohio, kills 174 people.
Inter Milan was founded on Football Club Internazionale, following a schism from A.C. Milan.

1909.event: Ernest Shackleton, leading the Nimrod Expedition to the South Pole, plants the British flag 97 nautical miles (180 km; 112 mi) from the South Pole, the farthest anyone had ever reached at that time.
Ernest Shackleton's expedition finds the magnetic South Pole.
Newly formed automaker General Motors (GM) buys into the Oakland Motor Car Company, which later becomes GM's long-running Pontiac division.

RMS Republic, a passenger ship of the White Star Line, becomes the first ship to use the CQD distress signal after colliding with another ship, the SS Florida, off the Massachusetts coastline, an event that kills six people. The Republic sinks the next day.
Richard Strauss's opera Elektra receives its debut performance at the Dresden State Opera.
United States troops leave Cuba, with the exception of Guantanamo Bay Naval Base, after being there since the Spanish-American War.
The Paris Film Congress opens, an attempt by European producers to form an equivalent to the MPCC cartel in the United States.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) is founded.
New Zealand's worst maritime disaster of the 20th century happens when the SS Penguin, an inter-island ferry, sinks and explodes at the entrance to Wellington Harbour.
The Flores Theater fire in Acapulco, Mexico kills 250.

1910.event: Captain David Beatty is promoted to Rear admiral, and becomes the youngest admiral in the Royal Navy (except for Royal family members) since Horatio Nelson.
The first public radio broadcast takes place; a live performance of the operas Cavalleria rusticana and Pagliacci is sent out over the airwaves from the Metropolitan Opera House in New York.
Construction ends on the Buffalo Bill Dam in Wyoming, United States, which was the highest dam in the world at the time, at 99 m (325 ft).
The Boy Scouts of America is incorporated by William D. Boyce.
The deadliest avalanche in United States history buries a Great Northern Railway train in northeastern King County, Washington, killing 96 people.
Rockefeller Foundation: John D. Rockefeller Jr. announces his retirement from managing his businesses so that he can devote all his time to philanthropy.
French aviator Raymonde de Laroche becomes the first woman to receive a pilot's license.
Henri Fabre becomes the first person to fly a seaplane, the Fabre Hydravion, after taking off from a water runway near in France.
The Transandine Railway connecting Chile and Argentina is inaugurated.
SMS Zrínyi, one of the last pre-dreadnought battleships built by the Austro-Hungarian Navy, is launched.

1911.event: A magnitude 7.7 earthquake destroys the city of Almaty in Russian Turkestan.
A gun battle in the East End of London leaves two dead. It sparked a political row over the involvement of then-Home Secretary Winston Churchill.
Kappa Alpha Psi, the world's third oldest and largest black fraternity, is founded at Indiana University.
The University of the Philippines College of Law is formally established; three future Philippine presidents are among the first enrollees.
Roald Amundsen's South Pole expedition makes landfall on the eastern edge of the Ross Ice Shelf.
Eugene B. Ely lands on the deck of the USS Pennsylvania anchored in San Francisco Bay, the first time an aircraft landed on a ship.
The first Monte Carlo Rally takes place.
Mexican Revolution: Mexicali is captured by the Mexican Liberal Party, igniting the Magonista rebellion of 1911.
The destroyer USS Terry makes the first airplane rescue at sea saving the life of Douglas McCurdy ten miles from Havana, Cuba.

1912.event: The RMS Titanic sank in the North Atlantic after hitting an iceberg.
The Republic of China is established.
The Scout Association is incorporated throughout the British Empire by royal charter.

The sixth All-Russian Conference of the Russian Social Democratic Labour Party (Prague Party Conference) opens. In the course of the conference, Vladimir Lenin and his supporters break from the rest of the party to form the Bolshevik movement.
New Mexico is admitted to the Union as the 47th U.S. state.
German geophysicist Alfred Wegener first presents his theory of continental drift.
The African National Congress is founded, under the name South African Native National Congress (SANNC).
Immigrant textile workers in Lawrence, Massachusetts, go on strike when wages are reduced in response to a mandated shortening of the work week.
British polar explorer Captain Robert Falcon Scott reaches the South Pole, one month after Roald Amundsen.
The International Opium Convention is signed at The Hague.
The Xuantong Emperor, the last Emperor of China, abdicates.

1913.event: An Atlantic coast storm sets the lowest confirmed barometric pressure reading for a non-tropical system in the continental United States.

First Balkan War: The Battle of Lemnos begins; Greek admiral Pavlos Kountouriotis forces the Turkish fleet to retreat to its base within the Dardanelles, from which it did not venture for the rest of the war.
First Balkan War: A Greek flotilla defeats the Ottoman Navy in the Naval Battle of Lemnos, securing the islands of the Northern Aegean Sea for Greece.
Grand Central Terminal opens in New York City.
The Sixteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, authorizing the Federal government to impose and collect an income tax.
Greek military aviators, Michael Moutoussis and Aristeidis Moraitinis perform the first naval air mission in history, with a Farman MF.7 hydroplane.
A group of meteors is visible across much of the eastern seaboard of the Americas, leading astronomers to conclude the source had been a small, short-lived natural satellite of the Earth.
The 13th Dalai Lama proclaims Tibetan independence following a period of domination by Manchu Qing dynasty and initiated a period of almost four decades of independence.
The Armory Show opens in New York City, displaying works of artists who are to become some of the most influential painters of the early 20th century.
Pedro Lascuráin becomes President of Mexico for 45 minutes; this is the shortest term to date of any person as president of any country.

1914.event: Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria was assassinated, leading to the outbreak of World War I.
The SPT Airboat Line becomes the world's first scheduled airline to use a winged aircraft.
The Ford Motor Company announces an eight-hour workday and minimum daily wage of $5 in salary plus bonuses.
The Phi Beta Sigma fraternity is founded by African-American students at Howard University in Washington D.C., United States.
Copyright: In New York City the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is established to protect the copyrighted musical compositions of its members.
HMHS Britannic, sister to the RMS Titanic, is launched at Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast.
China joins the Universal Postal Union.
Prince William of Wied arrives in Albania to begin his reign as King.
Nineteen men, women, and children participating in a strike are killed in the Ludlow Massacre during the Colorado Coalfield War.
Ypiranga incident: A German arms shipment to Mexico is intercepted by the U.S. Navy near Veracruz.
First baseball game at Wrigley Field, then known as Weeghman Park, in Chicago.

1915.event: The United States House of Representatives rejects a proposal to require states to give women the right to vote.
The 6.7 Mw  Avezzano earthquake shakes the Province of L'Aquila in Italy with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing between 29,978 and 32,610.
Russia defeats Ottoman Turkey in the Battle of Sarikamish during the Caucasus Campaign of World War I.
Japan issues the "Twenty-One Demands" to the Republic of China in a bid to increase its power in East Asia.
Georges Claude patents the neon discharge tube for use in advertising.

German strategic bombing during World War I: German zeppelins bomb the towns of Great Yarmouth and King's Lynn in the United Kingdom killing at least 20 people, in the first major aerial bombardment of a civilian target.
Kiwanis International is founded in Detroit.
Over 600 people are killed in Guadalajara, Mexico, when a train plunges off the tracks into a deep canyon.
World War I: British Grand Fleet battle cruisers under Vice-Admiral Sir David Beatty engage Rear-Admiral Franz von Hipper's battle cruisers in the Battle of Dogger Bank.
Alexander Graham Bell inaugurates U.S. transcontinental telephone service, speaking from New York to Thomas Watson in San Francisco.

1916.event: World War I: The Battle of Gallipoli concludes with an Ottoman Empire victory when the last Allied forces are evacuated from the peninsula.
World War I: Imperial Russia begins the Erzurum Offensive, leading to the defeat of the Ottoman Empire's Third Army.

Both Oswald Boelcke and Max Immelmann, for achieving eight aerial victories each over Allied aircraft, receive the German Empire's highest military award, the Pour le Mérite as the first German aviators to earn it.
In Brushaber v. Union Pacific Railroad Co., the Supreme Court of the United States declares the federal income tax constitutional.
World War I: The British government passes the Military Service Act that introduces conscription in the United Kingdom.

The Canadian province of Manitoba grants women the right to vote and run for office in provincial elections (although still excluding women of Indigenous or Asian heritage), marking the first time women in Canada are granted voting rights.
The Centre Block of the Parliament buildings in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada burns down with the loss of seven lives.
World War I: In France, the Battle of Verdun begins.
The Governor-General of Korea establishes a clinic called Jahyewon in Sorokdo to segregate Hansen's disease patients.
In the Battle of Verdun, a German unit captures Fort Douaumont, keystone of the French defences, without a fight.

1917.event: World War I: The Battle of Rafa is fought near the Egyptian border with Palestine.
The Kingsland munitions factory explosion occurs as a result of sabotage.
The United States pays Denmark $25 million for the Virgin Islands.
Silvertown explosion: A blast at a munitions factory in London kills 73 and injures over 400. The resulting fire causes over £2,000,000 worth of damage.
American entry into World War I: President Woodrow Wilson of the still-neutral United States calls for "peace without victory" in Europe.
Sinking of the SS Laurentic after hitting two German mines off the coast of Northern Ireland.
World War I: Kaiser Wilhelm II orders the resumption of unrestricted submarine warfare.
World War I: The American entry into World War I begins when diplomatic relations with Germany are severed due to its unrestricted submarine warfare.
The current constitution of Mexico is adopted, establishing a federal republic with powers separated into independent executive, legislative, and judicial branches.
The Congress of the United States passes the Immigration Act of 1917 over President Woodrow Wilson's veto.

1918.event: An armistice was signed, effectively ending World War I.
The Finnish Declaration of Independence is recognized by Russia, Sweden, Germany and France.
U.S. President Woodrow Wilson announces his "Fourteen Points" for the aftermath of World War I.
Battle of Bear Valley: The last battle of the American Indian Wars.
The Minnie Pit Disaster coal mining accident occurs in Halmer End, Staffordshire, in which 155 men and boys die.
Finnish Civil War: The first serious battles take place between the Red Guards and the White Guard.
The Gregorian calendar is introduced in Russia by decree of the Council of People's Commissars effective February 14 (New Style).
The Ukrainian People's Republic declares independence from Soviet Russia.
The Finnish Defence Forces (The White Guards) are established as the official army of independent Finland, and Baron C. G. E. Mannerheim is appointed its Commander-in-Chief.
Finnish Civil War: A group of Red Guards hangs a red lantern atop the tower of Helsinki Workers' Hall to symbolically mark the start of the war.
Beginning of the Finnish Civil War.

1919.event: The German Workers' Party, which would become the Nazi Party, is founded in Munich.
Montenegrin guerrilla fighters rebel against the planned annexation of Montenegro by Serbia, but fail.
Rosa Luxemburg and Karl Liebknecht, two of the most prominent socialists in Germany, are tortured and murdered by the Freikorps at the end of the Spartacist uprising.
Great Molasses Flood: A wave of molasses released from an exploding storage tank sweeps through Boston, Massachusetts, killing 21 and injuring 150.

Nebraska becomes the 36th state to approve the Eighteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution. With the necessary three-quarters of the states approving the amendment, Prohibition is constitutionally mandated in the United States one year later.
World War I: The Paris Peace Conference opens in Versailles, France.
Ignacy Jan Paderewski becomes Prime Minister of the newly independent Poland.
A revolutionary Irish parliament is founded and declares the independence of the Irish Republic. One of the first engagements of the Irish War of Independence takes place.
Act Zluky is signed, unifying the Ukrainian People's Republic and the West Ukrainian National Republic.
The Order of the White Rose of Finland is established by Baron Gustaf Mannerheim, the regent of the Kingdom of Finland.

1920.event: The 19th Amendment was ratified, granting American women the right to vote.
The second Palmer Raid, ordered by the US Department of Justice, results in 6,000 suspected communists and anarchists being arrested and held without trial.
Over 640 are killed after a magnitude 6.4 earthquake strikes the Mexican states Puebla and Veracruz.
The New York State Assembly refuses to seat five duly elected Socialist assemblymen.
The steel strike of 1919 ends in failure for the Amalgamated Association of Iron, Steel and Tin Workers labor union.
The Treaty of Versailles takes effect, officially ending World War I for all combatant nations except the United States.
League of Nations Covenant automatically enters into force after the Treaty of Versailles is ratified by Germany.
The Reichstag Bloodbath of January 13, 1920, the bloodiest demonstration in German history.
The League of Nations holds its first council meeting in Paris, France.
Alcohol Prohibition begins in the United States as the Volstead Act goes into effect.
The United States Senate votes against joining the League of Nations.

1921.event: World premiere of the science fiction play by the Czech writer Karel Čapek R.U.R. in theater in Hradec Králové.
Greco-Turkish War: The First Battle of İnönü, the first battle of the war, begins near Eskişehir in Anatolia.
The Marxist Left in Slovakia and the Transcarpathian Ukraine holds its founding congress in Ľubochňa.
The British K-class submarine HMS K5 sinks in the English Channel; all 56 on board die.
The first Constitution of Turkey is adopted, making fundamental changes in the source and exercise of sovereignty by consecrating the principle of national sovereignty.
Bolsheviks launch a revolt in Georgia as a preliminary to the Red Army invasion of Georgia.
Constituent Assembly of the Democratic Republic of Georgia adopts the country's first constitution.
Rezā Shāh takes control of Tehran during a successful coup.
After Russian forces under Baron Roman von Ungern-Sternberg drive the Chinese out, the Bogd Khan is reinstalled as the emperor of Mongolia.[citation needed]
Georgian capital Tbilisi falls to the invading Russian forces after heavy fighting and the Russians declare the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic.

1922.event: Dáil Éireann ratifies the Anglo-Irish Treaty by a 64-57 vote.
Leonard Thompson becomes the first person to be injected with insulin.
Knickerbocker Storm: Washington, D.C.'s biggest snowfall, causes a disaster when the roof of the Knickerbocker Theatre collapses, killing over 100 people.
Ulysses by James Joyce is published.
The Washington Naval Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., limiting the naval armaments of United States, Britain, Japan, France, and Italy.
United States President Warren G. Harding introduces the first radio set in the White House.
Brazil becomes a member of the Berne Convention copyright treaty.
A challenge to the Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution, allowing women the right to vote, is rebuffed by the Supreme Court of the United States in Leser v. Garnett.
The United Kingdom ends its protectorate over Egypt through a Unilateral Declaration of Independence.
Mahatma Gandhi is arrested in India, tried for sedition, and sentenced to six years in prison, only to be released after nearly two years for an appendicitis operation.

1923.event: Britain's Railways are grouped into the Big Four: LNER, GWR, SR, and LMS.
Juan de la Cierva makes the first autogyro flight.
Lithuanian residents of the Memel Territory rebel against the League of Nations' decision to leave the area as a mandated region under French control.
Occupation of the Ruhr: Troops from France and Belgium occupy the Ruhr area to force Germany to make its World War I reparation payments.
Texas Tech University is founded as Texas Technological College in Lubbock, Texas.
Greece becomes the last European country to adopt the Gregorian calendar.
Howard Carter unseals the burial chamber of Pharaoh Tutankhamun.
The Arts Club of Chicago hosts the opening of Pablo Picasso's first United States showing, entitled Original Drawings by Pablo Picasso, becoming an early proponent of modern art in the United States.
Insulin becomes generally available for use by people with diabetes.
The Duke of York weds Lady Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon at Westminster Abbey.

1924.event: Ramsay MacDonald becomes the first Labour Prime Minister of the United Kingdom.
The 1924 Winter Olympics opens in Chamonix, in the French Alps, inaugurating the Winter Olympic Games.
Six days after his death Lenin's body is carried into a specially erected mausoleum.
Russia-United Kingdom relations are restored, over six years after the Communist revolution.
The Royal Greenwich Observatory begins broadcasting the hourly time signals known as the Greenwich Time Signal.
Capital punishment: The first state execution in the United States by gas chamber takes place in Nevada.

George Gershwin's Rhapsody in Blue received its premiere in a concert titled "An Experiment in Modern Music", in Aeolian Hall, New York, by Paul Whiteman and his band, with Gershwin playing the piano.
The Computing-Tabulating-Recording Company changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM).
The 407-year-old Islamic caliphate is abolished, when Caliph Abdülmecid II of the Ottoman Caliphate is deposed. The last remnant of the old regime gives way to the reformed Turkey of Kemal Atatürk.
The Free State of Fiume is annexed by the Kingdom of Italy.

1925.event: Nellie Tayloe Ross of Wyoming becomes the first female governor in the United States.
The Government of Turkey expels Patriarch Constantine VI from Istanbul.
Serum run to Nome: Dog sleds reach Nome, Alaska with diphtheria serum, inspiring the Iditarod race.
The 1925 serum run to Nome: The second delivery of serum arrives in Nome, Alaska.
The New Yorker publishes its first issue.
The Charlevoix-Kamouraska earthquake strikes northeastern North America.
The Tri-State Tornado hits the Midwestern states of Missouri, Illinois, and Indiana, killing 695 people.
The Butler Act prohibits the teaching of human evolution in Tennessee.
Syngman Rhee is removed from office after being impeached as the President of the Provisional Government of the Republic of Korea.

1926.event: Crown Prince Nguyễn Phúc Vĩnh Thuỵ is crowned king of Vietnam, the country's last monarch.
Abdul-Aziz ibn Saud is crowned King of Hejaz.
The first demonstration of the television by John Logie Baird.
The El Virilla train accident, Costa Rica, kills 248 people and wounds another 93 when a train falls off a bridge over the Río Virilla between Heredia and Tibás.
The dictator Theodoros Pangalos is elected President of Greece without opposition.
History of Rocketry: Robert Goddard launches the first liquid-fueled rocket, at Auburn, Massachusetts.
Chiang Kai-shek initiates a purge of communist elements within the National Revolutionary Army in Guangzhou.
Varney Airlines makes its first commercial flight (Varney is the root company of United Airlines).
Violet Gibson attempts to assassinate Italian Prime Minister Benito Mussolini.
Al-Baqi cemetery, former site of the mausoleum of four Shi'a Imams, is leveled to the ground by Wahhabis.

1927.event: New Mexican oil legislation goes into effect, leading to the formal outbreak of the Cristero War.
The first transatlantic commercial telephone service is established from New York City to London.
A fire at the Laurier Palace movie theatre in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, kills 78 children.
Fritz Lang's futuristic film Metropolis is released in Germany.
Louis B. Mayer, head of film studio Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM), announces the creation of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, at a banquet in Los Angeles, California.
Teddy Wakelam gives the first live radio commentary of a football match, between Arsenal F.C. and Sheffield United at Highbury.
Ibn Saud takes the title of King of Nejd.
A revolt against the military dictatorship of Portugal breaks out at Oporto.

U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs a bill by Congress establishing the Federal Radio Commission (later replaced by the Federal Communications Commission) which was to regulate the use of radio frequencies in the United States.
German theoretical physicist Werner Heisenberg writes a letter to fellow physicist Wolfgang Pauli, in which he describes his uncertainty principle for the first time.

1928.event: Boris Bazhanov defects through Iran. He is the only assistant of Joseph Stalin's secretariat to have defected from the Eastern Bloc.
A disastrous flood of the River Thames kills 14 people and causes extensive damage to much of riverside London.
Leon Trotsky is exiled to Alma-Ata.
In California, the St. Francis Dam fails; the resulting floods kill 431 people.
Charles Lindbergh is presented with the Medal of Honor for the first solo trans-Atlantic flight.
The Bremen, a German Junkers W 33 type aircraft, takes off for the first successful transatlantic aeroplane flight from east to west.
The Bremen, a German Junkers W 33 type aircraft, reaches Greenly Island, Canada - the first successful transatlantic aeroplane flight from east to west.

The Jinan incident begins with the deaths of twelve Japanese civilians by Chinese forces in Jinan, China, which leads to Japanese retaliation and the deaths of over 2,000 Chinese civilians in the following days.
The President of the Republic of China, Zhang Zuolin, is assassinated by Japanese agents.
Second Northern Expedition: The National Revolutionary Army captures Peking, whose name is changed to Beijing ("Northern Capital").

1929.event: The U.S. stock market crashed on Black Tuesday, leading to the Great Depression.
The former municipalities of Point Grey, British Columbia and South Vancouver, British Columbia are amalgamated into Vancouver.
King Alexander of the Serbs, Croats and Slovenes suspends his country's constitution (the January 6th Dictatorship).
Mother Teresa arrives by sea in Calcutta, India, to begin her work among India's poorest and sick people.
The first full-length talking motion picture filmed outdoors, In Old Arizona, is released.
Members of the Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng assassinate the labor recruiter Bazin, prompting a crackdown by French colonial authorities.
Kingdom of Italy and the Vatican sign the Lateran Treaty.
Saint Valentine's Day Massacre: Seven people, six of them gangster rivals of Al Capone's gang, are murdered in Chicago.

In the first battle of the Warlord Rebellion in northeastern Shandong against the Nationalist government of China, a 24,000-strong rebel force led by Zhang Zongchang was defeated at Zhifu by 7,000 NRA troops.
President Calvin Coolidge signs legislation establishing the 96,000 acres (390 km2) Grand Teton National Park in Wyoming.
Huey P. Long, Governor of Louisiana, is impeached by the Louisiana House of Representatives.

1930.event: Clessie Cummins arrives at the National Automobile Show in New York City, having driven a car powered by one of his diesel engines from Indianapolis.
The Indian National Congress declares 26 January as Independence Day or as the day for Poorna Swaraj ("Complete Independence") which occurred 17 years later.
The Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union orders that a million prosperous peasant families be driven off their farms.
Communist Party of Vietnam is founded at a "Unification Conference" held in Kowloon, British Hong Kong.
The Việt Nam Quốc Dân Đảng launches the failed Yên Bái mutiny in hope of overthrowing French protectorate over Vietnam.
The Romanian Football Federation joins FIFA.
While studying photographs taken in January, Clyde Tombaugh discovers Pluto.
Elm Farm Ollie becomes the first cow to fly in a fixed-wing aircraft and also the first cow to be milked in an aircraft.
International Unemployment Day demonstrations globally initiated by the Comintern.
Mahatma Gandhi begins the Salt March, a 200-mile march to the sea to protest the British monopoly on salt in India.

1931.event: Guy Menzies flies the first solo non-stop trans-Tasman flight (from Australia to New Zealand) in 11 hours and 45 minutes, crash-landing on New Zealand's west coast.
Sir Isaac Isaacs is sworn in as the first Australian-born Governor-General of Australia.
The Hawke's Bay earthquake, New Zealand's worst natural disaster, kills 258.
The British Raj completes its transfer from Calcutta to New Delhi.
The U.S. Congress approves the construction of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge by the state of California.
An anarchist uprising in Encarnación briefly transforms the city into a revolutionary commune.
The United States adopts The Star-Spangled Banner as its national anthem.
The British Raj: Gandhi-Irwin Pact is signed.
The Parliament House of Finland was officially inaugurated in Helsinki, Finland.
Alam Ara, India's first talking film, is released.

1932.event: The United States Post Office Department issues a set of 12 stamps commemorating the 200th anniversary of George Washington's birth.
Hattie Caraway becomes the first woman elected to the United States Senate.
Finland and the Soviet Union sign a non-aggression treaty.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Chinese National Revolutionary Army begins the defense of Harbin.
Second Sino-Japanese War: Harbin, Manchuria, falls to Japan.
Prohibition law is abolished in Finland after a national referendum, where 70% voted for a repeal of the law.

The Empire of Japan creates the independent state of Manzhouguo (the obsolete Chinese name for Manchuria) free from the Republic of China and installed former Chinese Emperor Aisin Gioro Puyi as Chief Executive of the State.

Hitler, having been stateless for seven years, obtains German citizenship when he is appointed a Brunswick state official by Dietrich Klagges, a fellow Nazi. As a result, Hitler is able to run for Reichspräsident in the 1932 election.
Aviator Charles Lindbergh's 20-month-old son Charles Jr is kidnapped from his home in East Amwell, New Jersey. His body would not be found until May 12.

1933.event: Minnie D. Craig becomes the first woman elected as Speaker of the North Dakota House of Representatives, the first woman to hold a Speaker position anywhere in the United States.
Construction of the Golden Gate Bridge begins in San Francisco Bay.
The 20th Amendment to the United States Constitution is ratified, changing the beginning and end of terms for all elected federal offices.
The name Pakistan is coined by Choudhry Rahmat Ali Khan and is accepted by Indian Muslims who then thereby adopted it further for the Pakistan Movement seeking independence.
Adolf Hitler's rise to power: Hitler takes office as the Chancellor of Germany.
Adolf Hitler announces that the expansion of Lebensraum into Eastern Europe, and its ruthless Germanisation, are the ultimate geopolitical objectives of Nazi foreign policy.
Mutiny on Royal Netherlands Navy warship HNLMS De Zeven Provinciën off the coast of Sumatra, Dutch East Indies.
In round 13 of a boxing match at New York City's Madison Square Garden, Primo Carnera knocks out Ernie Schaaf. Schaaf dies four days later.
In Miami, Giuseppe Zangara attempts to assassinate US President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt, but instead shoots Chicago mayor Anton J. Cermak, who dies of his wounds on March 6.

The U.S. Congress approves the Blaine Act to repeal federal Prohibition in the United States, sending the Twenty-first Amendment to the United States Constitution to state ratifying conventions for approval.

1934.event: Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay becomes a United States federal prison.
A "Law for the Prevention of Genetically Diseased Offspring" comes into effect in Nazi Germany.
The 8.0 Mw  Nepal-Bihar earthquake strikes Nepal and Bihar with a maximum Mercalli intensity of XI (Extreme), killing an estimated 6,000-10,700 people.
The Apollo Theater reopens in Harlem, New York City.
German-Polish declaration of non-aggression is signed.
The Export-Import Bank of the United States is incorporated.
Far-right leagues rally in front of the Palais Bourbon in an attempted coup against the French Third Republic, creating a political crisis in France.
The Balkan Entente is formed between Greece, Romania, Yugoslavia, and Turkey.
The Austrian Civil War ends with the defeat of the Social Democrats and the Republikanischer Schutzbund.

1935.event: Benito Mussolini and French Foreign minister Pierre Laval sign the Franco-Italian Agreement.
Amelia Earhart becomes the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to California.
A plebiscite in Saarland shows that 90.3% of those voting wish to join Nazi Germany.
Gottfried Krueger Brewing Company starts selling the first canned beer.
Iceland becomes the first Western country to legalize therapeutic abortion.
Leonarde Keeler administers polygraph tests to two murder suspects, the first time polygraph evidence was admitted in U.S. courts.
USS Macon, one of the two largest helium-filled airships ever created, crashes into the Pacific Ocean off the coast of California and sinks.
A jury in Flemington, New Jersey finds Bruno Hauptmann guilty of the 1932 kidnapping and murder of the Lindbergh baby, the son of Charles Lindbergh.
Caroline Mikkelsen becomes the first woman to set foot in Antarctica.
Adolf Hitler orders the Luftwaffe to be re-formed, violating the provisions of the Treaty of Versailles.

1936.event: Kashf-e hijab decree is made and immediately enforced by Reza Shah, Iran's head of state, banning the wearing of Islamic veils in public.
The first building to be completely covered in glass, built for the Owens-Illinois Glass Company, is completed in Toledo, Ohio.
King George V of the United Kingdom dies. His eldest son succeeds to the throne, becoming Edward VIII. The title Prince of Wales is not used for another 22 years.
The first inductees into the Baseball Hall of Fame are announced.
Second Italo-Abyssinian War: Italian troops launch the Battle of Amba Aradam against Ethiopian defenders.
The Popular Front wins the 1936 Spanish general election.
In the February 26 Incident, young Japanese military officers attempt to stage a coup against the government.
The February 26 Incident in Tokyo ends.
First flight of K5054, the first prototype Supermarine Spitfire advanced monoplane fighter aircraft in the United Kingdom.
Prelude to World War II: In violation of the Locarno Pact and the Treaty of Versailles, Germany reoccupies the Rhineland.

1937.event: Spanish Civil War: Nationalists and Republican both withdraw after suffering heavy losses, ending the Second Battle of the Corunna Road.
Howard Hughes sets a new air record by flying from Los Angeles to New York City in seven hours, 28 minutes, 25 seconds.

Franklin D. Roosevelt and John Nance Garner are sworn in for their second terms as U.S. President and U.S. Vice President; it is the first time a Presidential Inauguration takes place on January 20 since the 20th Amendment changed the dates of presidential terms.
The trial of the anti-Soviet Trotskyist center sees seventeen mid-level Communists accused of sympathizing with Leon Trotsky and plotting to overthrow Joseph Stalin's regime.
The Guiding Light debuts on NBC radio from Chicago. In 1952 it moves to CBS television, where it remains until September 18, 2009.
Spanish Civil War: Republicans establish the Interprovincial Council of Santander, Palencia and Burgos in Cantabria.
The Flint sit-down strike ends when General Motors recognizes the United Auto Workers trade union.
Wallace H. Carothers receives a United States patent for nylon.

Yekatit 12: During a public ceremony at the Viceregal Palace (the former Imperial residence) in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, two Ethiopian nationalists of Eritrean origin attempt to kill viceroy Rodolfo Graziani with a number of grenades.
The League of Nations bans foreign national "volunteers" in the Spanish Civil War.

1938.event: The World Land Speed Record on a public road is broken by Rudolf Caracciola in the Mercedes-Benz W125 Rekordwagen at a speed of 432.7 kilometres per hour (268.9 mph).
Adolf Hitler appoints himself as head of the Armed Forces High Command.
BBC Television produces the world's first ever science fiction television programme, an adaptation of a section of the Karel Čapek play R.U.R., that coined the term "robot".

Second Sino-Japanese War: During the Nanking Massacre, the Nanking Safety Zone International Committee is renamed "Nanking International Rescue Committee", and the safety zone in place for refugees falls apart.
Oil is discovered in Saudi Arabia.
Anschluss: German troops occupy and absorb Austria.
Mexico creates Pemex by expropriating all foreign-owned oil reserves and facilities.
Second Sino-Japanese War: The Battle of Taierzhuang begins, resulting several weeks later in the war's first major Chinese victory over Japan.
The 1938 German parliamentary election and referendum seeks approval for a single list of Nazi candidates and the recent annexation of Austria.
U.S. Supreme Court delivers its opinion in Erie Railroad Co. v. Tompkins and overturns a century of federal common law.

1939.event: The Black Friday bushfires burn 20,000 square kilometers of land in Australia, claiming the lives of 71 people.
Norway claims Queen Maud Land in Antarctica.
The deadliest earthquake in Chilean history strikes Chillán, killing approximately 28,000 people.
Spanish Civil War: Catalonia Offensive: Troops loyal to nationalist General Francisco Franco and aided by Italy take Barcelona.
First flight of the Lockheed P-38 Lightning.
Generalísimo Francisco Franco becomes the 68th "Caudillo de España", or Leader of Spain.
Spanish Civil War: The Nationalists conclude their conquest of Catalonia and seal the border with France.

As part of British air raid precautions, the first of 2.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}1⁄2 million Anderson shelters is constructed in a garden in Islington, north London.

United States labor law: The U.S. Supreme Court rules in NLRB v. Fansteel Metallurgical Corp. that the National Labor Relations Board has no authority to force an employer to rehire workers who engage in sit-down strikes.
An Imperial Japanese Army ammunition dump explodes at Hirakata, Osaka, Japan, killing 94.

1940.event: Winter War: Battle of Raate Road: The Finnish 9th Division finally defeat the numerically superior Soviet forces on the Raate-Suomussalmi road.
World War II: Britain introduces food rationing.
Three trains on the Nishinari Line; present Sakurajima Line, in Osaka, Japan, collide and explode while approaching Ajikawaguchi Station. One hundred and eighty-one people are killed.
The second full-length animated Walt Disney film, Pinocchio, premieres.
The Soviet Union begins mass deportations of Polish citizens from occupied eastern Poland to Siberia.
World War II: Altmark incident: The German tanker Altmark is boarded by sailors from the British destroyer HMS Cossack. A total of 299 British prisoners are freed.
Martin Kamen and Sam Ruben discover carbon-14.
For her performance as Mammy in Gone with the Wind, Hattie McDaniel becomes the first African American to win an Academy Award.
Finland initiates Winter War peace negotiations.
In a ceremony held in Berkeley, California, physicist Ernest Lawrence receives the 1939 Nobel Prize in Physics from Sweden's consul general in San Francisco.

1941.event: The Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor, leading the United States to enter World War II.
World War II: The Cardiff Blitz severely damages the cathedral in Cardiff, Wales.
Amy Johnson, a 37-year-old pilot and the first woman to fly solo from London to Australia, disappears after bailing out of her plane over the River Thames, and is presumed dead.
United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt delivers his Four Freedoms speech in the State of the Union address.
World War II: First flight of the Avro Lancaster.
World War II: The Greek army captures Kleisoura.
Franco-Thai War: Vichy French forces inflict a decisive defeat over the Royal Thai Navy.
World War II: British troops launch a general counter-offensive against Italian East Africa.
World War II: HMS Greyhound and other escorts of convoy AS-12 sink Italian submarine Neghelli with all hands 64 kilometres (40 mi) northeast of Falkonera.
A German officer is killed in Bucharest, Romania, sparking a rebellion and pogrom by the Iron Guard, killing 125 Jews and 30 soldiers.
Sparked by the murder of a German officer in Bucharest, Romania the day before, members of the Iron Guard engaged in a rebellion and pogrom killing 125 Jews.

1942.event: The Declaration by United Nations is signed by twenty-six nations.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) obtains the conviction of 33 members of a German spy ring headed by Fritz Joubert Duquesne in the largest espionage case in United States history—the Duquesne Spy Ring.
World War II: Manila is captured by Japanese forces, enabling them to control the Philippines.
World War II: Japanese forces capture Kuala Lumpur, the capital of the Federated Malay States.
World War II: Japanese forces attack Tarakan in Borneo, Netherlands Indies (Battle of Tarakan)
World War II: United States President Franklin D. Roosevelt creates the National War Labor Board.
Henry Ford patents a soybean car, which is 30% lighter than a regular car.
World War II: First use of an aircraft ejection seat by a German test pilot in a Heinkel He 280 jet fighter.
The Holocaust: Nazi Germany begins deporting Jews from the Łódź Ghetto to Chełmno extermination camp.
Crash of TWA Flight 3, killing all 22 aboard, including film star Carole Lombard.

1943.event: The Republic of China agrees to the Sino-British New Equal Treaty and the Sino-American New Equal Treaty.
Italian-American anarchist Carlo Tresca is assassinated in New York City.
World War II: Japan begins Operation Ke, the successful operation to evacuate its forces from Guadalcanal during the Guadalcanal Campaign.
World War II: Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill begin the Casablanca Conference to discuss strategy and study the next phase of the war.
World War II: The Soviet counter-offensive at Voronezh begins.
The Pentagon is dedicated in Arlington, Virginia.
World War II: Greek submarine Papanikolis captures the 200-ton sailing vessel Agios Stefanos and mans her with part of her crew.
Warsaw Ghetto Uprising: The first uprising of Jews in the Warsaw Ghetto.
World War II: Australian and American forces defeat Japanese army and navy units in the bitterly fought Battle of Buna-Gona.
World War II: Troops of the British Eighth Army capture Tripoli in Libya from the German-Italian Panzer Army.

1944.event: D-Day occurred as Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy, France.
World War II: US flying ace Major Greg "Pappy" Boyington is shot down in his Vought F4U Corsair by Captain Masajiro Kawato flying a Mitsubishi A6M Zero.
World War II: Operation Carpetbagger, involving the dropping of arms and supplies to resistance fighters in Europe, begins.
The Daily Mail becomes the first major London newspaper to be published on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.

World War II: Allied forces launch the first of four assaults on Monte Cassino with the intention of breaking through the Winter Line and seizing Rome, an effort that would ultimately take four months and cost 105,000 Allied casualties.
World War II: The Allies commence Operation Shingle, an assault on Anzio and Nettuno, Italy.
World War II: The 900-day Siege of Leningrad is lifted.
World War II: Approximately 38 people are killed and about a dozen injured when the Polish village of Koniuchy (present-day Kaniūkai, Lithuania) is attacked by Soviet partisan units.
In Bologna, Italy, the Anatomical theatre of the Archiginnasio is completely destroyed in an air-raid, during the Second World War.
World War II: The Battle of Cisterna, part of Operation Shingle, begins in central Italy.
World War II: American forces land on Kwajalein Atoll and other islands in the Japanese-held Marshall Islands.

1945.event: Japan formally surrendered aboard the USS Missouri, officially ending World War II.
An atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima by the United States during World War II.
Victory in Europe Day was celebrated as Nazi Germany's surrender became official.
World War II: The German Luftwaffe launches Operation Bodenplatte, a massive, but failed, attempt to knock out Allied air power in northern Europe in a single blow.
The Soviet Union recognizes the new pro-Soviet Provisional Government of the Republic of Poland.
World War II: Philippine Commonwealth troops under the Philippine Commonwealth Army units enter the province of Ilocos Sur in Northern Luzon and attack invading Japanese Imperial forces.
World War II: The Sixth United States Army begins the invasion of Lingayen Gulf.
World War II: The Red Army begins the Vistula-Oder Offensive.
World War II: Adolf Hitler moves into his underground bunker, the so-called Führerbunker.
World War II: The Vistula-Oder Offensive forces German troops out of Warsaw.
The SS-Totenkopfverbände begin the evacuation of the Auschwitz concentration camp as the Red Army closes in.
Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg is taken into Soviet custody while in Hungary; he is never publicly seen again.
World War II: Liberation of Kraków, Poland by the Red Army.

1946.event: Popular Canadian American jockey George Woolf dies in a freak accident during a race; the annual George Woolf Memorial Jockey Award is created to honor him.
The first general election ever in Vietnam is held.

Andrei Zhdanov, Chairman of the Finnish Allied Commission, submitted to the Finnish War Criminal Court an interrogation report by General Erich Buschenhagen, a German prisoner of war, on the contacts between Finnish and German military personnel before the Continuation War and a copy of Hitler's Barbarossa plan.
The first General Assembly of the United Nations assembles in the Methodist Central Hall, Westminster. Fifty-one nations are represented.
The United States Army Signal Corps successfully conducts Project Diana, bouncing radio waves off the Moon and receiving the reflected signals.
Enver Hoxha, Secretary General of the Communist Party of Albania, declares the People's Republic of Albania with himself as head of state.
The UN Security Council holds its first session.
General Douglas MacArthur establishes the International Military Tribunal for the Far East in Tokyo to try Japanese war criminals.

In Iran, Qazi Muhammad declares the independent people's Republic of Mahabad at Chahar Cheragh Square in the Kurdish city of Mahabad; he becomes the new president and Haji Baba Sheikh becomes the prime minister.
Creation of the Central Intelligence Group, forerunner of the Central Intelligence Agency.

1947.event: India gained independence from British rule.
Cold War: The American and British occupation zones in Allied-occupied Germany, after World War II, merge to form the Bizone, which later (with the French zone) became part of West Germany.
The Canadian Citizenship Act 1946 comes into effect, converting British subjects into Canadian citizens. Prime Minister William Lyon Mackenzie King becomes the first Canadian citizen.
Proceedings of the U.S. Congress are televised for the first time.
Pan American Airlines becomes the first commercial airline to offer a round-the-world ticket.
The Black Dahlia murder: The dismembered corpse of Elizabeth Short was found in Los Angeles.
KTLA, the first commercial television station west of the Mississippi River, begins operation in Hollywood.
Thomas Goldsmith Jr. files a patent for a "Cathode Ray Tube Amusement Device", the first ever electronic game.
The Paris Peace Treaties are signed by Italy, Romania, Hungary, Bulgaria, Finland and the Allies of World War II.
The largest observed iron meteorite until that time creates an impact crater in Sikhote-Alin, in the Soviet Union.
Christian Dior unveils a "New Look", helping Paris regain its position as the capital of the fashion world.

1948.event: The British railway network is nationalized to form British Railways.
Burma gains its independence from the United Kingdom becoming an independent republic, named the Union of Burma, with Sao Shwe Thaik as its first President and U Nu its first Prime Minister.
Kentucky Air National Guard pilot Thomas Mantell crashes while in pursuit of a supposed UFO.
The Renville Agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesia is ratified.
The Flag of Quebec is adopted and flown for the first time over the National Assembly of Quebec. The day is marked annually as Québec Flag Day.
British South American Airways' Tudor IV Star Tiger disappears over the Bermuda Triangle.

Following the assassination of Mahatma Gandhi in his home compound, India's prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, broadcasts to the nation, saying "The light has gone out of our lives". The date of the assassination becomes observed as "Martyrs' Day" in India.
Ceylon (later renamed Sri Lanka) becomes independent within the British Commonwealth.
The Conference of Youth and Students of Southeast Asia Fighting for Freedom and Independence convenes in Calcutta.

1949.event: United Nations cease-fire takes effect in Kashmir from one minute before midnight. War between India and Pakistan stops accordingly.
Luis Muñoz Marín is inaugurated as the first democratically elected Governor of Puerto Rico.
The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the central bank of the Philippines, is established.
In his "State of the Union" address, United States President Harry S. Truman unveils his Fair Deal program.
The first "networked" television broadcasts took place as KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania goes on the air connecting the east coast and mid-west programming.
Chinese Civil War: The Communist forces take over Tianjin from the Nationalist government.
Point Four Program, a program for economic aid to poor countries, is announced by United States President Harry S. Truman in his inaugural address for a full term as president.
The first Emmy Awards are presented in the United States; the venue is the Hollywood Athletic Club.
The Hale telescope at Palomar Observatory sees first light under the direction of Edwin Hubble, becoming the largest aperture optical telescope (until BTA-6 is built in 1976).
These Are My Children, the first television daytime soap opera, is broadcast by the NBC station in Chicago.

1950.event: In the Sverdlovsk air disaster, all 19 of those on board are killed, including almost the entire national ice hockey team (VVS Moscow) of the Soviet Air Force - 11 players, as well as a team doctor and a masseur.
The United Kingdom recognizes the People's Republic of China. The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the UK in response.
British submarine HMS Truculent collides with an oil tanker in the Thames Estuary, killing 64 men.
Finland forms diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China.
The Great Brink's Robbery: Eleven thieves steal more than $2 million from an armored car company's offices in Boston.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 79 relating to arms control is adopted.
American lawyer and government official Alger Hiss is convicted of perjury.
The Knesset resolves that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel.
The Constitution of India comes into force, forming a republic. Rajendra Prasad is sworn in as the first President of India. Observed as Republic Day in India.
President Truman orders the development of thermonuclear weapons.

1951.event: Korean War: Chinese and North Korean forces capture Seoul for the second time.
