Korean War: Beginning of the Ganghwa massacre, in the course of which an estimated 200-1,300 South Korean communist sympathizers are slaughtered.
First Indochina War: The Battle of Vĩnh Yên begins.
The catastrophic eruption of Mount Lamington in Papua New Guinea claims 2,942 lives.
Nuclear testing at the Nevada Test Site begins with Operation Ranger.
United Nations Security Council Resolution 90 relating to the Korean War is adopted.
The Canadian Army enters combat in the Korean War.

The Broker, a Pennsylvania Railroad passenger train derails near Woodbridge Township, New Jersey. The accident kills 85 people and injures over 500 more. The wreck is one of the worst rail disasters in American history.
Korean War: More than 700 suspected communist sympathizers are massacred by South Korean forces.
Korean War: The two-day Geochang massacre begins as a battalion of the 11th Division of the South Korean Army kills 719 unarmed citizens in Geochang, in the South Gyeongsang district of South Korea.

1952.event: NBC's long-running morning news program Today debuts, with host Dave Garroway.
Black Saturday in Egypt: rioters burn Cairo's central business district, targeting British and upper-class Egyptian businesses.

Elizabeth II becomes Queen of the United Kingdom and her other Realms and Territories and Head of the Commonwealth upon the death of her father, George VI. At the exact moment of succession, she was in a tree house at the Treetops Hotel in Kenya.
King George VI of the United Kingdom is buried in St George's Chapel, Windsor Castle.
Emmett Ashford becomes the first African-American umpire in organized baseball by being authorized to be a substitute umpire in the Southwestern International League.
The British government, under Winston Churchill, abolishes identity cards in the UK to "set the people free".
The Bengali Language Movement protests occur at the University of Dhaka in East Pakistan (now Bangladesh).
Vincent Massey is sworn in as the first Canadian-born Governor General of Canada.
Fulgencio Batista leads a successful coup in Cuba.
In Cilaos, Réunion, 1870 mm (73 inches) of rain falls in a 24-hour period, setting a new world record (March 15 through March 16).

1953.event: Sir Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay reached the summit of Mount Everest.
Frances P. Bolton and her son, Oliver from Ohio, become the first mother and son to serve simultaneously in the U.S. Congress.
The play Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett receives its première in Paris.

An article appears in Pravda accusing some of the most prestigious and prominent doctors, mostly Jews, in the Soviet Union of taking part in a vast plot to poison members of the top Soviet political and military leadership.
Josip Broz Tito is elected the first President of Yugoslavia.
Almost 72 percent of all television sets in the United States are tuned into I Love Lucy to watch Lucy give birth.
A North Sea flood causes over 1,800 deaths in the Netherlands and over 300 in the United Kingdom.
The Batepá massacre occurred in São Tomé when the colonial administration and Portuguese landowners unleashed a wave of violence against the native creoles known as forros.
Cold War: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower denies all appeals for clemency for Julius and Ethel Rosenberg.
Book censorship in the United States: The Georgia Literature Commission is established.

1954.event: India establishes its highest civilian awards, the Bharat Ratna and the Padma Vibhushan.
Georgetown-IBM experiment: The first public demonstration of a machine translation system is held in New York at the head office of IBM.
BOAC Flight 781, a de Havilland DH.106 Comet 1, explodes and falls into the Tyrrhenian Sea, killing 35 people.
The Hudson Motor Car Company merges with Nash-Kelvinator Corporation forming the American Motors Corporation.
In the United States, the National Negro Network is established with 40 charter member radio stations.
The first nuclear-powered submarine, the USS Nautilus, is launched in Groton, Connecticut by Mamie Eisenhower, the First Lady of the United States.
U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower warns against United States intervention in Vietnam.
Frank Selvy becomes the only NCAA Division I basketball player ever to score 100 points in a single game.
Canada and the United States agree to construct the Distant Early Warning Line, a system of radar stations in the far northern Arctic regions of Canada and Alaska.
The first Church of Scientology is established in Los Angeles.

1955.event: Rosa Parks refused to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, sparking the Civil Rights Movement.

Following the assassination of the Panamanian president José Antonio Remón Cantera, his deputy, José Ramón Guizado, takes power, but is quickly deposed after his involvement in Cantera's death is discovered.
Contralto Marian Anderson becomes the first person of color to perform at the Metropolitan Opera in Giuseppe Verdi's Un ballo in maschera.
The Government of Sindh, Pakistan, abolishes the Jagirdari system in the province. One million acres (4000 km2) of land thus acquired is to be distributed among the landless peasants.
Israel obtains four of the seven Dead Sea Scrolls.
Twenty-nine people are killed when Sabena Flight 503 crashes into Monte Terminillo near Rieti, Italy.
Operation Teapot: Teapot test shot "Wasp" is successfully detonated at the Nevada Test Site with a yield of 1.2 kilotons.  Wasp is the first of fourteen shots in the Teapot series.
Norodom Sihanouk, king of Cambodia, abdicates the throne in favor of his father, Norodom Suramarit.
An order to protect the endangered Saimaa ringed seal (Pusa hispida saimensis) was legalized.
The EOKA rebellion against the British Empire begins in Cyprus, with the goal of unifying with Greece.
The American Civil Liberties Union announces it will defend Allen Ginsberg's book Howl against obscenity charges.

1956.event: Sudan achieves independence from Egypt and the United Kingdom.
A fire damages the top part of the Eiffel Tower.
The Greek National Radical Union is formed by Konstantinos Karamanlis.
Operation Auca: Five U.S. missionaries are killed by the Huaorani of Ecuador shortly after making first contact.
Soviet Union cedes Porkkala back to Finland.
Elvis Presley makes his first national television appearance.
In the United States, Civil Rights Movement leader Martin Luther King Jr.'s home is bombed in retaliation for the Montgomery bus boycott.
The United States Merchant Marine Academy becomes a permanent Service Academy.
In his speech On the Cult of Personality and Its Consequences, Nikita Khrushchev, leader of the Soviet Union, denounces Stalin.
The International Air Transport Association finalizes a draft of the Radiotelephony spelling alphabet for the International Civil Aviation Organization.

1957.event: Sputnik 1, the first artificial satellite, was launched by the Soviet Union.
George Town, Penang, is made a city by a royal charter of Queen Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom.
Lèse majesté in Thailand is strengthened to include "insult" and changed to a crime against national security, after the Thai criminal code of 1956 went into effect.: 6, 18
The Hamilton Watch Company introduces the first electric watch.
In a speech given to the United States Congress, United States President Dwight D. Eisenhower announces the establishment of what will later be called the Eisenhower Doctrine.
British Prime Minister Sir Anthony Eden resigns from office following his failure to retake the Suez Canal from Egyptian sovereignty.
The African Convention is founded in Dakar, Senegal.
Kripalu Maharaj is named fifth Jagadguru (world teacher) after giving seven days of speeches before 500 Hindu scholars.
Israel withdraws from the Sinai Peninsula.
The New York City "Mad Bomber", George P. Metesky, is arrested in Waterbury, Connecticut and charged with planting more than 30 bombs.
American inventor Walter Frederick Morrison sells the rights to his flying disc to the Wham-O toy company, which later renames it the "Frisbee".

1958.event: The European Economic Community is established.
The West Indies Federation is formed.
Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite, launched by the Soviet Union in 1957, falls to Earth from orbit.
The Moroccan Army of Liberation ambushes a Spanish patrol in the Battle of Edchera.
Willie O'Ree, the first Black Canadian National Hockey League player, makes his NHL debut with the Boston Bruins.
After a general uprising and rioting in the streets, President Marcos Pérez Jiménez leaves Venezuela.
The Lego company patents the design of its Lego bricks, still compatible with bricks produced today.
Cold War: Space Race: The first successful American satellite detects the Van Allen radiation belt.
Founding of the Benelux Economic Union, creating a testing ground for a later European Economic Community.
Gamal Abdel Nasser is nominated to be the first president of the United Arab Republic.

1959.event: Cuban Revolution: Fulgencio Batista, dictator of Cuba, is overthrown by Fidel Castro's forces.
Luna 1, the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon and to orbit the Sun, is launched by the Soviet Union.
Alaska is admitted as the 49th U.S. state.
Luna 1 becomes the first spacecraft to reach the vicinity of the Moon.
The United States recognizes the new Cuban government of Fidel Castro.
Charles de Gaulle is proclaimed as the first President of the French Fifth Republic.
The Vega de Tera dam fails, triggering a disastrous flood that nearly destroys the town of Ribadelago and kills 144 residents.
Austral Líneas Aéreas Flight 205 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean near Astor Piazzolla International Airport in Mar del Plata, Argentina, killing 51.
The first Melodifestivalen is held in Cirkus, Stockholm, Sweden.
The forces of the Sultanate of Muscat occupy the last strongholds of the Imamate of Oman, Saiq and Shuraijah, marking the end of Jebel Akhdar War in Oman.

1960.event: Cameroon achieves independence from France and the United Kingdom.
National Airlines Flight 2511 is destroyed in mid-air by a bomb, while en route from New York City to Miami.
The Associations Law comes into force in Iraq, allowing registration of political parties.
President of Egypt Gamal Abdel Nasser opens construction on the Aswan Dam by detonating ten tons of dynamite to demolish twenty tons of granite on the east bank of the Nile.
The Reserve Bank of Australia, the country's central bank and banknote issuing authority authorized by the 1959 Reserve Bank Act, is established.
Capital Airlines Flight 20 crashes into a farm in Charles City County, Virginia, killing all 50 aboard, the third fatal Capital Airlines crash in as many years.
Japan and the United States sign the US-Japan Mutual Security Treaty
Scandinavian Airlines System Flight 871 crashes near Ankara Esenboğa Airport in Turkey, killing all 42 aboard.
Little Joe 1B, a Mercury spacecraft, lifts off from Wallops Island, Virginia with Miss Sam, a female rhesus monkey on board.
Avianca Flight 671 crashes at Montego Bay, Jamaica airport, killing 37 people.

1961.event: Yuri Gagarin became the first human to journey into outer space.
Cold War: After a series of economic retaliations against one another, the United States severs diplomatic relations with Cuba.
The SL-1 nuclear reactor is destroyed by a steam explosion in the only reactor incident in the United States to cause immediate fatalities.
A protest by agricultural workers in Baixa de Cassanje, Portuguese Angola, turns into a revolt, opening the Angolan War of Independence, the first of the Portuguese Colonial Wars.
In France a referendum supports Charles de Gaulle's policies in Algeria.
British authorities announce they have uncovered the Soviet Portland Spy Ring in London.
Throgs Neck Bridge over the East River, linking New York City's boroughs of The Bronx and Queens, opens to road traffic.

U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower delivers a televised farewell address to the nation three days before leaving office, in which he warns against the accumulation of power by the "military-industrial complex" as well as the dangers of massive spending, especially deficit spending.
Former Congolese Prime Minister Patrice Lumumba is murdered in circumstances suggesting the support and complicity of the governments of Belgium and the United States.
John F. Kennedy is inaugurated the 35th President of the United States of America, becoming the youngest man to be elected into that office, and the first Catholic.
The Portuguese luxury cruise ship Santa Maria is hijacked by opponents of the Estado Novo regime with the intention of waging war until dictator António de Oliveira Salazar is overthrown.

1962.event: The Cuban Missile Crisis ended as Soviet missiles were removed from Cuba.
John Glenn became the first American to orbit the Earth.
Western Samoa achieves independence from New Zealand; its name is changed to the Independent State of Western Samoa.
Pope John XXIII excommunicates Fidel Castro.
Apollo program: NASA announces plans to build the C-5 rocket launch vehicle, then known as the "Advanced Saturn", to carry human beings to the Moon.
Cold War: While tied to its pier in Polyarny, the Soviet submarine B-37 is destroyed when fire breaks out in its torpedo compartment.
An avalanche on Huascarán in Peru causes around 4,000 deaths.
Vietnam War: Operation Chopper, the first American combat mission in the war, takes place.
The Derveni papyrus, Europe's oldest surviving manuscript dating to 340 BC, is found in northern Greece.
Netherlands New Guinea Conflict: Indonesian Navy fast patrol boat RI Macan Tutul commanded by Commodore Yos Sudarso sunk in Arafura Sea by the Dutch Navy.
Ranger 3 is launched to study the Moon. The space probe later misses the moon by 22,000 miles (35,400 km).
French President Charles de Gaulle calls for Algeria to be granted independence.

1963.event: U.S. President John F. Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas.
Martin Luther King Jr. delivered his "I Have a Dream" speech in Washington, D.C.
Vietnam War: The Viet Cong wins its first major victory, at the Battle of Ap Bac.
Coup d'état in Togo results in the assassination of president Sylvanus Olympio.
The Chicago North Shore and Milwaukee Railroad ends operation.
The Élysée Treaty of cooperation between France and West Germany is signed by Charles de Gaulle and Konrad Adenauer.
The Guinea-Bissau War of Independence officially begins when PAIGC guerrilla fighters attack the Portuguese Army stationed in Tite.
The first inductees into the Pro Football Hall of Fame are announced.

The European Court of Justice's ruling in Van Gend en Loos v Nederlandse Administratie der Belastingen establishes the principle of direct effect, one of the most important, if not the most important, decisions in the development of European Union law.
The regime of Prime Minister of Iraq, Brigadier General Abd al-Karim Qasim is overthrown by the Ba'ath Party.
Construction begins on the Gateway Arch in St. Louis, Missouri.
The publication of Betty Friedan's The Feminine Mystique reawakens the feminist movement in the United States as women's organizations and consciousness raising groups spread.

1964.event: The Civil Rights Act was signed into law in the United States.
The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland is divided into the independent republics of Zambia and Malawi, and the British-controlled Rhodesia.
President Lyndon B. Johnson declares a "War on Poverty" in the United States.
Martyrs' Day: Several Panamanian youths try to raise the Panamanian flag in the U.S.-controlled Panama Canal Zone, leading to fighting between U.S. military and Panamanian civilians.

Surgeon General of the United States Dr. Luther Terry, M.D., publishes the landmark report Smoking and Health: Report of the Advisory Committee to the Surgeon General of the United States saying that smoking may be hazardous to health, sparking national and worldwide anti-smoking efforts.
Rebels in Zanzibar begin a revolt known as the Zanzibar Revolution and proclaim a republic.
Anti-Muslim riots break out in Calcutta, in response to anti-Hindu riots in East Pakistan. About one hundred people are killed.

In Manchester, New Hampshire, fourteen-year-old Pamela Mason is murdered. Edward Coolidge is tried and convicted of the crime, but the conviction is set aside by the landmark Fourth Amendment case Coolidge v. New Hampshire (1971).
The 24th Amendment to the United States Constitution, prohibiting the use of poll taxes in national elections, is ratified.
Blue Ribbon Sports, which would later become Nike, is founded by University of Oregon track and field athletes.
An unarmed United States Air Force T-39 Sabreliner on a training mission is shot down over Erfurt, East Germany, by a Soviet MiG-19.

1965.event: The People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan is founded in Kabul, Afghanistan.
South Vietnamese Prime Minister Trần Văn Hương is removed by the military junta of Nguyễn Khánh.
The current design of the Flag of Canada is chosen by an act of Parliament.
Eastern Air Lines Flight 663 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean and explodes, killing everyone aboard.
Vietnam War: The United States Marine Corps sends a MIM-23 Hawk missile battalion to South Vietnam, the first American troops in-country without an official advisory or training mission.
Malcolm X visits Smethwick near Birmingham following the racially-charged 1964 United Kingdom general election.
A new red-and-white maple leaf design is adopted as the flag of Canada, replacing the old Canadian Red Ensign banner.

Project Ranger: The Ranger 8 probe launches on its mission to photograph the Mare Tranquillitatis region of the Moon in preparation for the manned Apollo missions. Mare Tranquillitatis or the "Sea of Tranquility" would become the site chosen for the Apollo 11 lunar landing.
The Gambia becomes independent from the United Kingdom.

Colonel Phạm Ngọc Thảo of the Army of the Republic of Vietnam, and a communist spy of the North Vietnamese Viet Minh, along with Generals Lâm Văn Phát and Trần Thiện Khiêm, all Catholics, attempt a coup against the military junta of the Buddhist Nguyễn Khánh.

1966.event: Tashkent Declaration, a peace agreement between India and Pakistan signed that resolved the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.
Lyndon B. Johnson states that the United States should stay in South Vietnam until Communist aggression there is ended.
Robert C. Weaver becomes the first African American Cabinet member when he is appointed United States Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.
The First Nigerian Republic, led by Abubakar Tafawa Balewa is overthrown in a military coup d'état.

Palomares incident: A B-52 bomber collides with a KC-135 Stratotanker over Spain, killing seven airmen, and dropping three 70-kiloton nuclear bombs near the town of Palomares and another one into the sea.
Air India Flight 101 crashes into Mont Blanc.
The three Beaumont children disappear from a beach in Glenelg, South Australia, resulting in one of the country's largest-ever police investigations.
The Soviet Union launches the unmanned Luna 9 spacecraft as part of the Luna program.
Pakistan suggests a six-point agenda with Kashmir after the Indo-Pakistani War of 1965.
The Soviet Union's Luna 9 becomes the first spacecraft to make a soft landing on the Moon, and the first spacecraft to take pictures from the surface of the Moon.

1967.event: Ronald Reagan, past movie actor and future President of the United States, is sworn in as Governor of California.
Cultural Revolution: The Shanghai People's Commune is established following the seizure of power from local city officials by revolutionaries.
Vietnam War: United States Marine Corps and ARVN troops launch "Operation Deckhouse Five" in the Mekong River delta.
Dr. James Bedford becomes the first person to be cryonically preserved with intent of future resuscitation.
Counterculture of the 1960s: The Human Be-In takes place in San Francisco, California's Golden Gate Park, launching the Summer of Love.
The first Super Bowl is played in Los Angeles. The Green Bay Packers defeat the Kansas City Chiefs 35-10.
Albert DeSalvo, the "Boston Strangler", is convicted of numerous crimes and is sentenced to life imprisonment.
Between dozens and hundreds of anti-Somocista demonstrators are killed by the Nicaraguan National Guard in Managua.
Diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and Ivory Coast are established.

Milton Keynes (England) is founded as a new town by Order in Council, with a planning brief to become a city of 250,000 people. Its initial designated area enclosed three existing towns and twenty-one villages. The area to be developed was largely farmland, with evidence of continuous settlement dating back to the Bronze Age.

1968.event: Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis, Tennessee.
Alexander Dubček comes to power in Czechoslovakia, effectively beginning the "Prague Spring".
Surveyor Program: Surveyor 7, the last spacecraft in the Surveyor series, lifts off from launch complex 36A, Cape Canaveral.
Johnny Cash performs live at Folsom State Prison.
Vietnam War: Battle of Khe Sanh: One of the most publicized and controversial battles of the war begins.
A B-52 bomber crashes near Thule Air Base, contaminating the area after its nuclear payload ruptures. One of the four bombs remains unaccounted for after the cleanup operation is complete.
Apollo 5 lifts off carrying the first Lunar module into space.
Operation Igloo White, a US electronic surveillance system to stop communist infiltration into South Vietnam begins installation.
USS Pueblo (AGER-2) is attacked and seized by the Korean People's Navy.
Vietnam War: The 1st Australian Task Force launches Operation Coburg against the North Vietnamese Army and Viet Cong during wider fighting around Long Bình and Biên Hòa.
Vietnam War: Tet Offensive launch by forces of the Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army against South Vietnam, the United States, and their allies.

1969.event: Apollo 11 astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin became the first humans to land on the Moon.
The Woodstock Music Festival began in Bethel, New York.
The Stonewall riots began in New York City, sparking the modern LGBTQ+ rights movement.
The Venera 5 space probe is launched at 06:28:08 UTC from Baikonur.
Ariana Afghan Airlines Flight 701 crashes in Fernhill, West Sussex, while on approach to Gatwick Airport, killing 50 people.

The New York Jets of the American Football League defeat the Baltimore Colts of the National Football League to win Super Bowl III in what is considered to be one of the greatest upsets in sports history.
USS Enterprise fire: An accidental explosion aboard the USS Enterprise near Hawaii kills 28 people.
Czech student Jan Palach commits suicide by self-immolation in Prague, Czechoslovakia, in protest against the Soviets' crushing of the Prague Spring the year before.

Space Race: Soviet spacecraft Soyuz 4 and Soyuz 5 perform the first-ever docking of manned spacecraft in orbit, the first-ever transfer of crew from one space vehicle to another, and the only time such a transfer was accomplished with a space walk.
Black Panther Party members Bunchy Carter and John Huggins are killed during a meeting in Campbell Hall on the campus of UCLA.
United Airlines Flight 266 crashes into Santa Monica Bay killing all 32 passengers and six crew members.

Student Jan Palach dies after setting himself on fire three days earlier in Prague's Wenceslas Square to protest about the invasion of Czechoslovakia by the Soviet Union in 1968. His funeral turns into another major protest.

1970.event: The defined beginning of Unix time, at 00:00:00.

The 7.1 Mw  Tonghai earthquake shakes Tonghai County, Yunnan province, China, with a maximum Mercalli intensity of X (Extreme). Between 10,000 and 15,000 people are known to have been killed and about another 26,000 are injured.
Biafra capitulates, ending the Nigerian Civil War.
Nigerian Civil War: Biafran rebels surrender following an unsuccessful 32-month fight for independence from Nigeria.
Muammar Gaddafi is proclaimed premier of Libya.

The Boeing 747, the world's first "jumbo jet", enters commercial service for launch customer Pan American Airways with its maiden voyage from New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport to London Heathrow Airport.
Japan launches Ohsumi, becoming the fourth nation to put an object into orbit using its own booster.
Jeffrey R. MacDonald, United States Army captain, is charged with murder of his pregnant wife and two daughters.
The Chicago Seven are found not guilty of conspiring to incite riots at the 1968 Democratic National Convention.
Rhodesia declares itself a republic, breaking its last links with the British crown.

1971.event: Cigarette advertisements are banned on American television.
The second Ibrox disaster kills 66 fans at a Rangers-Celtic association football (soccer) match.

The Harrisburg Seven: Rev. Philip Berrigan and five other activists are indicted on charges of conspiring to kidnap Henry Kissinger and of plotting to blow up the heating tunnels of federal buildings in Washington, D.C.
The current Emley Moor transmitting station, the tallest free-standing structure in the United Kingdom, begins transmitting UHF broadcasts.
The Singapore Declaration, one of the two most important documents to the uncodified constitution of the Commonwealth of Nations, is issued.
Charles Manson and four "Family" members (three of them female) are found guilty of the 1969 Tate-LaBianca murders.
Idi Amin leads a coup deposing Milton Obote and becomes Uganda's president.
Apollo program: Apollo 14: Astronauts Alan Shepard, Stuart Roosa, and Edgar Mitchell, aboard a Saturn V, lift off for a mission to the Fra Mauro Highlands on the Moon.
The Winter Soldier Investigation, organized by the Vietnam Veterans Against the War to publicize war crimes and atrocities by Americans and allies in Vietnam, begins in Detroit.
Idi Amin replaces President Milton Obote as leader of Uganda.

1972.event: Rose Heilbron becomes the first female judge to sit at the Old Bailey in London, UK.
US President Richard Nixon announces the Space Shuttle program.
Iberia Flight 602 crashes near Ibiza Airport, killing all 104 people on board.

Bowing to international pressure, President of Pakistan Zulfikar Ali Bhutto releases Bengali leader Sheikh Mujibur Rahman from prison, who had been arrested after declaring the independence of Bangladesh.
Sheikh Mujibur Rahman returns to the newly independent Bangladesh as president after spending over nine months in prison in Pakistan.
Prime Minister Kofi Abrefa Busia and President Edward Akufo-Addo of Ghana are ousted in a bloodless military coup by Colonel Ignatius Kutu Acheampong.
Queen Margrethe II of Denmark ascends the throne, the first Queen of Denmark since 1412 and the first Danish monarch not named Frederick or Christian since 1513.
Members of the Mukti Bahini lay down their arms to the government of the newly independent Bangladesh, a month after winning the war against the occupying Pakistan Army.
Pakistan launches its nuclear weapons program, a few weeks after its defeat in the Bangladesh Liberation War, as well as the Indo-Pakistani War of 1971.

1973.event: The Paris Peace Accords were signed, intended to establish peace in Vietnam.
Denmark, Ireland and the United Kingdom are admitted into the European Economic Community.

In his second shooting spree of the week, Mark Essex fatally shoots seven people and wounds five others at Howard Johnson's Hotel in New Orleans, Louisiana, before being shot to death by police officers.
Soviet space mission Luna 21 is launched.
Watergate scandal: The trial of seven men accused of illegal entry into Democratic Party headquarters at Watergate begins.
Major League Baseball owners vote in approval of the American League adopting the designated hitter position.
Elvis Presley's concert Aloha from Hawaii is broadcast live via satellite, and sets the record as the most watched broadcast by an individual entertainer in television history.
Vietnam War: Citing progress in peace negotiations, President Richard Nixon announces the suspension of offensive action in North Vietnam.
Amílcar Cabral, leader of the independence movement in Guinea-Bissau and Cape Verde, is assassinated in Conakry, Guinea.
The Supreme Court of the United States delivers its decisions in Roe v. Wade and Doe v. Bolton, legalizing elective abortion in all fifty states.
The crew of Apollo 17 addresses a joint session of Congress after the completion of the final Apollo moon landing mission.

1974.event: United States President Richard Nixon signs a bill lowering the maximum U.S. speed limit to 55 MPH in order to conserve gasoline during an OPEC embargo.
In response to the 1973 oil crisis, daylight saving time commences nearly four months early in the United States.
A Disengagement of Forces agreement is signed between the Israeli and Egyptian governments, ending conflict on the Egyptian front of the Yom Kippur War.
China gains control over all the Paracel Islands after a military engagement between the naval forces of China and South Vietnam.
Turkish Airlines Flight 301 crashes during takeoff from Izmir Cumaovası Airport (now İzmir Adnan Menderes Airport), killing 66 of the 73 people on board the Fokker F28 Fellowship.
Pan Am Flight 806 crashes near Pago Pago International Airport in American Samoa, killing 97.
A fire in the 25-story Joelma Building in São Paulo, Brazil kills 189 and injures 293.
The Symbionese Liberation Army kidnaps Patty Hearst in Berkeley, California.

M62 coach bombing: The Provisional Irish Republican Army (IRA) explodes a bomb on a bus carrying off-duty British Armed Forces personnel in Yorkshire, England. Nine soldiers and three civilians are killed.
Grenada gains independence from the United Kingdom.

1975.event: Saigon fell, marking the end of the Vietnam War.
At the opening of a new railway line, a bomb blast at Samastipur, Bihar, India, fatally wounds Lalit Narayan Mishra, Minister of Railways.
The Federal Rules of Evidence are approved by the United States Congress.
This date overflowed the 12-bit field that had been used in the Decsystem 10 operating systems. There were numerous problems and crashes related to this bug while an alternative format was developed.
The Tasman Bridge in Tasmania, Australia, is struck by the bulk ore carrier Lake Illawarra, killing twelve people.
Ella T. Grasso becomes Governor of Connecticut, the first woman to serve as a Governor in the United States other than by succeeding her husband.
The Alvor Agreement is signed, ending the Angolan War of Independence and giving Angola independence from Portugal.
The Monitor National Marine Sanctuary is established as the first United States National Marine Sanctuary.
Haicheng earthquake (magnitude 7.3 on the Richter scale) occurs in Haicheng, Liaoning, China.
Riots break out in Lima, Peru after the police forces go on strike the day before. The uprising (locally known as the Limazo) is bloodily suppressed by the military dictatorship.
The Soyuz 17 Soviet spacecraft returns to Earth.

1976.event: The United States celebrated its Bicentennial.
A bomb explodes on board Middle East Airlines Flight 438 over Qaisumah, Saudi Arabia, killing all 81 people on board.

The Gale of January 1976 begins, resulting in coastal flooding around the southern North Sea coasts, affecting countries from Ireland to Yugoslavia and causing at least 82 deaths and US$1.3 billion in damage.
The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights, adopted by the United Nations General Assembly, comes into force.

The Troubles: The Ulster Volunteer Force shoots dead six Irish Catholic civilians in County Armagh, Northern Ireland. The next day, gunmen would shoot dead ten Protestant civilians nearby in retaliation.
The Khmer Rouge proclaim the Constitution of Democratic Kampuchea.

The Troubles: Gunmen shoot dead ten Protestant civilians after stopping their minibus at Kingsmill in County Armagh, Northern Ireland, UK, allegedly as retaliation for a string of attacks on Catholic civilians in the area by Loyalists, particularly the killing of six Catholics the night before.
The United Nations Security Council votes 11-1 to allow the Palestine Liberation Organization to participate in a Security Council debate (without voting rights).
Gerald Ford's would-be assassin, Sara Jane Moore, is sentenced to life in prison.
Lebanese Christian militias kill at least 1,000 in Karantina, Beirut.
Commercial service of Concorde begins with the London-Bahrain and Paris-Rio routes.

1977.event: Three bombs explode in Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union, within 37 minutes, killing seven. The bombings are attributed to an Armenian separatist group.
Japan Air Lines Cargo Flight 1045, a Douglas DC-8 jet, crashes onto the runway during takeoff from Ted Stevens Anchorage International Airport, killing five.
Linjeflyg Flight 618 crashes in Kälvesta near Stockholm Bromma Airport in Stockholm, Sweden, killing 22 people.
Capital punishment in the United States resumes after a ten-year hiatus, as convicted murderer Gary Gilmore is executed by firing squad in Utah.
Scientists identify a previously unknown bacterium as the cause of the mysterious Legionnaires' disease.
Australia's worst rail disaster occurs at Granville, Sydney, killing 83.
SFR Yugoslavia's Prime minister, Džemal Bijedić, his wife and six others are killed in a plane crash in Bosnia and Herzegovina.
President Gerald Ford pardons Iva Toguri D'Aquino (a.k.a. "Tokyo Rose").
The Atocha massacre occurs in Madrid during the Spanish transition to democracy.

1978.event: Air India Flight 855, a Boeing 747, crashes into the Arabian Sea off the coast of Bombay, India, due to instrument failure, spatial disorientation, and pilot error, killing all 213 people on board.

On the orders of the President of Pakistan, Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, paramilitary forces opened fire on peaceful protesting workers in Multan, Pakistan; it is known as 1978 massacre at Multan Colony Textile Mills.
United States Food and Drug Administration requires all blood donations to be labeled "paid" or "volunteer" donors.
The European Court of Human Rights finds the United Kingdom's government guilty of mistreating prisoners in Northern Ireland, but not guilty of torture.
The last Volkswagen Beetle made in Germany leaves VW's plant in Emden. Beetle production in Latin America continues until 2003.
Soviet satellite Kosmos 954, with a nuclear reactor on board, burns up in Earth's atmosphere, scattering radioactive debris over Canada's Northwest Territories. Only 1% is recovered.
The Crown of St. Stephen (also known as the Holy Crown of Hungary) goes on public display after being returned to Hungary from the United States, where it was held after World War II.
The Blizzard of 1978, one of the worst Nor'easters in New England history, hit the region, with sustained winds of 65 mph and snowfall of four inches an hour.
Proceedings of the United States Senate are broadcast on radio for the first time.
The Budd Company unveils its first SPV-2000 self-propelled railcar in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

1979.event: Normal diplomatic relations are established between the People's Republic of China and the United States.
Third Indochina War: Cambodian-Vietnamese War: Phnom Penh falls to the advancing Vietnamese troops, driving out Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge.
Iranian Revolution: The last Iranian Shah flees Iran with his family for good and relocates to Egypt.
Pope John Paul II starts his first official papal visits outside Italy to The Bahamas, Dominican Republic, and Mexico.
A Varig Boeing 707-323C freighter, flown by the same commander as Flight 820, disappears over the Pacific Ocean 30 minutes after taking off from Tokyo.
Iranian Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini returns to Tehran after nearly 15 years of exile.
Pluto moves inside Neptune's orbit for the first time since either was discovered.
The Iranian Revolution establishes an Islamic theocracy under the leadership of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.
An intense windstorm strikes western Washington and sinks a 0.5-mile (0.80 km) long section of the Hood Canal Bridge.
In Kabul, Setami Milli militants kidnap the American ambassador to Afghanistan, Adolph Dubs who is later killed during a gunfight between his kidnappers and police.

1980.event: U.S. President Jimmy Carter authorizes legislation giving $1.5 billion in loans to bail out the Chrysler Corporation.
Iran Air Flight 291 crashes in the Alborz Mountains while on approach to Mehrabad International Airport in Tehran, Iran, killing 128 people.
Mother Teresa is honored with India's highest civilian award, the Bharat Ratna.
Through cooperation between the U.S. and Canadian governments, six American diplomats secretly escape hostilities in Iran in the culmination of the Canadian Caper.
USCGC Blackthorn collides with the tanker Capricorn while leaving Tampa, Florida and capsizes, killing 23 Coast Guard crewmembers.
The Rubik's Cube makes its international debut at the Ideal Toy Corp. in Earl's Court, London.
Reports surface that the FBI is targeting allegedly corrupt Congressmen in the Abscam operation.
First winter ascent of Mount Everest by Krzysztof Wielicki and Leszek Cichy.
Miracle on Ice: In Lake Placid, New York, the United States hockey team defeats the Soviet Union hockey team 4-3.
Iran hostage crisis: Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini states that Iran's parliament will decide the fate of the American embassy hostages.

1981.event: MTV launched, marking a new era in music and television.
Greece is admitted into the European Community.
One of the largest investigations by a British police force ends when serial killer Peter Sutcliffe, the "Yorkshire Ripper", is arrested in Sheffield, South Yorkshire.
A local farmer reports a UFO sighting in Trans-en-Provence, France, claimed to be "perhaps the most completely and carefully documented sighting of all time".
Salvadoran Civil War: The FMLN launches its first major offensive, gaining control of most of Morazán and Chalatenango departments
Pope John Paul II receives a delegation from the Polish trade union Solidarity at the Vatican led by Lech Wałęsa.
President of the Philippines Ferdinand Marcos lifts martial law eight years and five months after declaring it.

Phil Smith and Phil Mayfield parachute off a Houston skyscraper, becoming the first two people to BASE jump from objects in all four categories: buildings, antennae, spans (bridges), and earth (cliffs).
Iran hostage crisis: United States and Iranian officials sign an agreement to release 52 American hostages after 14 months of captivity.
Twenty minutes after Ronald Reagan is inaugurated as the 40th President of the United States of America, Iran releases 52 American hostages.
Production of the iconic DeLorean sports car begins in Dunmurry, Northern Ireland, United Kingdom.

1982.event: Peruvian Javier Pérez de Cuéllar becomes the first Latin American to hold the title of Secretary-General of the United Nations.
Breakup of the Bell System: In the United States, AT&T agrees to divest itself of twenty-two subdivisions.
Shortly after takeoff, Air Florida Flight 90, a Boeing 737 jet, crashes into Washington, D.C.'s 14th Street Bridge and falls into the Potomac River, killing 78 including four motorists.
US Army general James L. Dozier is rescued by Italian anti-terrorism forces from captivity by the Red Brigades.
Richard Skrenta writes the first PC virus code, which is 400 lines long and disguised as an Apple boot program called "Elk Cloner".
Hama massacre: The government of Syria attacks the town of Hama.
Japan Air Lines Flight 350 crashes near Haneda Airport in an attempted pilot mass murder-suicide, killing 24 of the 174 people on board.
The drilling rig Ocean Ranger sinks during a storm off the coast of Newfoundland, killing 84 workers.
Soviet probe Venera 14 lands on Venus.
The South African government bombs the headquarters of the African National Congress in London.

1983.event: The ARPANET officially changes to using TCP/IP, the Internet Protocol, effectively creating the Internet.
Turkish Airlines Flight 158 crashes at Ankara Esenboğa Airport in Ankara, Turkey, killing 47 and injuring 20.
The International Olympic Committee restores Jim Thorpe's Olympic medals to his family.
Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie is arrested in Bolivia.
The Apple Lisa, the first commercial personal computer from Apple Inc. to have a graphical user interface and a computer mouse, is announced.
The pilot shaft of the Seikan Tunnel, the world's longest sub-aqueous tunnel (53.85 km) between the Japanese islands of Honshū and Hokkaidō, breaks through.

Singapore cable car crash: Panamanian-registered oil rig, Eniwetok, strikes the cables of the Singapore Cable Car system linking the mainland and Sentosa Island, causing two cabins to fall into the water and killing seven people and leaving thirteen others trapped for hours.

The Melbourne dust storm hits Australia's second largest city. The result of the worst drought on record and a day of severe weather conditions, a 320 metres (1,050 ft) deep dust cloud envelops the city, turning day to night.
Irish race horse Shergar is stolen by gunmen.

One hundred women protest in Lahore, Pakistan against military dictator Zia-ul-Haq's proposed Law of Evidence. The women were tear-gassed, baton-charged and thrown into lock-up. The women were successful in repealing the law.

1984.event: The original American Telephone & Telegraph Company is divested of its 22 Bell System companies as a result of the settlement of the 1974 United States Department of Justice antitrust suit against AT&T.
Brunei becomes independent of the United Kingdom.
Brunei becomes the sixth member of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN).

Holy See-United States relations: The United States and Holy See (Vatican City) re-establish full diplomatic relations after almost 117 years, overturning the United States Congress's 1867 ban on public funding for such a diplomatic envoy.
The Apple Macintosh, the first consumer computer to popularize the computer mouse and the graphical user interface, is introduced during a Super Bowl XVIII television commercial.
Apple Computer places the Macintosh personal computer on sale in the United States.
Tropical Storm Domoina makes landfall in southern Mozambique, eventually causing 214 deaths and some of the most severe flooding so far recorded in the region.
Doctor John Buster and a research team at Harbor-UCLA Medical Center in the United States announce history's first embryo transfer, from one woman to another resulting in a live birth.
Space Shuttle program: STS-41-B is launched using Space Shuttle Challenger.
Space Shuttle program: STS-41-B Mission: Astronauts Bruce McCandless II and Robert L. Stewart make the first untethered space walk using the Manned Maneuvering Unit (MMU).

1985.event: The wreck of the RMS Titanic was discovered on the ocean floor.
The first British mobile phone call is made by Michael Harrison to his father Sir Ernest Harrison, chairman of Vodafone.

Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency launches Sakigake, Japan's first interplanetary spacecraft and the first deep space probe to be launched by any country other than the United States or the Soviet Union.

Sandinista Daniel Ortega becomes president of Nicaragua and vows to continue the transformation to socialism and alliance with the Soviet Union and Cuba; American policy continues to support the Contras in their revolt against the Nicaraguan government.
A passenger train plunges into a ravine in Ethiopia, killing 428 in the worst railroad disaster in Africa.
Galaxy Airlines Flight 203 crashes near Reno-Tahoe International Airport in Reno, Nevada, killing 70 people.
World Airways Flight 30H overshoots the runway at Logan International Airport in Boston, Massachusetts, and crashes into Boston Harbor. Two people are presumed dead.
Supergroup USA for Africa (United Support of Artists for Africa) records the hit single We Are the World, to help raise funds for Ethiopian famine relief.
Ugo Vetere, then the mayor of Rome, and Chedli Klibi, then the mayor of Carthage, meet in Tunis to sign a treaty of friendship officially ending the Third Punic War which lasted 2,131 years.
William J. Schroeder becomes the first recipient of an artificial heart to leave the hospital.

1986.event: The Chernobyl nuclear disaster occurred in the Soviet Union.
The Gateway Bridge, Brisbane, Queensland, Australia is officially opened.
Space Shuttle program: NASA Administrator Bill Nelson lifts off from Kennedy Space Center aboard Columbia on mission STS-61-C as a payload specialist.
A month-long violent struggle begins in Aden, South Yemen between supporters of Ali Nasir Muhammad and Abdul Fattah Ismail, resulting in thousands of casualties.

The first IBM PC computer virus is released into the wild. A boot sector virus dubbed (c)Brain, it was created by the Farooq Alvi Brothers in Lahore, Pakistan, reportedly to deter unauthorized copying of the software they had written.
In the United States, Martin Luther King Jr. Day is celebrated as a federal holiday for the first time.

The Rock and Roll Hall of Fame inducts its first members: Little Richard, Chuck Berry, James Brown, Ray Charles, Sam Cooke, Fats Domino, The Everly Brothers, Buddy Holly, Jerry Lee Lewis and Elvis Presley.
The Voyager 2 space probe makes its closest approach to Uranus.
The National Resistance Movement topples the government of Tito Okello in Uganda.
The Ugandan government of Tito Okello is overthrown by the National Resistance Army, led by Yoweri Museveni.
Space Shuttle program: STS-51-L mission: Space Shuttle Challenger disintegrates after liftoff, killing all seven astronauts on board.

1987.event: The Isleta Pueblo tribe elect Verna Williamson to be their first female governor.
The Maryland train collision: An Amtrak train en route to Boston from Washington, D.C., collides with Conrail engines in Chase, Maryland, United States, killing 16 people.
Philippine security forces open fire on a crowd of 10,000-15,000 demonstrators at Malacañang Palace, Manila, killing 13.
Mohammed Said Hersi Morgan sends a "letter of death" to Somali President Siad Barre, proposing the genocide of the Isaaq people.
After the 1986 People Power Revolution, the Philippines enacts a new constitution.
Justice Mary Gaudron becomes the first woman to be appointed to the High Court of Australia.
Supernova 1987a is seen in the Large Magellanic Cloud.
Iran-Contra affair: The Tower Commission rebukes President Ronald Reagan for not controlling his national security staff.
The British ferry MS Herald of Free Enterprise capsizes in about 90 seconds, killing 193.
Lieyu massacre: Taiwanese military massacre of 19 unarmed Vietnamese refugees at Donggang, Lieyu, Kinmen.

1988.event: The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America comes into existence, creating the largest Lutheran denomination in the United States.
Lee Teng-hui becomes the first native Taiwanese President of the Republic of China.
China Southwest Airlines Flight 4146 crashes near Chongqing Jiangbei International Airport, killing all 98 passengers and 10 crew members.
In R v Morgentaler the Supreme Court of Canada strikes down all anti-abortion laws.
Doug Williams becomes the first African-American quarterback to play in a Super Bowl and leads the Washington Redskins to victory in Super Bowl XXII.
Manuel Noriega is indicted on drug smuggling and money laundering charges.
Michael Jordan makes his signature slam dunk from the free throw line inspiring Air Jordan and the Jumpman logo.

Cold War: The 1988 Black Sea bumping incident: The U.S. missile cruiser USS Yorktown (CG-48) is intentionally rammed by the Soviet frigate Bezzavetnyy in the Soviet territorial waters, while Yorktown claims innocent passage.
The Nagorno-Karabakh Autonomous Oblast votes to secede from Azerbaijan and join Armenia, triggering the First Nagorno-Karabakh War.
Saddam Hussein begins the Anfal genocide against Kurds and Assyrians in northern Iraq.

1989.event: The Berlin Wall fell, marking a symbolic end to the Cold War.
The Tiananmen Square protests were suppressed by the Chinese government.
Tim Berners-Lee proposed the World Wide Web.
The Montreal Protocol comes into force, stopping the use of chemicals contributing to ozone depletion.
Second Gulf of Sidra incident: A pair of Libyan MiG-23 "Floggers" are shot down by a pair of US Navy F-14 Tomcats during an air-to-air confrontation.
Satwant Singh and Kehar Singh are sentenced to death for conspiracy in the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi; the two men are executed the same day.
Kegworth air disaster: British Midland Flight 92, a Boeing 737-400, crashes into the M1 motorway, killing 47 of the 126 people on board.
Notorious serial killer Ted Bundy, with over 30 known victims, is executed by the electric chair at the Florida State Prison.
Cold War: Hungary establishes diplomatic relations with South Korea, making it the first Eastern Bloc nation to do so.
The American embassy in Kabul, Afghanistan is closed.
Soviet-Afghan War: The last Soviet armoured column leaves Kabul.
After a stroke two weeks previously, South African President P. W. Botha resigns as leader of the National Party, but stays on as president for six more months.
A military coup overthrows Alfredo Stroessner, dictator of Paraguay since 1954.

1990.event: Nelson Mandela was released from prison after 27 years in South Africa.
David Dinkins is sworn in as New York City's first black mayor.
United States invasion of Panama: Manuel Noriega, former leader of Panama, surrenders to American forces.
In Pakistan's deadliest train accident an overloaded passenger train collides with an empty freight train, resulting in 307 deaths and 700 injuries.
Time Warner is formed by the merger of Time Inc. and Warner Communications.
A seven-day pogrom breaks out against the Armenian civilian population of Baku, Azerbaijan, during which Armenians were beaten, tortured, murdered, and expelled from the city.
Douglas Wilder becomes the first elected African American governor as he takes office as Governor of Virginia in Richmond, Virginia.
Washington, D.C. Mayor Marion Barry is arrested for drug possession in an FBI sting.
Protests in Azerbaijan, part of the Dissolution of the Soviet Union.

Japan launches Hiten, the country's first lunar probe, the first robotic lunar probe since the Soviet Union's Luna 24 in 1976, and the first lunar probe launched by a country other than Soviet Union or the United States.
Avianca Flight 52 crashes in Cove Neck, New York, killing 73.

1991.event: The Soviet Union was officially dissolved.
Sharon Pratt Dixon becomes the first African American woman mayor of a major city and first woman Mayor of the District of Columbia.
Georgian forces enter Tskhinvali, the capital of South Ossetia, Georgia, opening the 1991-92 South Ossetia War.
Somali Civil War: The United States Embassy to Somalia in Mogadishu is evacuated by helicopter airlift days after the outbreak of violence in Mogadishu.
Roger Lafontant, former leader of the Tonton Macoute in Haiti under François Duvalier, attempts a coup d'état, which ends in his arrest.
Representatives from the United States and Iraq meet at the Geneva Peace Conference to try to find a peaceful resolution to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait.
Persian Gulf War: An act of the U.S. Congress authorizes the use of American military force to drive Iraq out of Kuwait.
Soviet Union troops attack Lithuanian independence supporters in Vilnius, killing 14 people and wounding around 1,000 others.
The United Nations deadline for the withdrawal of Iraqi forces from occupied Kuwait expires, preparing the way for the start of Operation Desert Storm.
Elizabeth II, in her capacity as Queen of Australia, signs letters patent allowing Australia to become the first Commonwealth realm to institute its own Victoria Cross in its honours system.
Coalition Forces go to war with Iraq, beginning the Gulf War.

1992.event: CommutAir Flight 4821 crashes on approach to Adirondack Regional Airport, in Saranac Lake, New York, killing two people.
President of Georgia Zviad Gamsakhurdia flees the country as a result of the military coup.
The Assembly of the Serb People in Bosnia and Herzegovina proclaims the creation of Republika Srpska, a new state within Yugoslavia.
The first discoveries of extrasolar planets are announced by astronomers Aleksander Wolszczan and Dale Frail. They discovered two planets orbiting the pulsar PSR 1257+12.
El Salvador officials and rebel leaders sign the Chapultepec Peace Accords in Mexico City, Mexico ending the 12-year Salvadoran Civil War that claimed at least 75,000 lives.
During a visit to South Korea, Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa apologizes for forcing Korean women into sexual slavery during World War II.
Air Inter Flight 148, an Airbus A320-111, crashes into a mountain near Strasbourg, France, killing 87 of the 96 people on board.
Rebel forces occupy Zaire's national radio station in Kinshasa and broadcast a demand for the government's resignation.
Space Shuttle program: The space shuttle Discovery launches on STS-42 carrying Dr. Roberta Bondar, who becomes the first Canadian woman and the first neurologist in space.
The Chief Judicial Magistrate of Bhopal court declares Warren Anderson, ex-CEO of Union Carbide, a fugitive under Indian law for failing to appear in the Bhopal disaster case.

1993.event: Dissolution of Czechoslovakia: Czechoslovakia is divided into the Czech Republic and Slovak Republic.
Sri Lankan Civil War: The Sri Lanka Navy kill 35-100 civilians on the Jaffna Lagoon.
In Moscow, Russia, George H. W. Bush and Boris Yeltsin sign the second Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (START).
The oil tanker MV Braer runs aground on the coast of the Shetland Islands, spilling 84,700 tons of crude oil.
Indian Border Security Force units kill 55 Kashmiri civilians in Sopore, Jammu and Kashmir, in revenge after militants ambushed a BSF patrol.
Four people are killed when Lufthansa CityLine Flight 5634 crashes on approach to Charles de Gaulle Airport in Roissy-en-France, France.
The Fourth Republic of Ghana is inaugurated with Jerry Rawlings as president.
Bosnian War: The Bosnian Army executes a surprise attack at the village of Kravica in Srebrenica.
Space Shuttle program: Endeavour heads for space for the third time as STS-54 launches from the Kennedy Space Center.
The Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC) is signed.

1994.event: The Zapatista Army of National Liberation initiates twelve days of armed conflict in the Mexican state of Chiapas.
The North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) comes into effect.
Baikal Airlines Flight 130 crashes near Mamoney, Irkutsk, Russia, resulting in 125 deaths.
American figure skater Nancy Kerrigan is attacked and injured by an assailant hired by her rival Tonya Harding's ex-husband during the U.S. Figure Skating Championships.
A British Aerospace Jetstream 41 operating as United Express Flight 6291 crashes in Gahanna, Ohio, killing five of the eight people on board.
Russian cosmonaut Valeri Polyakov on Soyuz TM-18 leaves for Mir. He would stay on the space station until March 22, 1995, for a record 437 days in space.
The Irish Government announces the end of a 15-year broadcasting ban on the IRA and its political arm Sinn Féin.
The 6.7 Mw  Northridge earthquake shakes the Greater Los Angeles Area with a maximum Mercalli intensity of IX (Violent), leaving 57 people dead and more than 8,700 injured.
The spacecraft Clementine by BMDO and NASA is launched.
Space Shuttle program: STS-60 is launched, carrying Sergei Krikalev, the first Russian cosmonaut to fly aboard the Shuttle.

1995.event: The World Trade Organization comes into being.
The Draupner wave in the North Sea in Norway is detected, confirming the existence of freak waves.
Austria, Finland and Sweden join the EU.
A chemical fire in an apartment complex in Manila, Philippines, leads to the discovery of plans for Project Bojinka, a mass-terrorist attack.
An avalanche hits the Icelandic village Súðavík, destroying 25 homes and burying 26 people, 14 of whom died.
The 6.9 Mw  Great Hanshin earthquake shakes the southern Hyōgo Prefecture with a maximum Shindo of VII, leaving 5,502-6,434 people dead, and 251,301-310,000 displaced.
After being struck by lightning the crew of Bristow Helicopters Flight 56C are forced to ditch. All 18 aboard are later rescued.
Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Beit Lid suicide bombing: In central Israel, near Netanya, two Gazans blow themselves up at a military transit point, killing 19 Israeli soldiers.
The Norwegian rocket incident: Russia almost launches a nuclear attack after it mistakes Black Brant XII, a Norwegian research rocket, for a US Trident missile.
Hydroxycarbamide becomes the first approved preventive treatment for sickle cell disease.

1996.event: An Antonov An-32 cargo aircraft crashes into a crowded market in Kinshasa, Zaire, killing up to 223 people on the ground; two of six crew members are also killed.

First Chechen War: Chechen separatists launch a raid against the helicopter airfield and later a civilian hospital in the city of Kizlyar in the neighboring Dagestan, which turns into a massive hostage crisis involving thousands of civilians.
The Czech Republic applies for membership in the European Union.
The barge North Cape oil spill occurs as an engine fire forces the tugboat Scandia ashore on Moonstone Beach in South Kingstown, Rhode Island.
Billy Bailey becomes the last person to be hanged in the United States.
In a military coup, Colonel Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara deposes the first democratically elected president of Niger, Mahamane Ousmane.
Germany first observes the International Holocaust Remembrance Day.
President Jacques Chirac announces a "definitive end" to French nuclear weapons testing.
An explosives-filled truck rams into the gates of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka in Colombo, killing at least 86 people and injuring 1,400.
The Communications Decency Act is passed by the U.S. Congress.

1997.event: Hong Kong was handed over from the United Kingdom to China.
Comair Flight 3272 crashes in Raisinville Township in Monroe County, Michigan, killing 29 people.

Space Shuttle program: Atlantis launches from the Kennedy Space Center on mission STS-81 to the Russian space station Mir, carrying astronaut Jerry M. Linenger for a four-month stay on board the station, replacing astronaut John E. Blaha.
Cape Canaveral Air Force Station: A Delta II carrying the GPS IIR-1 satellite explodes 13 seconds after launch, dropping 250 tons of burning rocket remains around the launch pad.
Yasser Arafat returns to Hebron after more than 30 years and joins celebrations over the handover of the last Israeli-controlled West Bank city.
The U.S. House of Representatives votes 395-28 to reprimand Newt Gingrich for ethics violations, making him the first Speaker of the House to be so disciplined.
Madeleine Albright becomes the first woman to serve as United States Secretary of State.
En route to Lebanon, two Israeli Sikorsky CH-53 troop-transport helicopters collide in mid-air over northern Galilee, Israel, killing 73.
The Bojnurd earthquake measuring Mw  6.5 strikes Iran. With a Mercalli intensity of VIII, it kills at least 88 and damages 173 villages.
The so-called Big Three banks in Switzerland announce the creation of a $71 million fund to aid Holocaust survivors and their families.
Space Shuttle Discovery is launched on a mission to service the Hubble Space Telescope.

1998.event: Following a currency reform, Russia begins to circulate new rubles to stem inflation and promote confidence.
A massive ice storm hits eastern Canada and the northeastern United States, continuing through January 10 and causing widespread destruction.
Over 100 people are killed in the Sidi-Hamed massacre in Algeria.
Nineteen European nations agree to forbid human cloning.
Alfredo Ormando sets himself on fire in St. Peter's Square, protesting against homophobia.
Clinton-Lewinsky scandal: Matt Drudge breaks the story of the Bill Clinton-Monica Lewinsky affair on his Drudge Report website.
Space Shuttle program: space shuttle Endeavour launches on STS-89 to dock with the Russian space station Mir.
Netscape announces Mozilla, with the intention to release Communicator code as open source.
During a historic visit to Cuba, Pope John Paul II demands political reforms and the release of political prisoners while condemning US attempts to isolate the country.
A suicide attack by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam on Sri Lanka's Temple of the Tooth kills eight and injures 25 others.

1999.event: Euro currency is introduced in 11 member nations of the European Union (with the exception of the United Kingdom, Denmark, Greece and Sweden; Greece adopts the euro two years later).
The Mars Polar Lander is launched by NASA.
Former professional wrestler Jesse Ventura is sworn in as governor of Minnesota, United States.
The Senate trial in the impeachment of U.S. President Bill Clinton begins.
British Aerospace agrees to acquire the defence subsidiary of the General Electric Company plc, forming BAE Systems in November 1999.
War on Drugs: In one of the largest drug busts in American history, the United States Coast Guard intercepts a ship with over 4,300 kilograms (9,500 lb) of cocaine on board.
Australian missionary Graham Staines and his two sons are burned alive by radical Hindus while sleeping in their car in Eastern India.
A 6.0 magnitude earthquake hits western Colombia killing at least 1,000.
Unarmed West African immigrant Amadou Diallo is shot 41 times by four plainclothes New York City police officers on an unrelated stake-out, inflaming race relations in the city.
Crown Prince Abdullah becomes the King of Jordan on the death of his father, King Hussein.

2000.event: The world celebrated the beginning of the new millennium.
A Norwegian passenger train departing from Trondheim, collides with a local train coming from Hamar in Åsta, Åmot; 19 people are killed and 68 injured in the accident.
The last natural Pyrenean ibex, Celia, is killed by a falling tree, thus making the species extinct.
Crossair Flight 498, a Saab 340 aircraft, crashes in Niederhasli, Switzerland, after taking off from Zurich Airport, killing 13 people.

Ecuador: After the Ecuadorian Congress is seized by indigenous organizations, Col. Lucio Gutiérrez, Carlos Solorzano and Antonio Vargas depose President Jamil Mahuad. Gutierrez is later replaced by Gen. Carlos Mendoza, who resigns and allows Vice-President Gustavo Noboa to succeed Mahuad.
Kenya Airways Flight 431 crashes into the Atlantic Ocean off the coast of Ivory Coast, killing 169.
Alaska Airlines Flight 261 crash: An MD-83, experiencing horizontal stabilizer problems, crashes in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of Point Mugu, California, killing all 88 aboard.
First digital cinema projection in Europe (Paris) realized by Philippe Binant with the DLP CINEMA technology developed by Texas Instruments.

The World Summit Against Cancer for the New Millennium, Charter of Paris is signed by the President of France, Jacques Chirac and the Director General of UNESCO, Koichiro Matsuura, initiating World Cancer Day which is held on February 4 every year.
Russian forces massacre at least 60 civilians in the Novye Aldi suburb of Grozny, Chechnya.
Second Chechen War: Russia captures Grozny, Chechnya, forcing the separatist Chechen Republic of Ichkeria government into exile.

2001.event: Terrorist attacks were carried out on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon in the United States.
Downtown Disney opens to the public as part of the Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, California.
An earthquake hits El Salvador, killing more than 800.
Wikipedia, a free wiki content encyclopedia, goes online.
Second Congo War: Congolese President Laurent-Désiré Kabila is assassinated by one of his own bodyguards in Kinshasa.
US President Bill Clinton awards former President Theodore Roosevelt a posthumous Medal of Honor for his service in the Spanish-American War.
President of the Philippines Joseph Estrada is ousted in a nonviolent four-day revolution, and is succeeded by Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

Five people attempt to set themselves on fire in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, an act that many people later claim is staged by the Communist Party of China to frame Falun Gong and thus escalate their persecution.
The 7.7 Mw Gujarat earthquake shakes Western India, leaving 13,805-20,023 dead and about 166,800 injured.
Thousands of student protesters in Indonesia storm parliament and demand that President Abdurrahman Wahid resign due to alleged involvement in corruption scandals.
In the Netherlands, a Scottish court convicts Libyan Abdelbaset al-Megrahi and acquits another Libyan citizen for their part in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988.

2002.event: Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Israeli forces seize the Palestinian freighter Karine A in the Red Sea, finding 50 tons of weapons.
President of the United States George W. Bush signs into law the No Child Left Behind Act.
War in Afghanistan: The UN Security Council unanimously establishes an arms embargo and the freezing of assets of Osama bin Laden, al-Qaeda, and the remaining members of the Taliban.
Mount Nyiragongo erupts in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, displacing an estimated 400,000 people.
The Sierra Leone Civil War is declared over.
Kmart becomes the largest retailer in United States history to file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
U.S. journalist Daniel Pearl is kidnapped in Karachi, Pakistan and subsequently murdered.
An explosion at a military storage facility in Lagos, Nigeria, kills at least 1,100 people and displaces over 20,000 others.
TAME Flight 120, a Boeing 727-100, crashes in the Andes mountains in southern Colombia, killing 94.
In his State of the Union address, President George W. Bush describes "regimes that sponsor terror" as an Axis of evil, in which he includes Iraq, Iran and North Korea.

2003.event: Space Shuttle Columbia disintegrated upon re-entry, killing all seven astronauts.
Turkish Airlines Flight 634 crashes near Diyarbakır Airport, Turkey, killing the entire crew and 70 of the 75 passengers.
Air Midwest Flight 5481 crashes at Charlotte-Douglas Airport, in Charlotte, North Carolina, killing all 21 people on board.
Illinois Governor George Ryan commutes the death sentences of 167 prisoners on Illinois's death row based on the Jon Burge scandal.
The Space Shuttle Columbia takes off for mission STS-107 which would be its final one. Columbia disintegrated 16 days later on re-entry.
A bushfire kills four people and destroys more than 500 homes in Canberra, Australia.
A 7.6 magnitude earthquake strikes the Mexican state of Colima, killing 29 and leaving approximately 10,000 people homeless.
A very weak signal from Pioneer 10 is detected for the last time, but no usable data can be extracted.
The United States Department of Homeland Security officially begins operation.
Invasion of Iraq: A group of people leave London, England, for Baghdad, Iraq, to serve as human shields, intending to prevent the U.S.-led coalition troops from bombing certain locations.
The first selections for the National Recording Registry are announced by the Library of Congress.

2004.event: A massive tsunami struck Southeast Asia following a 9.1 magnitude earthquake.

In a vote of confidence, General Pervez Musharraf wins 658 out of 1,170 votes in the Electoral College of Pakistan, and according to Article 41(8) of the Constitution of Pakistan, is "deemed to be elected" to the office of President until October 2007.
Stardust successfully flies past Comet Wild 2, collecting samples that are returned to Earth.
Flash Airlines Flight 604 crashes into the Red Sea, resulting in 148 deaths, making it one of the deadliest aviation accidents in Egyptian history.
Spirit, a NASA Mars rover, lands successfully on Mars at 04:35 UTC.
Mikheil Saakashvili is elected President of Georgia following the November 2003 Rose Revolution.
The RMS Queen Mary 2, then the largest ocean liner ever built, is christened by her namesake's granddaughter, Queen Elizabeth II.

An inflatable boat carrying illegal Albanian emigrants stalls near the Karaburun Peninsula en route to Brindisi, Italy; exposure to the elements kills 28. This is the second deadliest marine disaster in Albanian history.
The world's largest ocean liner, RMS Queen Mary 2, makes its maiden voyage.
The national flag of the Republic of Georgia, the so-called "five cross flag", is restored to official use after a hiatus of some 500 years.
NASA's MER-A (the Mars Rover Spirit) ceases communication with mission control. The problem lies in the management of its flash memory and is fixed remotely from Earth on February 6.

2005.event: Hurricane Katrina made landfall on the Gulf Coast of the United States.
The dwarf planet Eris is discovered by Palomar Observatory-based astronomers, later motivating the International Astronomical Union (IAU) to define the term planet for the first time.
American Civil Rights Movement: Edgar Ray Killen is indicted for the 1964 murders of Chaney, Goodman, and Schwerner.
A train collision in Graniteville, South Carolina, United States, releases about 60 tons of chlorine gas.
The nuclear sub USS San Francisco collides at full speed with an undersea mountain south of Guam. One man is killed, but the sub surfaces and is repaired.
Mahmoud Abbas wins the election to succeed Yasser Arafat as President of the Palestinian National Authority, replacing interim president Rawhi Fattouh.
The Sudan People's Liberation Movement and the Government of Sudan sign the Comprehensive Peace Agreement to end the Second Sudanese Civil War.
Deep Impact launches from Cape Canaveral on a Delta II rocket.
ESA's SMART-1 lunar orbiter discovers elements such as calcium, aluminum, silicon, iron, and other surface elements on the Moon.
The Airbus A380, the world's largest commercial jet, is unveiled at a ceremony in Toulouse, France
In Belmopan, Belize, the unrest over the government's new taxes erupts into riots.

2006.event: Ehud Olmert becomes acting Prime Minister of Israel after the incumbent, Ariel Sharon, suffers a second, apparently more serious stroke.
A stampede during the Stoning of the Devil ritual on the last day at the Hajj in Mina, Saudi Arabia, kills at least 362 Muslim pilgrims.
Ellen Johnson Sirleaf is sworn in as Liberia's new president. She becomes Africa's first female elected head of state.
Evo Morales is inaugurated as President of Bolivia, becoming the country's first indigenous president.
Mexican professional wrestler Juana Barraza is arrested in connection with the serial killing of at least ten elderly women.
The roof of one of the buildings at the Katowice International Fair in Poland collapses due to the weight of snow, killing 65 and injuring more than 170 others.
Stephen Harper becomes Prime Minister of Canada.
The last Mobile army surgical hospital (MASH) is decommissioned by the United States Army.
A massive mudslide occurs in Southern Leyte, Philippines; the official death toll is set at 1,126.
A methane explosion in a coal mine near Nueva Rosita, Mexico, kills 65 miners.

2007.event: Apple CEO Steve Jobs unveiled the first iPhone.
Bulgaria and Romania join the EU.
Adam Air Flight 574 breaks apart in mid-air and crashes near the Makassar Strait, Indonesia, killing all 102 people on board.
The 110th United States Congress convenes, electing Nancy Pelosi as the first female Speaker of the House in U.S. history.
Apple CEO Steve Jobs introduces the original iPhone at a Macworld keynote in San Francisco.
A general strike begins in Guinea in an attempt to get President Lansana Conté to resign.
Comet C/2006 P1 (McNaught), one of the brightest comets ever observed is at its zenith visible during the day.
The Doomsday Clock is set to five minutes to midnight in response to North Korea's nuclear testing.

The strongest storm in the United Kingdom in 17 years kills 14 people and Germany sees the worst storm since 1999 with 13 deaths. Cyclone Kyrill causes at least 44 deaths across 20 countries in Western Europe.
Turkish-Armenian journalist Hrant Dink is assassinated in front of his newspaper's Istanbul office by 17-year-old Turkish ultra-nationalist Ogün Samast.

Four-man Team N2i, using only skis and kites, completes a 1,093-mile (1,759 km) trek to reach the Antarctic pole of inaccessibility for the first time since 1965 and for the first time ever without mechanical assistance.

2008.event: Barack Obama was elected as the first African-American President of the United States.
A Let L-410 Turbolet crashes in the Los Roques Archipelago in Venezuela, killing 14 people.
The Euphronios Krater is unveiled in Rome after being returned to Italy by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
A major tornado outbreak across the Southern United States kills 57.
Rebel East Timorese soldiers seriously wound President José Ramos-Horta. Rebel leader Alfredo Reinado is killed in the attack.
Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd makes a historic apology to the Indigenous Australians and the Stolen Generations.

Northern Illinois University shooting: A gunman opens fire in a lecture hall of Northern Illinois University in DeKalb County, Illinois, resulting in six fatalities (including the gunman) and 21 injuries.
A United States Air Force B-2 Spirit bomber crashes on Guam, marking  the first operational loss of a B-2.
Fidel Castro retires as the President of Cuba and the Council of Ministers after 32 years. He remains as head of the Communist Party for another three years.
The New York Philharmonic performs in Pyongyang, North Korea; this is the first event of its kind to take place in North Korea.

2009.event: Sixty-six people die in a nightclub fire in Bangkok, Thailand.
The first block of the blockchain of the decentralized payment system Bitcoin, called the Genesis block, is established by the creator of the system, Satoshi Nakamoto.
A 6.1-magnitude earthquake in northern Costa Rica kills 15 people and injures 32.

US Airways Flight 1549 ditches safely in the Hudson River after the plane collides with birds less than two minutes after take-off. This becomes known as "The Miracle on the Hudson" as all 155 people on board were rescued.
Barack Obama is inaugurated as the 44th President of the United States of America, becoming the first African-American President of the United States.
A protest movement in Iceland culminates as the 2009 Icelandic financial crisis protests start.
Israel withdraws from the Gaza Strip, officially ending a three-week war it had with Hamas. However, intermittent fire by both sides continues in the weeks to follow.
President Barack Obama signs an executive order to close the Guantanamo Bay detention camp; congressional opposition will prevent it being implemented.
Cyclone Klaus makes landfall near Bordeaux, France, causing 26 deaths as well as extensive disruptions to public transport and power supplies.
Rioting breaks out in Antananarivo, Madagascar, sparking a political crisis that will result in the replacement of President Marc Ravalomanana with Andry Rajoelina.

2010.event: A devastating earthquake struck Haiti, causing widespread destruction.
A suicide car bomber detonates at a volleyball tournament in Lakki Marwat, Pakistan, killing 105 and injuring 100 more.
The Burj Khalifa, the current tallest building in the world, officially opens in Dubai.

Gunmen from an offshoot of the Front for the Liberation of the Enclave of Cabinda attack a bus carrying the Togo national football team on its way to the 2010 Africa Cup of Nations, killing three people and injuring another nine.
An earthquake in Haiti occurs, killing between 220,000 and 300,000 people and destroying much of the capital Port-au-Prince.
Yemen declares an open war against the terrorist group al-Qaeda.
Rioting begins between Muslim and Christian groups in Jos, Nigeria, results in at least 200 deaths.
Ethiopian Airlines Flight 409 crashes into the Mediterranean Sea off the coast of Na'ameh, Lebanon, killing 90.
The 2009 Honduran constitutional crisis ends when Porfirio Lobo Sosa becomes the new President of Honduras.
A freak storm in the Hindu Kush mountains of Afghanistan triggers a series of at least 36 avalanches, burying over two miles of road, killing at least 172 people and trapping over 2,000 travelers.

2011.event: Osama bin Laden was killed by U.S. forces in Pakistan.
A bomb explodes as Coptic Christians in Alexandria, Egypt, leave a new year service, killing 23 people.
Estonia officially adopts the Euro currency and becomes the 17th Eurozone country.

Sitting US Congresswoman Gabby Giffords is shot in the head along with 18 others in a mass shooting in Tucson, Arizona. Giffords survived the assassination attempt, but six others died, including John Roll, a federal judge.
Iran Air Flight 277 crashes near Urmia in the northwest of the country, in icy conditions, killing 77 people.
President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali of Tunisia seeks refuge in Saudi Arabia after a series of demonstrations against his regime, considered to be the birth of the Arab Spring.
Syrian civil war: The Movement for a Democratic Society (TEV-DEM) is established with the stated goal of re-organizing Syria along the lines of democratic confederalism.
Anti-government demonstrations take place in Tirana, Albania. Four people lose their lives from gunshots, allegedly fired from armed police protecting the Prime Minister's office.
At least 35 are killed and 180 injured in a bombing at Moscow's Domodedovo Airport.
The first wave of the Egyptian revolution begins throughout the country, marked by street demonstrations, rallies, acts of civil disobedience, riots, labour strikes, and violent clashes.
Arab Spring: The Yemeni Revolution begins as over 16,000 protestors demonstrate in Sana'a.

2012.event: The 2012 Summer Olympics opened in London.
Twenty-six people are killed and 63 wounded when a suicide bomber blows himself up at a police station in Damascus.
A hot air balloon crashes near Carterton, New Zealand, killing all 11 people on board.
A bombing at Jamrud in Pakistan, kills at least 30 people and injures 78 others.

Violent protests occur in Bucharest, Romania, as two-day-old demonstrations continue against President Traian Băsescu's economic austerity measures. Clashes are reported in numerous Romanian cities between protesters and law enforcement officers.
The passenger cruise ship Costa Concordia sinks off the coast of Italy due to the captain Francesco Schettino's negligence and irresponsibility. There are 32 confirmed deaths.
The Mali War begins when Tuareg militias start fighting the Malian government for independence.
The Hong Kong-based file-sharing website Megaupload is shut down by the FBI.
Seventy-four people are killed and over 500 injured as a result of clashes between fans of Egyptian football teams Al Masry and Al Ahly in the city of Port Said.
The ferry MV Rabaul Queen sinks off the coast of Papua New Guinea near the Finschhafen District, with an estimated 146-165 dead.
A magnitude 6.7 earthquake hits the central Philippine island of Negros, leaving 112 people dead.

2013.event: At least 60 people are killed and 200 injured in a stampede after celebrations at Félix Houphouët-Boigny Stadium in Abidjan, Ivory Coast.
A gunman kills eight people in a house-to-house rampage in Kawit, Cavite, Philippines.
More than 100 people are killed and 270 injured in several bomb blasts in the Quetta area of Pakistan.
One French soldier and 17 militants are killed in a failed attempt to free a French hostage in Bulo Marer, Somalia.
A train carrying Egyptian Army recruits derails near Giza, Greater Cairo, killing 19 and injuring 120 others.
